[b] Developer's Expectation: [/b] "We made a game that is totally [b] NOT [/b] Pokemon with guns. Explore the world, [strike]catch[/strike] [b] GATHER [/b] them all, and play with your friends together."

[b] Your Expectation from Videos: [/b] "[i]Wait, I can shoot a penguin from a rocket launcher...? [/i] SIGN. ME. UP."

[b] Reality 25 Hours into the Game: [/b] "Well, I've done it. I finally built my bases up to my liking, the workforce is going strong, and I've uncovered every part of the map accessible by Pidgeot, [i] even the parts the Developers didn't expect me to. [/i] Now all I have left is to motivate Depresso to work at full efficiency, and I'll finally be ready to take on the boss and end the Tutorial. It's all coming together."

Good but horrible. Never seen a build mechanic as infuriating as this. Movement is also painfully slow and extremely glitchy. Honestly bad even for an early access game by modern standards.
Why can't you build down a level? Why can you only build out a couple of spaces from a foundation, specifically when building stairs? Why can you build a slanted roof out further than stairs? Why can't you connect anything to a roof or stairs? Why can't you align things? Who designed and QA'd this and thought "yeah, this is acceptable"?

So much has been copied from Ark, and even though that game's build and movement mechanics are not perfect, they are substantially better than this. How is this building and snapping mechanic so bad when a game such as Satisfactory exists?

For a game largely about base building and 100% about moving around, it feels pretty unplayable after a few hours - I don't even want to get into how slow and glitchy movement is...

I'll recommend this game because it is a fun game overall and obviously has potential, but the building and movement is honestly the worst of any survival-type game I've ever played.

UPDATE: Whatever changed in the last version completely broke dedicated servers. This is a major issue for anyone who wants to play multiplayer but doesn't want to be limited to 4 players/wants to be able to turn off the game. Not only was the periodic save corruption not completely fixed, my old server save became corrupted and it seems like all of my save backups were incompatible. I now have to start my game from scratch. On top of this, it seems like the game is saved in a different format depending on the platform (linux, windows, etc.), so migrating my server to my desktop from my linux server is a no go. I like this game, its fun, I will probably restart at some point regardless of this issue, however I cannot recommend it anymore to new players due to the unmitigated technical issues at this point. Pocketpair has had enough time to fix the serious issues and they are moving very slowly.

PREVIOUS REVIEW:
This game is really fun. It does a lot what Pokemon should have done a long time ago, and captures the market segment that Pokemon is missing (older demographic, PC players). If you've seen people complain about it being a ripoff or AI generated, ignore them, they don't know what they are talking about. Of course some of the creatures look similar to their Nintendo counterparts, and they definitely take inspiration from them, but its not plagiarism (and even if it was, I wouldn't really care, it would just be Pokemon on PC; somehow true fan games get a pass but this doesn't).

Anyway now that we got that out of the way, here are some of the things I love about the game:
- 111 monsters to catch, and mechanics to incentivise catching them more than once and actually seeking out their habitats
- Solid (albeit sometimes a little clunky) RPG combat system that integrates guns later in the tech tree
- Speaking of which--massive tech tree
- Difficulty is *very* configurable, so if you don't like drop rates, catch rates, etc. you can change them.
- Community servers (and dedicated server software has a native linux build)
- In-depth, but not ridiculously complicated crafting system
- Funny interactions between monsters

That being said, this *is* an early access game, and there are quite a few bugs to mention at the time of writing this:
- Many many graphical/physics glitches (almost all of them are minor/funny/not game breaking, although there is the occasional getting stuck in the floor; they have a manual respawn button for that)
- Sometimes very strange pathing of worker pals, and they can get stuck if you don't build your base to prevent it.
- Pals on servers that run 24/7 can and will get stuck while you're offline, causing them to not be able to eat and get depressed.
- MASSIVE memory leak on the dedicated server software, forces you to restart it every few hours
- Hostile pals forgetting how to attack (funny mostly)
- Really nasty bug where your save data can get deleted if the server does not shut down properly (I implemented my own periodic backup solution to prevent this from being an issue, if you plan on making a server you should absolutely do this)

There are definitely more that I missed, but those are the big ones I have noticed. Despite the bugs I think the game was money well spent, and am looking forward to changes the devs will make to improve the above issue and add more content to the game. My friends and I have been loving this game, and will for sure continue to play it.

This game is pretty good. Honestly survival games never really scratch that itch for me, but this really got me into it. The auto feeding bag helps manage food intake so you can pretty much ignore it for the most part, but still have to get food.

PALS
- Good range of Pals to work, ride, or fight with.
- A bit buggy in bases, you can also easily clip through the group/walls, but it is fun finding a good combination for what you need.
- Legendary Pals are fun to find and hunt, which is the only end-game really, but the real fun is finding their weakness and making sure your team is prepared for it.

BUILDING
- There is a lot to wish for here. It is fun to find a functional build, but honestly bigger Pals still get stuck regardless.
- Variety needs to be bigger.

Fighting
- Fun to find a good load out with guns/melee. Rocket launcher is just fun in the end-game.
- Progress of guns from makeshift to full automatic rifle is great. The damage variance is a bit low though, and could be more in line with the level difference.

Capturing
- Pal spheres go up tremendously, but the jump gets smaller and smaller toward the end. I believe the Legendary Spheres should be much higher than they are now. Small chances on level 50 Pals shouldn't happen. Honestly it should be closer to 50% on non-legendary.
- Capturing itself is fun and very addicting. The capture progress being 10 of each and being your primary way to level is fun as well.

Resources
- It's kind of boring to have "best base location" where there is only really one place that spawns the more important ores together at a decent rate.
- Most are buy-able in the end-game, but Pal Fluid is not, and that is a bit annoying. If I have 1 million of the currency and Pal Oil is the only thing I need, I should be able to buy it instead of spending an hour farming water types for it.

Mounts
- Most are fun, and it is fun to progress from the first ones to the later game ones.
- I hate that it takes up a Pal spot, because you breed one for specifically riding, and you don't use it in combat for the most part.
- I'll consider the glider Pals as mounts, as they also need to have a dedicated spot and not on your Pal team. The glider Pals are also fun to mess around with, and find one you like.

Breeding
- Fun as long as your hatch time isn't super long.
- Finding the right temperature for the type you want is cool, but having to have a dedicated Pal to head/cool a large amount is a bit of a pain. If it uses electricity it should be Pal-less.

There is a lot more to this game, and it is extremely fun. Sure you can say "it's a Pokemon knockoff", but that is mostly only the Pal/capture system you can say that on. The other systems you use are a huge part of the game as well.

I mostly bought Palworld thanks to the hype, I figured any game that sold millions of copies in the first week after release must be worthwhile. It was.
Overall, it's like Ark: Survival Evolved with more diverse and recognizable creatures, and less nerve wracking; beat up animals until you can forcibly tame them and make them work for you collecting resources and carrying you around, use resources to build a shelter using predesigned components for floors, walls, doorways, and roofs, and invariably ragequit when you leave your base untended to for too long and everything dies of starvation leading to you having to hunt down replacements for every creature you had tamed.
Except Palworld takes all of that and makes it better. Taming animals doesn't require you to stand around waiting for an unconscious animal to slowly wake up from a coma before it listens to you, you just have to beat it up a bit and throw your balls in its face. Forgetting to feed your pals doesn't result in them all dying and you having to track down and tame replacements, they just get knocked out like Pokemon and recover after taking a ten minute time-out in the palbox. Structures don't degrade over time for no reason like in Ark, they all stay up as long as they're within range of your palbox. Caves are exciting and interesting dungeon crawls with rare resources instead of a cramped nightmare of broken pathfinding and way too many giant bugs trying to crawl up your ass and eat you from the inside out.
Don't get me wrong, there are still issues that come along with an early access game, mostly in npc pathfinding (how the hell did my loupmoon get itself stuck on the roof AGAIN!?), game loading problems with crafting stations, and a lack of main story (at least in my opinion). As with any early access game, there will be some issues, but I've played enough games to recognize which ones are problems with the core game itself, as opposed to quality of life and final polish, and so far everything here makes for a solid framework.
Just make sure to catch ten of every pal you run into so you get all the good xp, it drops off big time if you're just killing them.

This is the first game I've ever left a review on for Steam Games. While I've massively enjoyed other games like the Ori games, Celeste, Rivals of Aether, Slay The Princess, etc, there's just something special about this game. I'll give you 5 pros, 5 cons, and then my personal opinion of the game.

Pros
1. Look and runs otherwordly. I can't believe this games runs this well.
2. 85% of of the designs are lovely and memorable. (My Personal top five are Katress, Wixen, Sazuka, Quivern, and Chillet.)
3. Monster collecting, open world, and survival, but still separates itself enough from Pokemon, Breath Of The Wild, and Ark.
4. The memes are *chef's kiss*.
5. Every pal is different and unique in some way, shape or form.
lot.
Cons
1. Lag a lot online.
2. Mouse and controller sometimes lock and you're unable to switch between keyboard and controller a lot.
3. Boring type charts and combinations.
4. Sometimes, Pals just don't spawn in... like, at all.
5. Character customization is boring and uninteresting. Needs more options.

Overall, this is a great 9/10 game. I haven't had this much fun with a game in forever. This is far from a Pokemon rip off. While this game isn't as good as Pokemon, it has well beyond the potential to be better, and is still just in early access. If the full release does come out, if done well, this could be the game of the year. Maybe even a decades top listed. 

And just remember, Pokemon stole designs from Dragon Quest... sooo...
good game

This game is the rebound relationship for ARK: Survival Evolved and Pokemon fans.

Tech, crafting/automation, and XP (for new pals) all scale well as you level thru the game; doesn't feel to grindy until you try breeding pals, which is the only endgame activity atm.

Palworld made me realize how much I've tortured myself with bad creature-collector games. As it is now, Palworld is very fun. However, the game will feel empty as you level and explore more of the map. With its current amount of content, I'd value this game at $20-25, which is pretty close to its current asking price.

Palworld needs more options for automation (e.g. task assignments/checkboxes). Thankfully devs are working on bug fixes now; there are some handfuls of bugs. Server hosting needs to be fixed; I want to rent a server from a partner of Pocketpair ASAP, rather than use an unaffiliated third-party or giving out my IP address; this is not a development issue though.

Common critiques I see of this game are it's "unpolished" and "lacks personality." That may be true. Yet, as I said, the game appeals to some disenfranchised fanbases who know who they are. gg

This game is pretty much if Ark: Survival Evolved and Pokemon had a baby. It is a ton of fun and someone could easier get hooked on it for hours. If you're a person who loves the crafting and survivalablity in Ark but want an easier way to tame creatures? this game is for you.

This will almost certainly becomes as thumbs-up as the game progresses and eventually comes out of early access.  THERE IS AN AMAZING GAME THERE, it's just too early.

For now, for all the great fun there is to be had, a lot of it is an exercise in frustration and/or in messing with the rules/difficulty to make the experience acceptable.

There are 2 big points that need to be addressed before I feel I can recommend this to my friends.


FIRST. pal behavior in base is just plain horrid.
- Larger pals get stuck everywhere.
- Assignment are fluky and break all the time.
- AI sometimes simply breaks and does nothing, except go hungry and unhappy (because it's not eating). Need to remove & readd to base to 'reset'.
- Half of the big stuff (nodes mining, breeding) only happens while you are physically present in the base, making secondary bases pretty useless and defeating the purpose of a lot of the timer base gameplay.
- Impossible to set priorities, and pals make terrible decisions, interrupting their activities all the time, and switching like headless chickens.
- Transporting is a scourge, bugs all the time, and prevent pals from doing their primary function.
- Watering is currently the worse, because no small pals have a decent rating, and all the lvl 3 and 4 are VERY prone to getting stuck and breaking, needing constant baby sitting (at least other jobs have regular size lvl 3...  thanks god for Raghawk,Eileen, Verdash, Anubis, etc).
- Simply put, base management is uber micromanagy, buggy and is an exercise in frustration at the moment.


SECOND, balancing is waaaay off.  
- Levelling curve is brutal past 38.
- Catch rates are dubious, especially on later pals, even when using legendary balls with max lifemunks (I understand the need to persevere, but having to throw 35 balls every time to catch jetdragon is just tedious, give me a more expensive ball then). 
- A handful of ingredients need to be grinded (pal oil, pal fluid) while the rest is overflowing and plentiful.
- The legendary schematics drop rate is tiny and they are instrumental in end game, making the whole thing a fluke.
- Player damage and attack stat utility is clearly dubious. It does something, but it's too subtle and really it's the last thing everyone invests in.
- The final boss fight is crazy. Absolutely not in line with rest of progression Huge difficulty spike, requiring legendaries and massive breading to beat (at least for me).
- Etc.


Oh, and I would be remiss not to mention how this game was uncomfortably inspired by (aka shameless pilfered) a bunch of other great titles.  This isn't a criticism, and the result is very promising, but if everybody did the same...  hrm, I don't know.  Anyway, credit where credit is due...

- Pals are obviously Pokemons.
- The environments/world is very inspired from Elden Ring, sparsely populated, with ruins and campfires.
- The jingles and zone intros are straight from Zelda.
- The boss intros are from Borderlands.
- The core loop and base building owes a lot to a bunch of tree punchers (Valheim chiefly) but now this is more a genre than anything else.
- Etc.


LASTLY, I don't play multiplayer with strangers, because humans are terrible ;)  So I don't have the problems people are having on public servers, but apparently it's not good.  So if that's your jam, beware.  But solo or coop with friends, that's obviously a non-issue.

So bottom line, it's is normal for things in early access to not be settled, so I'm not saying the current state is unacceptable, but I wouldn't recommend the game right now. It will be so much better later, don't spoil it for yourself... I wish I hadn't.

My experience with the game has been positive, mainly playing on a private server and in co-op/single-player. I've defeated most tower bosses and acquired many pals, but the end-game lacks activities to maintain interest, there is potential for improvement in this area, maybe the pal arena will be the answer. The game suffers from stability issues(lots of crashing), poor pal AI, and numerous glitches, especially with pals getting stuck or not performing tasks when you fast travel away. My brief time on official servers was disappointing due to frequent crashes and a hacker problem leading to a complete progress wipe. Despite these issues, the game offers good value, and has huge potential.



TLDR; Overall, an addicting experience, expect bugs while things are still being worked on. Avoid official/public servers like the plague until the hacker issue is dealt with. Well worth the money spent.

As someone who has played games for most my life even going back to one of my favorite games made 35 years ago I can solidly state this game is the greatest game ever made.  Sure there are a few bugs like the pals have a tiny bit of movement issues when traveling and doing tasks that they do on their own far better than me commanding them to do so but for the issues they have the reality is they have the greatest movement out of any NPCs ever made and the tiny glitches they have are funny and add emotion to them but are so insignificant that to correct their movements is as simple as picking them up or going to the box and moving them up and back down to the area and the tiny glitch is fixed and they mostly get hung up on your poor base building but its funny especially when you are mining and they just suddenly drop the stuff they were mining and stand on top of the rock they were mining and look smug doing so which is so human of them to take a break and pretend to be the king of the world on top of the rock.  The fact that the game renders the entire map at once and has 0 loading screens is insane on how perfect it is.  The movement is the best I have ever played in any game especially for its time.  The tiny glitches that get found are fixed faster than any other programmers have ever done.  The games map is frog flipping huge to a point of insanity and unlike every other game ever made its not empty like big game development companies keep lying about.  I normally never say this but if someone is claiming the game is bad they are lying about the issues.  Hell you can kick anyone form the server just by reporting them to the server leader and the ability to play online I have not done quite yet but dear god this game is near perfect.  The emotions the pals have.  The ability to build.  The ability to do so much with so little is just insane.  The ability to explore without being insulted is insanely good.  Straight up every thing I find in the game gets better and better and the game has so much that can be done that is being done.  There is just so much to the game that its literally insane.  The programming of how to move I can switch between flying, gliding, and back to flying mount better than I can walk in most games.  I can use the glider better than a thruster pack in Halo.  The aiming in the game is the best I have ever done.  The controls are seamless in their perfection.  The emotion and the building.  I admit it I got worse than addicted to the game.  The game put me into the gamer zone for 17 hours straight 3 times because its so good which is why I have taken a tiny break so that I can recover my strength because it caused me physical damage to smile so much from playing such a fun game.  I like to smile but the game caused my emotions to stretch myself so much it caused physical damage from being so fun to play.  So yea the main con of the game is its so fun it will cause physical damage.

Incredibly undercooked, even for early access. Pal pathing: non-existent. Bases that are supposed to be automated, with pals mining in your absence, fail to load while your character is away. When they reload, pals are often on top of roofs, or nodes of ore, despite your best efforts to build in pal-friendly ways. (Indeed, much of the game is centered around avoiding its bugs and feature incompleteness.) Palworld should have entered early access with the ability to prioritize tasks, at the very least, as you quickly find that half your roster can't be deployed at base because they have sub-specialties in useless tasks. 

The base building mechanics are likewise abysmal. There is incredibly limited ability to snap to components, as well as lack of angled and rotated pieces (or the ability to rotate them yourself). Building on anything but level ground is a chore at best, impossible at worst, as you fail to determine how to clip objects to something approaching attractiveness. It's the building that is what usually keeps me coming back to a survival-craft entry like Palworld, and it's sorely lacking here.

Here's the thing. Palworld may take its influences from other types of games or genres, but honestly, what games don't or haven't, over time? Even Pokemon wasn't original in its 'monster catching/using' idea, it just happened to be the Oreo to the Oreo/Hydrox way of things. Hydrox was first, but Oreo became the big man on campus.

That said, Palworld did something incredible in that this comparatively-small dev team proved that people were tired of Pokemon's rehashing and phoning it in, and wanted a breath of fresh air to the genre, and it made the king, the giant of that genre, bleed, from its seemingly-invincible mountaintop throne. It cut, and it cut deep with the first strike, with the wants and needs of the fans of that genre all holding and slashing that sword with that initial blow.

Is the game perfect? Not at all. It's in Early Access. Things aren't completely fleshed out, bugs are crawlin' in the gears, even terrain in certain areas have their issues. And yet, with all the flaws and roughness around the edges, you see people diving in and loving every minute.  When a game has its glaring issues and problems but you still have fans goin' for it, accepting it with its warts and all, you know you've got the start of something that could be huge.

Not only does Palworld give us a world to explore, it allows the players freedom in customizing their experiences from the start. When making a world you can set creature spawn, damage modifiers, changes to timers and building deterioration, stamina bar use, it goes on and on.  "Here's the world, make it comfortable for you and have fun." You capture creatures to work and explore alongside you, you meet their needs as they help you with yours, you build bases from the ground up and make patches of the world your own.

You're not gonna find a deep story right now, you're not gonna find engaging NPCs that draw you in deeper. What you'll find is go in, capture, build, explore, and just enjoy doing it while trying to work around shortcomings and bugs that may be frustrating, but with some patience and grit, you'll be ok.

With all that, I just hope that Pocketpair actually stays with it. They've struck oil, but now's the time to refine it further. If the devs can keep it up and listen well to the players while doing so, everyone's gonna be in for a fantastic ride.

I've had straight up *fun* playing this, and if you can get friends along for the ride, even better.  Ignore clickbait articles, rumors, and fans trying to rush to the defense of their precious multi-billion-dollar company as if they have personal stock in it.

Just have fun.

Ark meets Pokemon, what an awesome combo.  :)

The game, like Ark, is very very grindy and requires a lot of time getting resources in order to build what you needs. So if you are familiar with Ark and how you level up and spend points for blueprints and then grind for materials... there is the core of the game.

Add into the Ark mix wild Pokemon type animals and the theme of knocking the health down do you can throw a capture ball at them... then reuse those creatures in battle... there is your Pokemon type of theme.

I really really love the mix of the two of these, just a lot of fun in a HUGE HUGE open world. Nice job!!

=== Update ===

Repetitive, grind, pointless, same content recycled over and over and over... I realize its early access, but I am tired of being shot through wall, set on fire with no healing or way to put out the flames, so you just watch your health wear down and you die. It all just feel totally pointless...

If it goes on sale, a GOOD sale, sure give it a try. But right now, it is destined to become a title that collects dust in your library.

Love this game, as many people have said, this does add mechanics that we have wanted Pokemon to do for years. The amount of pals you can use as mounts in this game is sick as hell, using pals as weapons is a really fun mechanic, and the world has been fun enough to explore. The biggest issues with the game is the stability, especially on multiplayer serves, but at time of writing, most of those issues seem to have been solved? 

The base building mechanic seems good enough to build what you like, and I really appreciate that you can put your pals to work and still like, take care of their basic needs. It is weird that the marketing is like, " you can work your pals like slaves!", but the sanity mechanic really seems to disincentivize you to do that, and the game really wants you to take care of your workers so your base can be sustainable. 

Over all, I've enjoyed my time with the game, it is different enough from pokemon to feel like it's own thing. Not sure if they will add more options to engage with the combat aspects, would love to see them add more ways to use your pals directly in combat, instead of watching them fight automatically. Not sure how they would do that though without changing the nature of the combat. Looking forward to more npcs and quests as the game is developed!

Decent so far, but has some serious problems.

The game is insanely grindy, like, significantly worse than any other survival game I have played. Some of the grind can be alleviated through world settings, like resource drops and EXP, but others, like the insanely slow Pal work speed (which wouldn't be as big a problem if working pals had better AI/mangrment) is stuff there is no in game setting for.

It also just has the general survival open world problems. Map isn't very interesting to look at or explore (honestly can be shrunk a decent bit.. it's 70% generic open world grassy hills.) And the game is extremely glitch, but that's kinda to be expected for the stat it's in.

It has promise but is really rough around the edges, and can get repetitive very fast, even for the type of game it is.
As a superior being, I really enjoyed this game.

The Pokemon like game we never got, To me this game is like the Skyrim of the Catchem games. Offering you real-time battles instead of slow turn based moves, the game feels pretty fleshed out for 28 euro's. 

The positives can be outlined in the following points.

1: The Battle system is fun and does not feel like a drag
2: progression is fast / passed perfectly by default
3: Combat and base building is similar to many other games from Sunkenland to Raft e.t.c
4: Each PAL is unique and has a specific role set. 
5: They took inspiration of the best aspects of different genres and combined it to make this alot of fun.

Downsides currently in Feb 2024

1: there are bugs in Unreal engine, you need to enable page-file for example to prevent system locks or memory leaks, this is not documented anywhere.

2: The light sources are drawn very near and cant be adjusted so at night the only light sources close to you are drawn, this behaviour cant be edited with known unreal engine cmdlets inside of the engine.ini

3: This game is in Beta and the team developing this game are kind of like Hello Games, small and inexperienced but also impassioned  so expect great things but also expect it can take awhile like no man's sky.

4: Clipping and falling through the world is common, tricks like summoning your pal and choosing F to ride to get above ground is an easy fix, but its common enough to be annoying. 

In conclusion / final thoughts.

When we consider the full priced and micro-transaction culture that games of this type are in, this game is a breath of fresh air. It comes with features and options that other game publishers should have included in their own releases a decade ago. 

In summary if you are a fan of For example of Catch em Games and or like base building games or games you need to explore in. Gives this game a go I highly recommend it.

Palworld is a great game, variety of pals, the base building is fun and exploration is good and doesn't feel repetitive. Large map considering it is only early access also. As it stands the NPCs are very 2 dimensional and add little to the actual game in terms of story, but it's still early access. good!

100+ hours Single player review  
Runs shockingly well for an early access game only crashed one time at 100 hours in testing the VR mod in UEVR at max settings on a laptop RTX3080. honestly unless your playing online this game runs better than most supposedly finished games out there, so Kudos to the Optimizer for a job well done.

the game is an interesting take on the survival genre and though the first two hours gives the impression its going to be a boring craft-a-thon like so many others in the genre Palworld saves itself from falling into that pit by its inventive use of Pal's.

where other open world survivals devolve quickly into doing daily monotonous crafting chores
you quickly learn that each pal is capable of doing a different set of chores around the house and though its a little buggy later on as your base grows more complex in the late game
a few hours in and you will find yourself Free to explore while your Totally VOLUNTARY totally not forced to work "Family" of pals holds down the Planta..uh..Homestead crafting the bullets, and cooking  the meals while you explore the surprisingly diverse and absolutely massive map hunting bosses and discovering new critters to catch, each having surprisingly individual AI that reacts differently to the players actions.

Palworld offers 2 preset difficulties and a HIGHLY recommended Custom mode that allows you to blend almost every element of the game to your tastes; Hate grinding? just multiply XP gain and item drop rates. Combat to easy? you can make almost anything able you one-shot you into a re-spawn if you don't dodge roll and pay attention to attack animations. want too fight 3 bosses at once?it has you covered .....you masochistic freak.

Basically the game takes the Survival Genres and uses blends of other games you may have played before like Elden Ring, or Mother Base style work recruitment from MetalGear solid and a surprisingly small dash of Pokemon and uses them to fix many of the weaknesses of Survival games that get in the way of just having fun and exploring while giving the mountains of caught monsters something more to do than rot in storage.

the rougher elements like the copy past Dungeons , some useless or dead end mechanics and craftable items could simply be due to the games incomplete state but even if we never saw the endgame or even a single update and PocketPair vanished into the night its more than worth the $30 you pay for the 60-200 hours you can get out of it.

Palworld is truly a wonderful game. It's still in an early phase and lacks content in some areas but the Devs have assured us updates are coming! It's a breath of fresh air to have a developer that cares about their game and understands players will move on to play other games! If you're looking for a relaxed survival and world-building experience that has a Pokemon feel but is it's own game then definitely pick this game up! 10/10.

A fairly relaxing game that involves exploring and capturing 'pals'. They have various abilities and you can use them to gather resources and fight for you. There isn't much of a story unfortunately but there are world bosses to challenge.

You build a base to get better equipment and to keep your team fed. It can be a bit tedious to reach max level - you need to capture each pal 10 times for bonus XP. There are many settings you can change to suit your play style.

I did turn off base raids. Defences don't always work and it gets annoying repairing stuff. There are bugs where pals in your base regularly get stuck - you have to save them or they will starve.

On a side note, the dev's Craftopia game has been in early access since 2020 for some reason. If your waiting for Palworld to get a full release, it likely won't happen anytime soon.

Okay, so, this opinion comes from someone who plays (and has played) a shitton of video games ever since I was 4 years old--im not saying this to try and validate my opinion, but rather so you maybe get a better understanding of why I say certain things about this game in the following. I like monster tamers, I like exploration games, I'd even say the latter, while rather vague as a genre for video games, is probably what I enjoy the most. 
Palworld, as an open-world, monster tamer a la pokemon, immediately struck me as smth I would enjoy, and that I did. But this still is not something to get if you're looking for some kind of meaningful or memorable experience. It's basically junk food, as a video game. This game combines so many things from different titles (Pokemon, Breath of the wild, name any other survival game here); which isn't necessarily a bad thing in of itself, but it lacks a load of polish in everything. The world is rather empty, not particularly interesting to explore, the design of the monsters is mostly fun but nothing super exciting, the crafting and power progression makes the game rather grindy, which can be tuned down via world settings and I found that rather refreshing. It's fun for some time, but you really feel the fact that this game is just a jumble of different stuff, which was the same case for their previous game, Craftopia. In that sense, their games never feel like they have any love put into them, which is a shame. It feels more like a product than an experience. Yes, games are bought, and thus they are products. But to me, the value of a game often lies in the illusion they provide. When I play Outer Wilds, I get lost in the world, explore and ponder; when I play Monster Sanctuary, I get to think about how to build my team and rejoice every time I find a new exciting monster or secret path somewhere in the world, as I get lost in the fantasy of being a monster tamer; technically Palworld should provide me with this kind of feeling but it really really doesn't. I'm constantly taken out of the experience by the game: When I glide or climb, or look at the not-a-sheika-slate I immediately think of Zelda ("BUT CLIMBING WASN'T INVENTED BY ZEL-" Yes, I know Zelda didn't invent climbing, but the fact that the mechanic was literally plucked from BotW down to the very animation, is just plain disappointing), when I look at the "Pal Sphere" you bet all I see is a pokeball from Fiverr (for an example of smth inspired by pokemon like this, but well done, look no further than Cassette Beasts). Palworld doesnt do anything to really distinguish itself in terms of character. And while "Pokemon with guns" sounds fun to begin with, it honestly just feels like the guns were yet another thing simply shoehorned into this game because, guns are fun, right? Guns are fun, so guns will sell. It's not that well-integrated into the game and feels a bit random. Which leads to this game seeming like a somewhat soulless cash-grab (which is fine, but it doesnt do a lot to improve my view on this game either) in the sense that everything inside it is just there because of its popularity, not because it works well with the other mechanics in the game. 
As an early access game, this one also has a whole lotta bugs, constantly: there are problems with the pals' pathfinding, they consistently got stuck on top of buildings in my playthrough, preventing them from actually working in my base while I was outside doing things. Pals, particularly the larger "Alpha Pals" would often take off into the skies or get hit by an attack of my own pals so hard, they got smashed through the ground and went out of bounds, but still continued to attack me afterwards. Climbing is a bit janky, but frankly, "janky" and "clunky" are rather apt descriptions for the gameplay feel in general.
But, that doesn't mean you can't have fun with it. Which is why I'm still technically recommending this game. I might be ranting about this kind of analytical, nerdy stuff, but most people don't care about these things all too much. If you're just looking for an easy time sink with a continuous dopamine stream, you'll find it here. I'd give the game a 6.5/10. I'm sure most people will have a decently good time with this.

Review at 17 hours.
First lets talk basic mechanics. The movement feels very slow even when you are sprinting and the world is really big so it feels like it takes forever to get somewhere. The climbing is hit or miss (literally). Sometimes it seems you can grab things you where never meant to, other times you can't grab the plain flat wall. Moving on the progression feels very slow. Even on 2x it takes a long time to level after around level 12. This usually then requires you to run dungeons, which in general feel very empty and there is usually only 1 chest other than the 2 post-boss. These chests then don't drop more than some palspheres and coins. So getting anything blueprints is a bit of a grind, not to mention the resources to make the gear.

Now lets talk about the Pals and NPCs themselves. A big issue that I have seen far to commonly is that NPCs tend to get stuck in terrain. Another issue that has arisen is some will not eat even if their SAN is maxed and
they have food, leading to them getting sick. The last issue I have with them is half of them feel useless. Other than the attributes that the type comes with (handiwork, lumbering, etc) each Pal has a unique skill. Some, like the
Digtoise which can mine for you, are very useful. Others, like the Galeclaw which can be used as a glider, are less useful. (You can make yourself a glider). Many have the exact same traits but just look different. So unless you are going for the full Paldeck, they are not worth getting.

Lastly lets discuss map and transportation. As I wrote above the map is big. There are many pals that can be used to get around, some more useful than others. Many are rideable so you have your pick between ground, air, and water,
this being said, there is truly only one mount for ground worth getting imo and that is the Direhowl. It has a faster movement speed than anything else I have found so far, meaning there is no reason to grab something for movement
other than this. When I finally made a saddle for a flyer, I was rather disappointed when the stamina bar lasted 30 seconds to both get me in the air and moving. Once I did it was incredibly slow. Due to map size, this has ultimately driven me to continue ridding my direhowl as to not land every 30 seconds for stamina.

All in all, this game is fun and has a lot of potential, but I feel it needs a few updates. I'm not saying it is bad, but at this time I cannot recommend.

Okay, listen - Take ARK: Survival Evolved. Turn the dinosaurs into bootleg Pokemon. Put them to work like they're thralls you stole in Conan: Exiles. Explore a world climbing and gliding like Breath of the Wild. Fight bosses like in Elden Ring. Strive for the tree in the distance like in Valheim.

This title doesn't wear its influences on its sleeve - it has them tattooed on its face. Don't think that means it's any less sincere. This is not a 'good' game - not yet. It is however really fun. (EA, Feb 2024) This is the start of a potentially incredible game that could become a juggernaut in the genre once some holes are patched and more content added. That said, if this looks interesting, it's going to be hard NOT to get your money's worth.

This game is not particularly appropriate for small children. Teenagers should be fine. The Sheikah-dex leans into some content that's going to be on a kid-by-kid basis. Copyright-Friendly-Monster 069 is DTF for instance.

On one hand, I kind of don't want to write this review because I know that I am not a big fan of and am biased against base-building/crafting games like Valheim or The Forest and creature-capture games such as Pokemon. But this game already had a lot of positive reviews so I'm going to play as devil's advocate and provide some reasons as to why you shouldn't play this game, other than the fact that I simply didn't like the theme/genre of the game...

This game tries so hard to be everything in a sense that it tries to implement every single mechanic that makes other games "fun". It has grappling hooks and climbing mechanics and it also tries to be an automation game like Factorio in some ways. Unfortunately for me at the very least, all of these mechanics sucked in this game. Grappling hooks work poorly, and climbing feels so janky more often than not. Pals would frequently get stuck in weird places and couldn't find their way to a facility when your base is elevated and contains multiple floors.

IMO the progression system also felt pretty basic and it only felt unique in the first few hours of playtime. You started off crafting some basic facilities and the more you play, you will still do the same thing you did 10 hours ago except that you got to do it much faster due to better quality items/facilities and more Pals to lend you a hand. Yeah, you got to see and capture different Pals but the world itself is devoid of things that make the game interesting other than the fact that it has different Pals throughout different regions of the game.

I know of the fact that this game is still in Early Access, and so one day when they finally release the final version of the game, I will be giving it another chance. Meanwhile, I hope that they improve on the game's flaws but for now, my opinions on the game remain unchanged.

TLDR: If you like any of the genres it's tagged in, basically, try it. It is worth the hype. Don't buy it if you just want a quick laugh at "pokemon with guns" as the guns are end game and having played 35 hours at the moment divided somewhat evenly across both a personal save and a multiplayer world with a friend, I have not yet unlocked the first gun you can craft, so keep that in mind. The guns are end game. That is all

-

Gives me feels that Pokemon hasn't given me since I was a drooling little child and played it for the first time. In the current state of each franchise, this is better than pokemon, seems to have passionate devs who will make it even better and constantly fixing bugs.

If you're worried about microtransactions, there are NONE. You can get everything in the game from playing. There isn't any function in the game where you have to pull out your real-world credit card.

There's definitely the meme that it's pokemon with guns but the guns are end-game so if you only want to buy it for a quick laugh with the gun thing, then it may not be a good idea. If you want a survivalcraft monster catcher of impeccable quality considering the development rollercoaster that spat out this game, or even if you just want a new survival game that's better than most of the indie ones that have been released in the past few years, I can't reccommend it enough. I've already ordered my first Pal plushie. I'm in deep. 

After being left behind by pokemon after being a lifelong obsessive fan, this is filling the void, not because it's copying pokemon and being the exact same game, but because it's a new, fresh and innovative take on the monster collection genre the likes of which hasn't been seen yet. This is like an alternate universe where game freak decided to be at all creative with pokemon during the last 20+ years of having the rights to make its mainline games. Completely different gameplay loop. Like a lot of other reviews said, the gameplay is more like Ark but if the dinos were "pokemon".

Another thing to keep in mind is that there is really no way to completely avoid some kind of cruelty towards the pals even if totally by accident (you have to beat them up yourself to catch them the first few times which was... something I had to get used to) however if you want to play cruelly you can and if you want to avoid it at all costs and be a benevolent god, then you can do that too. In my experience trying to play both games, the game doesn't reward you extra for either play style leading both to be valid options for a full experience of the game. There are people who play through with a team full of their favorite creature and people who play without catching any Pals and just use human slaves - your morality is yours to choose.

Pretty much everything about the difficulty and every setting is customizable, and there is already a pretty healthy mod scene for the game if you somehow get bored with everything there already is to see, do and experience.

About: Palworld is a very chill and relaxing game, reminiscent of both ARK: Survival and Slime Rancher with a Pokemon twist. 

Review: The game still could use a lot of work in regards to debugging and some basic functionality issues, alongside a complete lack of storyline. I enjoy the concept of traveling the landscape trying to find and collect as many different creatures as possible, finding new eggs and discovering some beautiful scenery. I also like the combat, especially in caves, bossfights, or just trying to survive the more harsh creatures/NPCs! The downside is, unless you enjoy exploring, collecting, upgrading, and building, with a dash of resource/creature farming for materials, there isn't much more to the game at this point. I desperately wish there was a storyline or quests (or more of a point to the NPCs), and I find the economy side of the NPCs in it's current state to be very lacking. There are a couple funny easter eggs in NPC interactions, though!

It's still very fun how it is, and I hope they'll have the support to finalize this game! 

Takeaway: Definitely worth giving it a chance! It's a fun and chill game that has a lot of potential if given the proper support.

This game is decidedly fine. It's basically ARK but with a Pokemon skin. The content that is in the game so far matches the price, so you can't go wrong with this one. It's fine for what it is. I can see why people are enjoying it. I am too, but I'm not totally in love just yet. So far it's been fun but I need a little more; I'll get to that in a moment.

As far as complaints, the game does get a little grindy. I get why though - it needs to be that way for right now so that you don't run out of things to do right away. Also, some aspects of the game do come off as odd or off-kilter. I don't think any of it ruins the game, but you don't feel like a protagonist who is doing good things. You mostly come off as a ruthless survivalist who is doing whatever they can do to manage their situation. In a game of this genre, that doesn't really create the atmosphere you'd expect or desire. I'm sure this is related to the early state of the game also, and will improve as it becomes more complete.

Stuff I would like to see in the future would be an actual campaign / story mode, and more ways to control your Pals during battle. I really hope that's where this is headed eventually because I would love that a lot.

Holding my thumb up for now. Good stuff.

Update: Having completed my grind to 50, I still think the game has a lot of potential. Hope it turns into a deeper and more complex game over time.

In my opinion, Palworld may be the best game on the first quarter of 2024. I love everything about this game, especially the idea of giving guns to Pokemon lol.

However, I think the base building mechanics can be improved. Here are some of my suggestions.
1. Allow players to stack foundations vertically. That way we can build cool bases on the cliff, or around the cliff.
2. Allow players to build wall around the bottom of foundation.
3. Allow players to turn on/off overlapping structure from the option menu. This will make it easier for some players to build cool stuff.

Overall, it's 9/10 from me.

overview:

A lot of people say it's Pokemon with guns. I can see it but have you played any survival game like NMS or ARK or even to a point Zelda: breathe of the wilds it takes a lot more from that then anything else. That being said the Pals are fun and you can see influence of other games within it. The game is still early access and updates have been coming fast in that sense.

Pro's and Cons

Pros: Addictive, if your into survival games. You will plan to spend half an hour playing and next thing you know 5 hours have gone by. For it being in Beta there is a lot less bugs/crashing then I expected. Game mechanics run well. visually it look good, The map is huge with many ways to explore it.  it's very open once you finish the tutorial you can do whatever you want... or ignore the tutorial and do what you want from the start with it sitting there in the corner advising you to do it. 

Cons: The tutorial is weak and doesn't explain how to do everything and maybe if i read the handbook or whatever it is called i would. I am stubborn and unless it shows me how to do something i'll just try and figure it out at some point or end up seeing a video about it somewhere. Building in the game if annoying as you can't level out the ground or thing say they overlap for no reason or won't connect where they should. No real progressive story line unless it is in the journals since you do run into other people getting a quest or fetch quest here and there would be nice. So when i want to waste 5 hours doing whatever i can but if i feel like being productive in the game i can as well.  Pals getting stuck randomly and stupidly in the base. I am not sure how many times some Pal gets stuck in the logging site somehow at the top of a tree and it doesn't matter if they do that task or not. 


Future or changes to be seen:

Ignoring the video showing new features coming and the talk of an arena for PVP. I would want to see things change without adding mods to do it. Like increasing  base influence size as you increase level, more character customisation and being able to edit character within the game. AS mentioned in Cons a quest system with main and side quest. So somethings get rid of the need to hold X to do it. like hatching an egg that you have waited for why can't i just hit it or freeing a pal from a cage even building things to a point. for building maybe take skyrim's mining approach tap it and then see the character work until you move  or cancel the action. Having a safety script or something to ensure Pals don't get stuck for no reason in base. 

Just minor things but increased or no level Cap, a pal caught counter to let you know if you need them still for the first ten or not. Quicker movement all around not dramatically but besides the animation sometimes i can't tell if I am spiriting or not. While playing with a controller make the map not so jumpy it works fine on the xbox but on the PC it is easier to use the mouse when using the Map. Adding in fast travel from Base.


Overall Thoughts

It's a good game at a good price (for now) and worth playing. Most issues I have with the game can be fixed by mods. The developers  are really cool check out there interviews. Also the PC version runs much better then the xbox version. I am sure anyone that tries this game will enjoy it and considering that again it is early access how much there is to do or get lost to do in the game is impressive.
Absolute adventure!

So...Palworld came out and it was a bit of a success to massively understate things. I was looking forward to this game for years partially because of the memes but also because Pocketpair seemed to have learned their lessons from Craftopia (Which is still in development, It aint dead, though the Xbox version has been giving them headaches) from what I saw of the trailers. I played a LOT of craftopia with the wife last December and wrote a review of it.

At this point Pretty much everyone has their takes on it and everyone more or less knows what It is (TL:DR A.R.K With Not-pokemon with guns). Personally I think the controversies are dumb and its bait for the terminally online twiterrati to be mad but Instead of droning on about it (and I nearly did for half the review before deciding its not productive) I'm going to shift this in a different direction

I'm going to directly compare Palworld to Craftopia since its Craftopia 2 in a lot of ways since that's where my perspective is mostly from and its something that at least contributes to the general conversation.

In short Its overall a better experience than Craftopia, Especially at the start and as a result it is one of my favorite Open World Survivalcrafts. However I think Palworld is a weaker Multiplayer experience despite having vastly better netcode. I recommend it but It does have some questionable design decisions.

Palworld is a quantum leap in terms of QOL and this is why the game had its massive initial positive reception. Its performant, mostly controls well and has far better menus. Nevermind far shallower crafting trees (which is a good thing coming from Craftopia), better Automation, and better onboarding makes it a far more accessable experience. Its not perfect and in fact I'll call out a few pain points but coming from craftopia, its a massive improvement.

The Better automation Is the signature mechanic of Palworld. Instead of doing the tedious crafting and collecting, you let pals do it for you! Craftopia Had automation but it was kind of awkward to set up and use well with various drones and machines you had to craft (often with multiple stages of crafting). It also lead to your PC chugging with the amount of entities involved, Palworld is FAR More performant and scalable given the nature of the game being centered around the Pals instead of the kitchen sink. Instead of a hilariously chaotic factory and house, you get cute "Not Pokemon" doing all your jobs each well animated with far more personality than your average Pokemon, Sure the designs may be similar, but Pocketpair gets more mileage out of em because of how much they can express themselves in each Animation state. The fact that its pretty darn painless to set up (Basically pop your pals with the appropriate skills and facilities in and go) makes it leaps and bounds over most everything else I've tried in the genre.

However it is still somewhat flawed, Pathing issues aside (which can be circumvented by popping your pal inside a box and back to work or just grabbing them and throwing them outside of the troublesome spot, there still sometimes is too much "Manual fidgeting" involved as you cant set up a full production chain, nor can you task pals on certain things (easily at least). This makes things a little annoying when you want to say...produce ammunition for your guns as that's a multi tier production line which is where things get a bit more tedious like in most other Open World Survivalcraft games.

Craftopia did have similar creature collecting mechanics with "Monster Prisms" though you instead caught Unity asset store animals that you could ride, fight alongside, and throw em in certain machines to work (which would eventually kill them) and to be frank, you were encouraged to be FAR more cruel and careless with them because of the fact that they were designed to be killed for you to get use out of them (with the exception of transport and combat). Here there's hand crafted assets (No I don't think the pals are stolen, fly too close to the sun for a couple of them though) that has an entire mechanic dedicated to their care, Sanity which makes Pals less disposable as low sanity doesn't kill a pal but instead stresses them and if not taken care of, develop injuries or mental disorders that you'll have to treat. You can work them to the bone or you can be ethical about it. The choice is ultimately yours.

You do lose out on what most gamers would call RPG mechanics (Magic and Mana is gone as well as several weapon types and the entire skill tree), Vehicles, and as mentioned before some automation options (as awkward as it was to set up a whole factory, you could set up a full production chain to  anything if you had the appropriate inputs).

Whats gained however is focus, The experience is less ADD and frustrating to navigate. Menus are cleaner and easier to navigate than Craftopia ever was, and the tutorial is fantastic for getting you into the core game loop. This means going out and hunting pals and exploring is more rewarded by expanding options in your base and your base allows you to venture deeper into the world (and I still love Pocketpair's Environment art team). All of those mechanics are handled by your pals and how you manage them or by simple tech and stat progression. Everything is focused around pals, the aforementioned base building, how you approach combat (Using pals to flank a target so you can get a back-strike for a catch, using the pillars in the boss room to have them flank your target, Flying on a Vanwyrm to snipe foes from the sky, all great stuff!) traversal, and crafting all is focused on you and your interactions with Pals and its all wonderful.

Now I said this was a weaker multiplayer experience. I believe this is due to how bases are managed and progress. In Craftopia, you could build pretty much anywhere and were encouraged to find ore nodes and build extractors on them. Palworld requires you to slap down a palbox (which is limited) and then build within a circle, as you level up, you can stuff more pals and eventually place more palboxes in the overworld. If you guild up you share base progression more or less which means the leveling scale kind of breaks a little as your tech is progressing independently but your base levels up together. It feels awkward and with the new limitations I found myself sticking to my own base and my wife to hers once we unlocked the tech for a new base, nevermind we didn't share boxes. I think this game is better played solo and taken at your own pace so you can get around the awkward multiplayer progression.

In the end Palworld is an improvement. Its not perfect and craftopia can scratch a specific itch still, but its well worth the purchase if you are into the memes or the genre.
literally adult pokemon blended into ark. as a massive fan of both games, I highly approve of and appreciate this game. just keep in mind, this is DEFINITELY NOT a kids game.

It's like Pokemon, but with unique mechanics relative to the Pokemon-catching aspect and a building/crafting system. I love first-person building/crafting games and I liked the first-person open world adventures in the modern Pokemon games, so this definitely meets my criteria for a good Creature Collection game.

My only alterations to this approval is that the AI needs a bit more work with the Pals at your base for reacting to conditions due to "stressful work environments" (normal work mode specifically). The AI doesn't seem to respond well to "normal" working conditions and the Pals even having the positive stat bonuses to 'Work Speed' and 'Sanity' still have an easy trigger to working longer than 10 - 15 minutes and receive a negative status such as "upset/tired and not willing to work," "stressed out due to stressful work conditions." I'm not sure if it may be misunderstanding something involved with the AI coding, but I feel that the working conditions (if set to 'Normal' working conditions) would have a safe impact on the statuses when the Pals are working for about 20 - 30 minutes at the very most and then activate a 'break' sequence where they could roam around or use a Hot Tub to refresh their Sanity. Maybe an "Exhausted" status would work for activating a 'Go to Hot Tub' sequence to refresh the Sanity better than the "taking a break" status because when your Pal would take a break, it normally defaults to a 'Wandering' trigger event and the Sanity doesn't go up very much.
Another issue I've noticed is the Wandering aspect seems a bit janky since they like to roam to the outside of the base and get stuck in tight spaces and not respond to interactive objects such as stone/coal/sulfur/ore piles and trees. But I'm sure the issue has already been reported and is being updated as I type this out, so it is just for bringing the issue to attention.

Aside from the above mentioned, this is in general a great game and I could DEFINITELY see this being improving A LOT in the future and maybe even introduce breed-able color varieties of the available Pals that you catch and put into the Breeding Farm.

I am in the discord and they have talked about fixing a lot of these issues, so lets hope that happens. 
Besides that I'd highly recommend this game, it's a sh*t ton of fun with buddies and a great time killer after work.

I grew up with PokÃ©mon starting from Red/Blue and the last game I finished was Gold/Silver. However, I tried getting back to that franchise with Sapphire and Shield, but I really can't stand the turn based battles. I no longer have the same imagination I had when I was a kid.

I really feel that Palworld is the game that PokÃ©mon should have been, but they refuse to innovate because of overpaid legacy staff and inability to transition from 2D to 3D. I love the personality of each pal from Chillet flapping its ears to Depresso looking at you menacingly while mining rocks and attempts to drown itself while on the bathtub. I like the real time battles where you don't have to respect the enemy's time and you are just as involved in the battles as your summoned creatures with guns, and your pals can help you run your base and have an automated factory to craft you more weapons and Pal spheres to "catch 'em all", then breed, then condense it to a perfect Pal. You also have an option to have more than 1 Pal active in battles with a bracelet for select Pals, like Daedream and Dazzi.

Though its buggy and there are times that you would fall into the world map, I think they are less buggy than what Game Freak had produced for the last 10 years. I never bought a Switch as current PokÃ©mon is a disappointment and I have lost all hope that it will even try to modernize, and the gameplay loop of Palworld is so satisfying and I hope they would further expand the game.

This is amazing, though I don't see why everyone is calling it Pokemon with guns - there is some very close similarities in a few places, but I don't recall a Pokemon game where you gather a bunch of building resources in an open world for varied base facilities, put your Pokemon to work on using said things to craft and build, or flat-out eat your mons. Your player character is actually capable of doing things in battle, too, and you aren't FORCED to carry any Pals with you - you can go out alone and defend yourself with your own weapons. (Though mounts make traveling a LOT easier, but what I mean is that it doesn't feel like my player character is useless without a Pal.) There's hunger stats to keep up, and Pals have sanity you need to watch. Each Pal I've found has felt unique in what they can do; some are better for fighting, some are better for tasks at the base. Some of those base-taskers are well rounded and able to handle a variety, while others are specialized, but also better at what they do. Other Pals have extra-special abilities, like regenerating your health, or being a sonar for things of interest. The fighters have different styles, especially mounts, so it's really helpful to have a mount with a style that matches your own... unlike what I have now with the fastest land traveler I could get yet, who only kills what I want to catch, and I swear is deliberately slow at attacking only when we REALLY need to dodge an attack, and is INSANELY lucky that I'm not willing to permanently "retire" any Pal that's actually done something useful-
*Ahem*
Of course, it IS early access, so there are some glitches, and things that feel like they could use some modification. (Like how you have to individually chase, hope you can pick up, then toss a Pal at a task, then hope they see the task you're telling them to do. Or, and it may just be the way I build my bases, but the walls are more of a suggestion, as my Pals often clip outside and get stuck, then I have to re-put them in the base before they starve. I've also had multiple occasions of Pals and NPC's clipping into walls. There's also the fact that Pals don't eat until they're full before returning to tasks, they eat until they're above their hunger threshold... so I have some Pals that spend all their time walking back to the food box, eating a bit, starting towards their task, then getting hungry before doing anything and going back for more.) There is also, admittedly, a solid amount of EXP grinding, though this can be made a bit easier by changing the world settings.
(And, small spoiler alert but important to know,[spoiler] you stop at level 50, and while you can reset your stat distribution, it's a fairly tedious recipe to complete. [/spoiler]Watch what you spend your Level points on!)

In the end, though, this really is a great game. The map is filled with things to do and places to go. It feels alive by actively spawning NPC's that react to more than just the player. The Pals, while some designs are[i] notably [/i] similar to some existing Pokemon, have great designs. Even the variants are interesting, since the color change makes them stand out from the original.

And, because it feels like a good summary of my luck in this game, a (spoilers) story that I know I won't forget.
[spoiler] While I avoided looking things up unless I was super stuck, I did happen to see you could catch and keep humans at the base, including merchants - most notably, to me, the Black Marketeer, who sells rare Pals. I couldn't help it and decided I'd try to bring one back to my base, but he completely destroyed me multiple times. I spent hours getting ready for a round 2, gathering resources to craft a bunch of the best Spheres and piling up on EXP. With 45 Legendary Spheres, I went for a rematch. (Not counting the one my trigger-happy horse killed-) I somehow survived, I threw my first Sphere... and hit the 14% chance first try. It couldn't have been a more anti-climactic way for my grand quest to end. 100 out of 10, couldn't have asked for a better result. Now he's the most eager one in the base to help craft things, always either the first or second to get to it. [/spoiler]

Short version: In my 150-hour dive into Palworld, I've found it to be a game that addresses PokÃ©mon's limitations in representing a dynamic environment. It offers a living sandbox experience, akin to a blend of PokÃ©mon and Animal Crossing, with improved multiplayer functionality. As a former Destiny 2 player, I appreciate its slight shooter elements. While the game has glitches, they're manageable and expected in early access. The bases foster shared goals, but glitches affect tasks allocation and pathfinding. Food management in bases is also inefficient. Despite these issues, Palworld's innovative gameplay makes it worth playing, promising even more as it develops further.

Long version:

The main thing that this game implements is Pokemon's weakness, or inability to fully represent the environment we have come to expect from the anime: It is a living, breathing sandbox. This is also the perfect game if you liked Pokemon and/or Animal Crossing, but felt the ability to play and do things with friends was lackluster, or more trouble than it was worth. It even scratches the shooter itch JUST enough for me, coming from Destiny 2. I don't typically do reviews but wow, this deserves it. There are some glitches in the game that are irritating to some degree and it's a real shame, occasionally. However, ALL of them have work-arounds or are not required to progress, and this is early access. Given the massive influx of players and the funding they've gotten from sales, I have no doubt that they now have the means to correct these issues.

THE GOOD:

The bases in the game give everyone shared interests and goals, and the server method allows everybody to play together at once. No connecting, searching, exchanging friend codes, etc. You give someone your server code 1 time, they join you, and that's it. You just log in and there are your pals--pun intended. Time to go do stuff. Anybody can drop in or out at any time. For an early access title this is about as good as it gets. You build a base, establish a method of consistently obtaining food, building pal spheres (balls), and get out into the wilderness. Whereas Pokemon had you doing turn-based battles for the majority of the time, Palworld is real-time combat. They have added an element of skill to the game where you'll need to move your character and help fight to capture the Pals in the open environment. In Pokemon, you didn't necessarily need skill or any element of coordination to capture new ones, as combat was largely turn-based. Everything feels so much more alive this way; it's surreal and more satisfying on each capture. You don't just "use fly" as fast-travel: you can actually fly, as high as you're able (which levels up in time, if you so choose that skill tree) and discover. You don't just "surf" to cross a stream; you actually explore and find new things when you find the appropriate Pal to take you. Can't see at night? Use a fire Pal to light the way. Can't climb that cliff yet? Increase your stamina. Find a Pal who jumps higher. Find one that flies more efficiently. The practical application of the Pals you find is what makes this game shine brightest.

THE BAD:

The glitches... oh man, the glitches. I'll start with base life:

When you set up your base, everybody has a job. As with real life, not everybody likes their job. For example, 1 Pal named Anubis is extremely fast at the handiwork skill, used to make tons of items such as Pal Spheres. He can create them faster than you can, even after upgrading that skill tree 15 times. The problem? You can assign 3 of these fellas to your base and queue up some spheres to be made, but find all 3 of your Pals mining rock instead of helping you with your task. At the moment the game lacks a proper way to assign pals to any given task, especially the ones that have multiple skills. It would be nice to find some interface where I can always set Anubis to prioritize completing Handiwork tasks before going back to mining stone, for example. This would allow us to customize their behavior in a productive way, and make these Pals (that can potentially work so much faster than us) actually apply themselves.

At best, you can try to go run up to them, physically pick them up and bring them back to a certain work station, and HOPE that they don't run off when you put them down right in front of the place you intended them to be. Many times, even if you're facing a station and the prompt to "assign to X" shows up, they'll still hit the ground running, back to what they were doing before. Simultaneously, you get a prompt that they're "unable to work on Y," as you sit there going, "I WANTED YOU TO X, NOT Y!" This process wouldn't be great even if it was perfected--I think we'd be much better off with some user interface where we can click and drag any given Pal to designate tasks, perhaps on an overhead map of the base that's similar to the world map.

Rather than sit and repeat this chase-and-drop process, I've opted to keep an Anubis in my party and throw him out whenever I want him to focus 100% on a certain task. Unfortunately this limits you, as you can only have 1 Pal from your team out at a time. This 1 Pal is the ONLY Pal who stays 100% on-task with what you tell them to do, and has no issues being assigned by throwing him at a particular work station. Similar coding should be applied to base pals, but I have hope for the future. If this functionality is improved, we could all be farming things exponentially faster than what is currently possible, making base life much more fun. I estimate that end-game pals used in your base are only functioning at about 10-15% of the efficiency that they could be, if they were properly coded.

That leads me to my 2nd biggest problem: PATHING. For those who don't know what this means, the Pals in your base will get stuck. They will get stuck a lot. You will leave, come back, and find all 10-15 Pals in a mosh pit, unable to move and starving. If you employ bigger Pals in your base, there will be even more issues with their movement in tight environments. You'll have to take them all out of the base, put them back in the box, and re-assign them to the base. Again, this simple work-around takes 10 seconds to do, but it gets aggravating over time. When your 3 Anubis Pals didn't create any stone while you were gone because they got stuck for all 3 hours that you were out exploring dungeons, you come back pretty disappointed.

Similarly, if you have 5 Pals who can take care of 5 different tasks at once, you would expect to kill 5 birds with one stone. Unfortunately, as of the game's current state, if you queue up 5 items to be made, you'll be lucky to see 1 of your 5 Pals actively running over to work on those tasks. You typically have to micro-manage, sending your party Pal to complete things and move through the stations 1 at a time, personally.

FOOD: Food is problematic in the base setting because even if you establish a good way to get a supply for your pals to enjoy, they frequently don't eat until they're full. You'll find Anubis leaving his task to go eat when his stomach drops to 49% full. He'll stop, run across the base to your berry supply pit, eat 1 berry, run all the way back and start working again, 51% full. 15 seconds later you'll catch him stopping his work again to go eat 1 more berry. It's frustrating that they don't eat until they're full outright, because this repeated process really undermines the speed and efficiency that you're meant to achieve by employing the correct Pals in your base. As I mentioned there are ways to work around everything, such as producing higher quality food that brings you well above 50% with one bite, but one shouldn't have to plan for that.

Summary: Excellent game albeit with many, many frustrating glitches. It speaks to how much fun it is, however, that it is still worth playing in spite of all these problems. It is a breath of fresh air to what Pokemon should have been.

I initially bought this game because I saw my bestie playing it, but I've since become addicted. It's like P*kÃ©mon in some ways, yet different in others. The designs of the Pals are likable, and I appreciate that a lot of them can be used as mounts or be made to accompany you outside their Palballs. 

Unlike P*kemon, however, it is more violent, with the ability to kill pals and humans, and you do get food / material items from slain foes. I am cool with that, but someone looking for something more "monster friendly" may prefer something a little less violent. 

I also personally really enjoy the crafting and base designing aspects a lot more than I thought I would, and I've spent copious amounts of time on mine. I just wish there were some easier ways to place items without them being crooked, like offering both a direct placement mode and an overhead grid placement option. But I'm unsure how feasible that would be since I'm not a game designer myself.

Overall, I would recommend this game, and I think it's worth the current price of around $30 despite being in early access. I do think some big improvements with glitches will need to be made if they plan to charge more for the full release, though.

Note: I have only played co-op on my own and friend's servers, so I have no experience with the official ones and the issues others have spoken up about.

This game is just amazing! I currently have 131 unique pals and love the game so far!

However, some things I would love to see in the full release are:
- Sorting your inventory automatically into all chests within your base that hold any of that item (aka quick stash all stackables)
- Improve Pal AI (especially inside the base)
- Add a "catch bonus completed amount" tracker next to the encounter amount tracker and owned amount tracker in the Paldeck
- Ability to initiate fast travel from anywhere (maybe unlocked through a key item from a late game ancient technology?)
- Way more space in the Pal Box. It feels like you constantly have to condense Pals with the Pal Condenser or sell them. If you want to get multiple Pals to 4 stars almost all your space has to be reserved for that alone.
- Possiblity to move and rotate objects within your base (instead of destroying and rebuilding)
- Ability to repair every structure in your base from a menu instead of with repair sets. A lot of spaces in more advanced buildings are absolutely unreachable for Pals. Additionally, the player is not allowed to fix floors or walls, only objects like the workbench, but no "building structures". When you have any damaged unreachable structure in your base and at least 1 repair kit in any storage all pals with a Handiwork trait will bug out and try to fix it. When they are unable they will drop the repair kit on the ground, effectively waisting it. Until the last repair kit is pulled out of a chest for long enough and despawns all Handiwork pals will just stutter on the spot. Giving us an option from either the Pal Box or somewhere else to repair everything in the whole base (it would still cost the same ressources of course) would hugely help fixing all the walls players accidently shoot with their Assault Rifle when they actually want to grapple to that spot.
- PVP
- Decoupling of worlds and characters. It would be cool to just start on a new world with an existing character or join with a new character into your existing world. Multiplayer servers should have an option to allow or decline characters that played outside of the server world. This would enable way easier PVP.
