Honestly the early to mid game is fun, fairly balanced, and the glitches... you can *kind of* gloss over, you think.

But then like 30-40 hours in, you're in midgame and you need your bases to work, but they're not that functional because Pals are broken a.f. You are however still enamored with the Wixen stoking your ovens, and the Verdash picking your crops. You have some work-arounds that are OK, and you're still having fun probably...

And then the game just becomes more unstable and unplayable, it becomes a test of wills. How badly do you want to get to late game VS how much completely & utterly broken the base mechanics, Pal AI, supply chains, and Palbox UX/UI (or lack thereof) is. If you're like me you'll endure for a bit. . . but eventually it will just crush your will to play the game because ITS NOT FUN ANYMORE.

There's so many easy things the devs could do to at least control for and mitigate the brokeness in mid to late game, but those things just aren't there.

You can't get a refund at this point. You just quit. Don't play this game in its current state if the above jank will piss you off.

(P.S. I have almost so many hours because I started 3 separate times before ending up hosting my own server, and then doing my best to facilitate the game for my group of friends' enjoyment, and took a major detour through breeding and trying to get bases humming along... ultimately I'm tired of devs releasing broken games, even in EA, that your don't realize are broken until you're 30 or 40 hours in. It's one thing to be feature incomplete or content incomplete, it's another thing to be a growing ball of glitchfest)

Plays a lot like ark but there's no taming time which is nice, runs fairly smooth majority of the time, when you use Daedream's Necklace the lil wanna be cosmog will block you from building as it will stand right in front of you blocking you from putting whatever it may be down but you can literally just put his ass back in the PCso it's not that big a deal but it is very annoying. combat is decent, you can use a spear or a bow/crossbow for the first 20 levels and then the weapons slowly get better eventually leading to more modern guns. Even playing solo the game isn't so hard that it's a grind just to go out and gather supplies or materials but it's still hard enough that you need to be an appropriate level to get along, the 'pals' have a level sync so if you think you can cheese the game from day 1 and get a really high level 'pal' right of the bat than you are mistaken, it's level will drop down to be the same level as you or 1 level higher. There's no guide for putting together a house and it can be hella touchy when placing certain things, when you build up to have a two-story house and it'll hit you with 'not enough support' but there are no pillars to add support  in the game and the only way to build something that's structurally sound is you have to just build a box on top of a box so be careful when picking an area for your base, try find the most open and flat area and that'll make it easier to go hard on building otherwise just build a big f*** you fence on the perimeter of your base and leave it open-air style.

I have played for 30hrs, with nothing to show for it. If you join a dedicated server it's ridiculously laggy. I bought a personal server from Shockbyte, and it completely wiped ALL progress- TWICE!! 30hrs WASTED. They have 50,000 inquiries- yes, 50,000 for the same issue of wiping all progress. I cannot believe they released this game without fleshing everything out. It's a shame because it is super fun, amazing concept and really awesome gameplay- when it works. They SERIOUSLY need to fix these issues, or this will be a dead game. Very disappointed, wasted so much time.

*UPDATE*
They have fixed some of these issues, they still need to make dedicated servers. But honestly this game is suuuper addicting! Most fun I've had in a while- bugs and all. Hopefully more of these issues will be addressed, but I played 71 more hours after my initial review, its just so good.

Though some designs aren't as unique as one might hope, there's also a lot of unique designs. Considering the devs learned unreal engine from the ground up and made this game with a small team, Gamefreak should really learn from them. Pokemon fans (me included) have asked for a polished, good looking, pokemon game that isn't a turn based system adventure. I've definitely found my needs for this in Palworld.

Achievements are also kinda straight forward to get, and that should not be seen as a bad thing. I hope to see more achievements in the future, and am looking forward to new content!

THE POKEMON GUN WE ALL NEEDED. But all jokes aside, this game is great. It may have some unoriginal designs but the gameplay and graphics are great. The designs that are original look sick and the Pal gears make team building fun, having you consider the stats of your Pal and the partner ability too to make a good team to fight bosses with. Even Pals that can be rode can have a secondary effect to aid in battle. There's a ton of different Pals with Pal gears that you can craft to make different things happen, such as allowing the Pal to appear alongside you without needing to be sent out to shoot the enemies, or to activate a temporary buff that can boost a certain stat or adds a unique effect such as life drain to your weapon. The map is beautiful and ginormous. There's a ton of decorations you can build for your base. And lastly, the combat is fun and you can approach a boss in many ways, such as, sneaking up on it, charging head on or shooting it from far away. This game is great and has many positive reviews for a reason.

The core game play loop of this game is phenomenal. There's tons to explore and the chance of finding a new pal that will add usefulness to your base only adds the the excellent exploration.  The gliders and climb anywhere mechanics are very freeing. Automating and optimizing your base is also tons of fun, and feeds right back into exploration and catching new pals. This game truly emphasizes freedom of play, going so far as to allow you to capture human NPCs, with only a single line of "hey, this is considered immoral in this world," as a barrier. Also, Guns.

This game is better than many AAA releases in recent years, and its still early access. I'm certainly looking forward to some things though. It took me a while to realize you can still edit world settings from the title page even after the world has been created. I'm of the belief that you can always make improvements to UI.
The raid mechanics have caused me some bugs, and I could see some players not finding it compelling, luckily it can be turned off in world settings. As they sit though, the raids have potential but are a bit lacking in depth based on current AI behavior. 
The story also currently lacks depth. The idea that multiple factions are attempting to control the land and its resources makes sense, and leads to boss battles and other facets of good game design. Some cutscenes and voice acting would go a very long way in fleshing out the story of the game.

Critical points: Some of the pals are unimaginative to the point of clearly being AI designed. 
The armor design. It's bad.
I dislike suggestions that create excessive work for the devs, but some customization options for armor and clothing feel mandatory for a game that offers so much freedom in so many other places. Hunting a rare pal for materials to add a buff to your helmet? Missed opportunity.
Technology progression. This is a personal gripe, but I found the jump from tables to rusty conveyor belts a little jarring. Giving lifmunk a submachine gun before I could craft a crossbow? Not great for immersion.

This is at least 70% a survival/building/management game and then MAYBE 30% Pokemon-like kind of game. I enjoyed the sh*t out of it, put some serious hours in a very short amount of time and I pretty much made everything there is to do. If I never play it again, I've already got the time/enjoyment return out of my money.

That's probably not how the story ends though, depending on how devs will follow-up with Palworld's success. Over time, I'm hoping for several new areas (I hope we eventually reach the sky, not unlike TotK) and at least double the amount of Pals to catch/breed. Some more Tower Bosses would be nice, again at least double the current amout. 
Random/scheduled events around the map would go a long way, some more Alphas, hopefully some sort of Raid events/areas.
I'm definitely NOT looking forward for PvP, although I also don't grudge them for doing so. If people want it, just do it. But I hope that the majority of content we see from now on is PvE. I'll also add that I've joined some acquaintances of mine in a public server and it was utter shit. No joke, it's a completely different, shittier experience. Just stick to either solo play or host the game yourself (or have a friend do so). Just keep in mind people can only join when/while the host is Online.

I have a lot more expectations for the game, but I don't want to necessarily write them all down. I really hope this game succeeds as it has tremendous potential.

I wanted to love this but it's missing the most important part of a modern Pokemon title. 

The frame rate needs to be much much choppier. Where are the massive subterranean oceans I'm forced to render!? 

Also some of the monsters look stylistically similar to early-gen mons, so this is a direct attack on my childhood memories and I'm calling the police. Here is the foolproof method to prove how they are criminals with TWO WORDS! 

Please use the following mathematical formula;

[b]Element/Color/Shape + Animal  = Copyright infringement[/b] 

Fire + Fox = Vulpix. Only Nintendo owns the idea of a Firefox. How can people not see this!?

Ball + Sheep = Woloo. They have the same number of legs! Wake up sheeple!

Water + Penguin = Piplup. Penguins have nothing to do with water/ice wtf?!

/sarcasm

If you're looking through the negative reviews to see whats wrong, these are what I would consider the actual problems. 

Pals get stuck in base constantly. There are quite a few unique ways for them to get stuck. You can pick them up, but there seems to be a visual desync that can make that difficult, so its usually just best to put them back in the box for a second and redeploy them.

Building is objectively bad for a survival game. Things don't snap like they should and walls are still somehow only a suggestion for Pals, despite already receiving a 'fix'. 

Melee combat feels bad, but ranged seems like more of the focus of the game.

Other than that the gameplay loop/exploration is amazing for the price. There is no 'endgame' but this makes sense considering EA status. The ONLY real worry I have is that this Dev doesn't seem to stick with their EA titles. They've also stated that they have almost no experience with this engine, so expect fixes to be slow. That said, it seems like they've used all of their experience to make this and it's obviously much more promising than their other games. I bet they stick with this one, I just hope it doesn't say Jankworld for months and months.

It's easy to see why Palworld was a big success at launch - the game is a great mix of genres, deeper than originally seems, and well-designed to be immersive and draw the player in to consistently want more. The game is a bit buggy and laggy which is expected for early release, but the major issue why I would not recommend the game is that the official game servers are plagued by hackers who destroy the gaming experience. Hackers will steal your pals and items and destroy your base, which is not allowed through normal gameplay. I've lost countless hours across two different playthroughs due to hackers and have now lost all progress that I've made in the game. 

It's a shame that the developers do no respond to issues that were submitted to address the lost progress and/or hacker situation.

The first 40 hours or so were pretty fun. 50 hours + it just becomes tedious and feels like a chore. There was a lot of potential for the game to be not just good, but great. It has been a month and nothing of significance has been done to make the game more playable or enjoyable. Quality of life improvements are crucial and the longer they take to implement anything or have a concise road map for future content, the faster this game is going to drop like a dump into the toilet. A lot of the mess of this game has been excused by the audience but the devs have done little to nothing to fix the basic game mechanic such as path finding/worker assignments (though they seem to imply they have). It is disappointing but there are plenty of other indie games worth playing (yes, even early access) that the devs and community actually care about. To summarize the game in two words. WASTED POTENTIAL

"Palworld" is an innovative blend of survival, sandbox, and creature-collecting gameplay. The game's charming art style and vast open world provide a captivating backdrop for players to explore and build their own unique habitats. With a wide variety of adorable creatures to befriend and utilize in various tasks, from farming to combat, "Palworld" offers a fresh take on the genre. However, some may find the gameplay loop repetitive over time. Overall, "Palworld" is a fun and engaging experience for fans of sandbox games and creature collecting.

Frankly, the game is really good and feels very refreshing.
The graphisms, the gameplay and the content are really good for an early access.

So why is this a negative review? 2 words: PROGRESS LOST

The game is very buggy (nothing strange, it is an EA after all) and crashes without any reason sometimes. It would not be a big deal if said crashes weren't the cause of many deleted / corrupted save files.
To give you an idea of the state of the game, way too many mods get shared across steam discussions, Reddits, Discord, etc... just to give you the opportunity to restore your save files from backups and more often that it should be, it just doesn't work and you find yourself restarting all over again.

It happened to me 3 times:
- Once on a coop server (5h play time lost)
- Once on a dedicated online server (70h+ play time lost)
- Once on a solo game (10h play time lost)

So far, it is one of the worst (if not the worst) Early Access I played in my entire life.

I CANNOT recommend this game in this current state. I know the devs know about these problems and are trying to fix it as soon as possible, but this shouldn't be a thing in a first place.
Also, I fear these fixes delay way too much the addition of content in the game.

I'm willing to change my review in a near future if they manage to deploy some fixes quickly, but as the time being, it is a big NO for me.
Me trying to convince the poisoned, on fire, dying pal it is in it's best interest to stay in the sphere and work for my labor camp.

Quick Edit- Did anyone else lose some of their Palworld Playtime? I went from 137 hours total to 56 hours?!

 Palworld is... A beautiful mess. I'm sure you've heard many content creators surrounding Palworld say that already- as it's hard to miss the game- given how popular it has become. However- after 137 hours- within the span of a week- I can safely say that this game is extremely fun! It's still incredibly buggy and has its flaws, but the bugs weren't game breaking in my opinion. It was mostly just cases of Pals freezing randomly or the *slight* wall phasing- thankfully I've yet to phase through the ground, so that's a plus!
 The overall gameplay is enjoyable, however can feel pretty grindy at times, which to some people is great! Other times it can feel relaxing, strolling through forests or along the sandy shores, watching pals roam as they please. And then there's the other times where you'll start to rage when Pal #69 comes in hordes and destroys your base during a raid :).
 The pals themselves are excellently done. They are very well animated, so it feels like each pal has their personality. Just pay attention to the way a Pengullet waddles around with it's flippers moving about, or when it carries items on it's head! The pals look like they were made with love, which really gives them personality, and almost makes me feel bad for them when I force them to mine a bunch of stone, ore and wood for me!
 The humans on the other hand- almost feel like they have no personality. They wander aimlessly. The NPCs at cities should have more dialog. They say someone should defeat the boss, you defeat the boss, come back. say one new thing, and then someone should defeat the boss. 
 Overall- the gameplay mechanics are pretty great when combined into this game- The ARK-like technology points and choosing what to spend your points on in advancements is a really neat thing when combined with the Pokemon-like gameplay. The feeling of needing to catch all the pals continues the grind for resources. In turn it causes you to explore more of the map because you're eventually forced to search for coal to make refined ingots. Sulfur to make ammo and weapons. And eventually quarts for circuit boards- All of these things encourage the player to explore more of the map as they level up and progress. As you progress you also have to change and adapt your play style as you unlock new things- you unlock new weapons, new pal partner abilities, new areas of the map, different mounts. All while you still have to grind materials... so its easy to get sucked into it! 

 I genuinely recommend this game, however if you don't like buggy games, wait a little while until the game is out of early access, or at least until they patch a lot of bugs.
 But that's all from me- it's back to the grind for me! :D

I got lost in the hours of rewarding gameplay, finding new creatures, finding ways to farm resources, finding ways to cheese bosses. At some point, that rewarding factor comes to a steep halt if you no-life the game. The world is big and explorable but after a while, it feels pretty quiet and lifeless. You can adjust population density to fix some of that though. 

The game allows you to change do many aspects of gameplay in your world, allowing you to curate your own experience. After about 40 hours of gameplay, I made my own world and virtually skipped a lot of the grinding. 

There are a lot of aspects of the game obviously borrowed from Pokemon, but the game has a lot of it's own unique features. Im a bit divided on the gameplay. There's a million ways to go about combat really. Unless you're using a mounted Pal, you don't command their attacks, they act on their own. Meanwhile, you can use guns, arrows, spears, and grenades to combat enemy Pals. Some pals have support skills you can command and be healed, other pals, you can turn into weapons (example: one pal can turn into a flame thrower). My favorite way to approach combat is to constantly throw and return my creatures according to the situation. I tend to recall my pals before an attack lands on them, and resummon them elsewhere to counter the enemy. 

Game runs smooth on the steam deck but unfortunately will inevitably crash after enough exploration. My PC sounds like an airplane turbine when I fly too high. Game needs to be optimized as it consumes a lot of video memory. 

Overall the game is a blast. I unfortunately hit a wall a hundred hours in, but when you have friends playing with you, it's a whole new experience. I hope to see the player capacity increase. I hope to see cloud stored worlds so my friends can play in mine even when I'm not around. I hope to see more pals. I hope to see procedurally generatable worlds. I hope to see more weapons. I hope to see much much better item customization. I hope to see migratsble characters, items, and storage. Starting from scratch is fun, but sometimes, you want to bring some creatures with you. 

Good luck, Pocketpair.

Spoiler Alert: This is a must play, for sure.
It is a pitty that palworld firstly had been received with strong critiscism of plagiarism which is really unfair to the amazing work this small studio achieved to deliver. After dozens of hours in this game you actually realize how much personality it has, rather than being just a copy of other titles. In fact, it has a lot of inspiration on successful franchises, however, it just pick the most fun aspects of those games also adding its own personality. I love how the "pet system" works, specially due to the fact that every single monster has its own personality (literally speaking) , so even catching a same kind of creature it may have different personality traits among all the other specie friends.

It is important to take note that it is a work in progress, however, it shows a lot of pottencial for the years to come.

The game plays like "a certain game" (that people don't want to mention) + minecraft. Catch pals, gather resources, build bases, level up, explore.

Game is still in early access as I write this so there are still some minor bugs and problems, but no real game-breaking problems. I got to max level in one world, then started a new world and got about half-way through before I stopped.

I don't know if they have plans for plot, but that seems like the only real thing they're missing. Anything else they could add would just be additional content on top of what's there.

It could do with functionality improvements, such as better assigning Pals to things (maybe a contextual menu of some sort or if we zoom in using right click, it's definitely the one thing we're zoomed on); roles assignement / management in guilds; path finding not yet on point; but all in all good fun. took about 100 hours on a normal server to reach max level.

Think Poke'mon meets Monster Hunter meets Phantasy Star meets World of Warcraft. You hunt and catch "Pals" and use them in combat against other Pals. They also help you build and manage a base where you progress in technology, buildings, armor, and weaponry. You start primitive with bows and spears and work your way up to polymer, guns. The grind at base is pretty real, be prepared for that. lots of time spent turning ore into ingots and cooking food for you and your Pals. It's also quite addicting. I bought this game on 2-19 and am writing this review on 2-22. The 60.8 hours I have happened in 4 days. I'm Lv 23 and Lv goes to 50 so there's easily 100 hrs of game play here. This game is basically Poke'mon with guns and open world adventuring. Highly recommended. 9.5 of 10. I took off half a point cause if you die you drop all your gear where you died and have to try to go get it all back with nothing. I hate it when games do that.

I convinced my husband to join me in this game and we then proceeded to get sucked into almost a 12 hour straight binge of playing.  We lured in a friend and that was another hours long binge with Discord voice chat.  This game is very fun to play with a partner or friends without feeling frustrated or completely lost. I'm usually not an FPS kinda girl but Palworld really made combat fun instead of making me relive some PTSD from badly coded games of the past.

Exploration feels rewarding instead of punishing or restrictive. Dying in a fight just feels like a good natured arm punch from a friend vs an acid laced whip across the eyes everytime you blink.  The world is gorgeous, discovery is fun and the amount of times we've chimed "Oooh, egg!" while roaming was hilarious.  Warning though, my fellow ADHDers should....put a timer on or something.

If there's anything I hope is that the finished game will flesh out the base building, targeting and some of the pathing AIs.  Especially that last one because if I have to save a dumb water dragon from the roof one more time....

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This game is really fun but there are a number of issues that are pretty game breaking. For instance in your base pals have no idea how to get to anything ever for any reason. They prioritize things that make no sense and will constantly get sick and produce little to no resources. There is no way you the player can influence and control any of this. You can not prioritize what they work on even assigning them to a task using the built in mechanic doesn't work. Which makes one half of the game base management basically a crap shoot of build and rebuild with no information hoping it suddenly works. The rest of the game is amazing raiding dungeons, catching pals using crazy weapons and armor even using pals as weapons. Those fun parts I think outweigh the bad parts but man does the base mechanics quickly make playing just not much fun because you can't leave to do the good parts without losing substantial resources in curing depression and other issues.

I've had way too much fun with this game! Is it unfinished? Absolutely! Is it buggy as all get-out? Incredibly! Is it fun? YOU HAVE NO IDEA!

Catching monsters, catching humans, crafting, whackin' trees, scrounging for materials, getting bodied over and over again... and the best part is that you can custom tailor your worlds! I play single-player, and after getting frustrated with the grind (and the multitude of deaths), I started tinkering with the world. The game itself lets you do that. No need for mods or cheats - just the game itself. I wish more games would allow us to do that! Not everyone has the time or drive to painstakingly lob 1,0000 spheres to catch a Pal, not everyone wants to grind and grind and grind to see progress. Ain't nobody got time for that, and the game doesn't punish you for it - it lets you do (nearly) whatever you want!

I can't wait for updates! More NPCs! More animations! More things to do, things to see - things to capture. 

I don't normally buy early-access games, but I've already gotten more than my money's worth.

The sheer amount of content available for the price is amazing, 29 hours in and I haven't even explored half of what the world has to offer or even unlocked most of what is available, and I'm hooked.

The gameplay is snappy and quick, the pal moves and weapons you use also feel strangely realistic or punchy, for lack of a better word, which is a plus. 

The mix of so many gameplay elements like base building with more to it than just building, monster catching, having the pals helping out in everything you do, from the variety of weapons and resources, it all works surprisingly well put together.

The pals all have such unique animations, sound and overall designs, not only can you have pals working at your base and interacting with so many things at once, the ones you bring along in your party can do so much to help you adventuring, being mounts for faster travel, flying, gliding or just having them around you is awesome. 

The base building is so rewarding, the way pals help out in their unique ways, to needing specific resources, I just wish the base construction radious was a bit longer or at least allowed you to invest in making it wider, even if it cost large amounts of resources. 

Dungeons and caves are a pretty boring and repetitive after the first one, hopefully that changes in the future.

Sure it has a few bugs and needs some more work to polish things out, but performance looks pretty great considering the amount of stuff happening on a busy game, it is probably one of the best early access games I ever bought, everything feels fun and rewarding, especially with a coop partner, and even by yourself, also no microtransactions, just the full package, I love it.

Absolute bang for buck of a game, I was never much of a fan of survival games, but this one peaked my interest and it's worth every cent, early access after playing Palworld has a whole new meaning personally.

This game has revitalized the monster taming/hunting genre big time. Having a low budget PC I do experience lag, especially in dungeons where it seems to be common place for every player in general. The lag and bugs hasnât ruined my experience to the point of this being unplayable-its still very addicting with a lot to do despite being early access. Palworld takes inspiration from several games; movement+controls from the Soulsbourne universe, monster catching/battling/gyms/breeding from PokÃ©mon, building/gathering/farming from games like Minecraft and Stardew Valley. Some can also see this as Fortnite with monsters within its simplistic aesthetics and building/shooting mechanics. Most will just see this as an ARK survival game with the artstyle and designs resembling Pkmn.

I was never into open world or building games but this one really sucks you in, its everything Pkmn SV was meant to be with exploration in an open world. The innovation with your pals in this game brings more connection with your monsters as each of them has a role to play-whether theyâre good for battling or not they can all do several different tasks within your base. Just like in Pkmn within this game you can traverse with your monsters alongside you outside the ball and also mount a huge selection of them. In Palworld like in Digimon they added monsters with guns, canons, rockets, and missile launchers, without the pooping.

Being a life long fan of the monster genre I understand why pkmn/nintendo fans are hating on this game because of the designs and the capture sphere mechanics added in resembling Pkmn so much. There is an edit online comparing pkmn designs themselves showcasing they were inspired from Dragonquestâs monster designs. As a fan of this genre I welcome any solid monster taming/hunting game since its been pretty stale the past several years and this one has it all with a bright future ahead of it. This game took it to the next level and the numbers show how many people being lifelong fans of the genre have been waiting for a game like this.

Some things I wish to be added into this game is an IV judge/checker like in the core pkmn games. There are mods for this but I'd rather not go through the hassle of finding and installing them especially with some players reporting some mods hindering their game's performance. Pkmn GO added in the IV checker after the game was released for awhile becoming popular so hopefully they do the same for this. Another mechanic in this game thats much needed is being able to assign your Pals to specific tasks, as some tend to do something else even after throwing them into a specific task. Lastly being able to feed food/meds to workers in your base so you don't have to constantly switch them into your party. 

I've only played 1 file in Single player mode and its been a great experience while still playing alone. I played co op once with a friend and it was pretty cool being able to customize the settings in the steam version and have him catch up to my level quickly. Its also nice being able to turn off incubation times. Afaik xbox is lacking these features and also not able to name your pals in it. I refuse to play in public servers as there are hackers online or just randoms nuking bases. I truly hope this game continues to thrive-I'm really excited and looking forward to all the new updates and pals added in this awesome world. Its been a long time since Iâve been addicted to a game..I was so addicted to Palworld that I ended up skipping the gym and not seeing family/friends for a week. Its that good

really fun game, the current "endgame" could use a little tweaking to balance out the capture rate a little, but other than that, as long as content and bug fixes keep coming i see a good future for this game.

I like the game. It's cute, my Player Character isn't completely useless like they are in Ark, I can catch and breed critters, most of which I can ride for one use or another. The crafting and gathering aspect aren't bad and food is important, I don't know if some of the bosses in the game are soloable without cranking server settings a little bit but at least server settings are an option. There's no admin commands that I know of that do anything useful so good luck figuring that one out- I haven't the foggiest how they playtested this game without proper commands, which is why I believe they mostly didn't.

But hey. Pokemon didn't let me ride my horses and Ark wouldn't let me dodge roll. Neither of them let me automate my base with the help of my pets. Palworld does. So I'm happy with it.

This game does quite a few things right, and as it stands what is currently in place is pretty solid. The problem is it is rather easy to breeze through the content itself. The boss fights are fun enough, but don't require a lot of skill to beat and are pretty easy even without cheesing or glitching. If you want you can blitz a lot of the content relatively quickly and get stuck with nothing to do but min/maxing your pals--which gets boring real fast.

I don't feel like this is an issue with the amount of content available, but rather has more to do with the game's core loop. That, however, is something that will likely change and progress drastically as development continues. As it stands now though, catching pals and leveling them up so you can catch stronger pals to level them up also doesn't really lead anywhere very satisfying, but it is fun for a reasonable amount of time.

has some server issues, i've been unable to play it since the 24th of january. 
game just crashes on me in the main menu, apparently it's due to the epic connection it has.

The game is fun, and i can't recommend it enough but i'd recommend to wait until it's server issues get fixed, since i can't play it at all right now and i'm not the only one. although that'll change once it's playable again since the game is fun, though i'd say play it with a friend, makes for faster resource gathering and it's more fun with a friend anyway, kind of like in valheim. i found out that the issue is an epic connection issue so there's nothing i can do but wait for a fix unfortunately.

update: 
i got the game working by moving it to an external HDD, it didn't work on any of my ssds, other hdds or m.2s 

i've put some more hours into the game and i'm enjoying it, although loading is slow due to having it on an external HDD, it's running fairly well. there are some multiplayer issues, but mostly wonky stuff, nothing too game breaking.
wish that there was a way to party up in-game, after joining a guild to more easily diverse exp gain, right now it's hard to keep levels the same when playing with someone. 

game is fun, i don't like that the eagle has so low stamina for flying, getting wyvern soon though, so hopefully that'll improve it a bit, and i've seen theres a level up tier thing for the monsters, so maybe that'll increase the stamina limit of the flying, who knows. 

not a fan of the waves raiding ur base, fairly easy to do but doesn't really bring much to the game as of right now and i see it more of a nuisance than anything, though it does give some exp and rarely a pal you don't have yet which i guess is a pro for it being a feature. 

other than this, i'm looking forward to more in the future, i believe i heard somewhere that the devs are still making content for the game so that's good. although there's still lots to find, i'm glad that what's there isn't all to come.

Palworld isn't just a game; it's a movement. This humor-inducing treasure trove provides you bang for buck. But it also brought to light an inevitable outcome where Pokemon would be outclassed for their lack of quality improvement. I haven'tÂ played a Pokemon game in over ten years because the qualityÂ of their games never improved, in fact theyÂ deteriorated. It isn't a copycat Pokemon game that exploit their consumers with nostalgia, it's more! The additions of co-op and survival gave what the community yearned for. No matter what happens to this game after its unparalleled success, future games will listen to the community if they want a chance to make history like Palworld did.

When I was just an 8 year old, I fondly remember getting Pokemon Red, Blue, & Yellow (Yellow was in a limited edition bundle with a Pokemon themed Gameboy) for Christmas. I remember how amazing the game was and after I beat the games I was sad. When that happened, me and a bunch of other kids in my school were talking about how to make the Pokemon games better. *Basically* nothing was off limits, I remember one kid saying something like "it'd be cool to eat them" (That was the weird kid in school, I was nice to him because I am awkward) or "You being able to catch people would be so cool, imagine the Gym Leader Giovanni getting a challenge from your character and Officer Jenny pops out and arrests him"

I recommend this game because deep down it appeals to my childhood, wanting to achieve so many cool things in game but the Devs wouldn't do it because Nintendo lacks vision and are puritians in a way. You want machine gun nests? You got it. You want to catch people and make them do your bidding (Same with the Pals)? You got it. You want Swords, machine guns, shotguns, rocket launchers? You got it

The developers seem to be in-sync with their inner child and made something better then everyone got with PokÃ©mon

The game at its current state is very well worth the price. The content right now is rather simplistic and it does have lots of bugs and flaws but I still got a 100 hours of playtime out of it even though I did not really get deep into end game content (perfecting breeds, collecting legendary schematics). I will be breeding the fastest Jetragon for now and then wait to hopefully see lots of content updates.

Some flaws (all in early access - some might get fixed in future updates):
The lock down to regions is pretty much not existent. As soon as you get a flying Pal you can explore the whole map without too much risk of death. This leaves a big question mark if and how this game will ever have more story content than currently (which is pretty much just level up and beat all bosses with no context what so ever). Exploring new regions also becomes kind of irrelevant since there is no real challenge getting there except holding W and shift for a few minutes.

Crafting stuff takes WAY too long or is it fun gameplay to stand and wait for crafting to finish? You may argue that you can get i.e. Anubis and breed him to perfection so it pops out all items real fast but then why is there a stat that I can level for better workspeed (which brings me to my next point).

Most stats are just useless at this point and you should focus on leveling stamina (so you don't instantly drown if you drop below the map when glitched) and weight so you can carry more stuff while hunting Pals.
Workspeed -> gets replaced by Anubis
HP -> just get better shields and armor
Stamina -> useful in the beginning but will become less useful as soon as you get flying Pals
Attack -> Pals do way more damage so why even bother
Weight -> useful

Some questions that will come up in your head over and over again during playing: Why do I have carrying weight inside my bases? Why can I not reset my stats without modding the game? Why can I not have more than 3 bases without mods? Why can I not fast travel from anywhere back to fast travel points without mods? Why does crafting take so long? Why does breeding take 10 years when end game content is pretty much breeding 1000000 eggs? Why do I not just get blasted when I enter regions that are too high for my level? Why do I have to throw 10 legendary spheres when the catch chance is on 70%?

All in all this game is addicting and fun and end game content is optional, which is good, since some players might not enjoy grinding too much. Catching Pals is fun and challenging but can also get frustrating sometimes. You can fix some of the flaws by modding your game which also works on private servers. This game is just what Pokemon fans have been waiting for over all these years of Nintendo pumping out the same content over and over again and I would really love to see this game grow to its full potential.

After 50 hours of playtime, the persistent bugs and lack of meaningful updates are disappointing. The focus on peripheral issues like anti-cheat, instead of core gameplay improvements, and specific problems on dedicated servers, such as character mood issues and movement restrictions, highlight a concerning lack of progress in development. Overhyped poorly thought out game. People comparing this to Valheim/Pokemon/Factorio/Dark Souls are out to lunch, sure it was inspired by those games but the end result is anything but.

Imagine comparing to the king of crafting survival games when ressources you harvest just disapear. If I cut a tree in Valheim and aren't careful, the trunk will kill me, if I cut a tree in Palworld, there's no animation and the tree just disapears. You need to be careful how you build in Valheim, Palworld has a barebone building system inspired by Fortnite

You can't really build a factory, it's just individual workstations with no relations to eachother. No filters, no conveyor belt, no balancing recipes, just a "your pokemons can make bullets for you if they walk in the vicinity of the bullet station and have nothing better to do" just to tick off that checkmark.

Fighting is horrible, unbalanced, you'll spend your time throwing pokemons and humping pillars for the first few hours. Your pokemons don't evolve, cutting pokemons for meat isn't any different than just killing them in the wild with any weapon

It's trash, and they already have another game in EA that they've barely updated and I barely trust indie studios with their first early access titles so juggling two at the same time is a huge red flag

Don't buy into the hype and avoid this steaming pile of trash

After 320 hours and 4 playthroughs, I can say I have done everything I could in this game: reach Level [spoiler]50[/spoiler], defeat all Field Bosses, found and caught all [spoiler]137[/spoiler] Pals ([spoiler]138[/spoiler] including Gumoss Flower), beat all the towers, crafted all Legendary Weapon Schematics + Legendary Pal Metal Helm and Armors, and found and read all Journals. The only thing I have not done is breeding end-game Pals, which I will be doing while decorating my base, waiting for future updates, and playing other games. 

Needless to say, I highly recommend this game despite all its current bugs and glitches. New players have to watch out for hackers in the Official servers though. This is the reason I started a 4th playthrough as these hackers have destroyed our base plenty of times. I advise against playing here until this issue is resolved. I also recommend playing in dedicated servers with friends. My first and second playthroughs were in random servers which did not work out.

Still worth every buck. Will be waiting for future updates/patches

Credentials

*Fully acknowledged that this is early access and so everything stated in this review is written with this in-mind*

Max level on normal mode without adjusting sliders (to make the settings easy). Only change made was no item drop on death. 
Captured all legendary Pals and completed all boss towers. 
Now at min-maxing phase.

Summary

If youâre meant to be studying or working on a project, donât install this game as itâs highly addictive! So much fun to be had. It is 100% worth the asking price. 
Iâd recommend not Googling everything about the game as you go and try and just level through it as blindly as possible as the exploration and discovering new Pals is arguably the most fun part of the game. You really donât want to rush the journey on this one as itâs the best part.  

The three main pillars of play are:
-	Capturing/Killing Pals
-	Base building.
-	Defeating tower bosses.

Subcategories of play:
-	Breeding Pals/Empowering Pals.
-	Resource farming and management. 
-	Exploration. 

End Game
-	Not a lot to do at this stage (early access) other than min-max your Pals, your character and your base. 
-	Hardest achievement (that isnât merely a matter of farming) is capturing the currently available legendary Pals and defeating all of the tower bosses.
-	Once the above is achieved the only real thing to do in terms of actual vertical progression is to re-capture and breed (and condense) the same Pals over and over until you get perfect traits and empower your pals accordingly.
-	You can also farm epic/legendary recipes for crafting the most powerful player items. 

Pros
-	The most fun Iâve had in a game for a long time. Highly addictive and very entertaining.
-	The default (normal) pacing of progression has a nice balance. Itâs not too grindy nor is it overly simple and if you want you can put those sliders where you want them and turn it in to what can essentially be a sandbox game with almost zero difficulty or time-management (I wouldnât recommend this at least until youâve hit max level as it saps the fun out of it).  
-	Itâs a very good-looking game. 
-	In essence itâs a very simple game but it manages to bring the best elements of similar games together in a way that strikes the balance between âthis is really fun and just enjoyable â Iâll do my own thingâ and âIâve got to put an extra build in or capture another ten pals for XP â sleep is for the weak!â
-	Can see endless potential for end-game and wider development. 

Cons
-	Pathing of Pals can be clunky af. Sometimes youâll return to a breeding base only to find that one of the Pals has effed off elsewhere and has got stuck doing nothing. Or your Digtoise has fell off a ledge and hasnât eaten for 6 hours because itâs now stuck. 
-	At this stage (early access), end game feels a touch empty and depending on what you enjoy it is a tad âpointlessâ. Endlessly trying to min-max Pals when you can already clear the hardest content in the game begs the question â is it worth the time?

Personal Wishes for Further Development
-	More raid/tower bosses and vary up the skins/themes of regular dungeons. 
-	An interface to allow solo players to group for raids/dungeons without having to join a multi-player server. 
-	Reduce the number of Pals for the entire âcondensingâ process. Requiring 120 surplus Pals to empower one single Pal to max-stars is a tad much imo. 
-	Allow Pals to simply be assigned to Breeding Pens via an interface (similar to the Palbox) rather than having to grab and throw them in.

Constant crashing, constant data corruption despite having a top of the line PC and high speed internet.  NVIDIA 4080 Super, 64 gigs of RAM, i9 14900k, 2TB SSD, more than enough to exceed the recommended specs. I have made multiple solo games as well as private multi players games so that my wife and I can play together and each and every time I have lost hundreds of hours of game-play. Captured all Pals, completed all towers expect the last because again, crashing is a constant issue with running towers so I cannot get credit for completion. The game itself is great when it is working properly, however after I finish a play session I can no longer log into my existing game as it will constantly crash in a permanent loop regardless if I re-download the game or verify the integrity of my game files. On my wife's brand new 2 week old pc as of writing this review she is only experiencing her pc freezing up upon trying to close the game, which again is a common problem other people are having. Her PC specs are nearly identical to mine as well, but so far she is not having her game files become corrupted after a gaming sessions unlike myself. yet. I can't recommend this game at the moment unless you enjoy losing hundreds of hours of gameplay and I should mention not everyone experiences this issue but It is happening if you read the other 1000 comments all over the internet regarding losing game progress.

Honestly wasn't expecting to like it, but here I am with a ticket to the hype train.  The developers seem extremely down to earth with a focus on user experience, and not as capitalism-y as what has leaked into and seemingly flooded the gaming industry as of late.  Of course there are a few bugs, but it's early access and it also gives the game a lot of character (they aren't detrimental, just sometimes a pal gets stuck outside the walls or gets stuck in a tree and you have to reset them, etc).  There are a lot of well thought details as well, which I really enjoy as it shows the team was passionate about the project!  This game is super fun for casual play as well as combat/capture play as you level up; I can't wait for the upcoming timeline of updates.  Overall highly recommend for someone looking to play something new but familiar.

Fantastic game for survival lovers. With aspects taken from many games, it combines them all to make an engaging experience that continues to develop as you progress through the game. 

There is a real feel of progression with every level unlocking new items and ways to do things.

The pals that roam the world are well designed, and appear to be well balanced, with the 'catch 10' requirements on your pal deck pushing you to explore the map.

A few shaky bugs I've experienced, but nothing game breaking and the game is in beta so I'm not surprised to find a few - I'm sure these will be ironed out in time.

My only negative of this game would be on the base building aspect, it is very clunky and not the most intuitive at times. Coming from other survival games, I think I expected more from the building system here and the capabilities of item placement. Having said this, this does make this more rewarding when you make a nice looking build. I imagine this will also be doctored with time.

Overall, solid game, 8/10

There is one title from the big N which i really enjoyed in recent years, which this definitely takes inspiration from. That is however as far as I would say this crosses any similarity to their games.

Palworld gave us something that has been missing for a long time - a huge map thats heavily populated with content and variations. I have not had so much fun exploring a new games map in a long time, no matter where you go you find pals to interact or fight with. Consistent generation of resources and chests, randomly generated caves which are great for finding new gear.

Being able to play with friends in multiplayer has been great, giving callback to various survival games we have enjoyed over the past decade. I think the simplistic approach to pals and how they are used to work within your base (Work suitability and passive skills) really hits that itch to breed the best pal for the job. The ability to edit world settings;  adjust spawn rates, damage multipliers, and other elements means you can customise your world to not feel like a grind trying to get levels up and collect necessary gear to progress.

Although at this point in time I have defeated every boss, and caught every pal, I am still interested in playing more. Looking forward to updates moving ahead

It's been a long time since I've been this "wow'd" by an early access game.  It takes a lot of different gameplay elements from a lot of different games, and blends them all together.  Like open world survival craft?  Like creature collectors?  Like shooters?  Like base builders/automation games?  This takes many of the best elements of each of the genres and wraps them all up nicely in one little box for you.  I'll summarize a few takeaways that will make your gameplay quite a bit more enjoyable.

Of course it has it's bugs given how new it is, but many of these can be worked around with a little reddit reading and insight.  Some of the biggest QoL hacks are as follows:

1) Don't play on a public server unless you're a severe masochist or hate yourself.

2) Single player mode and private servers remedy most of the issues seen on public servers.

3) Materials in base can be accessed for crafting from anywhere in base, but you can also move them without placing them in your inventory.  Open a chest, drag the item out of the slot, and hit tab.  This allows you to go to another chest or your palbox without the carry weight burden and either open your inventory or chest to place the stack.  This allows for item organization and item transfer between bases easily.  No need for the slow walk of shame.  Place chests next to crafting stations so you can move heavy stacks of crafted items this way by first placing them in a chest.

4) Wood burns.  Fire pals sling fire in combat.  Build with that in mind before you go all grandiose.

5) If production is frustrating you, stop and watch your pals for a few minutes to see where your chokepoints are, then adjust accordingly.  Sometimes a specialist pal can fix all your problems over a jack of all trades due to a lack of other distractions.

6) If you play on a server constantly online, you can avoid pal injury by putting them away until you get back on.  If you value material farming as a priority, ensure you can buy/produce sufficient high quality meds before logging off and leaving them online to work without you.

7) If you have jumpy/graphical/fps issues, you can almost assuredly fix it with a bios update/display driver uninstaller-clean start.  You don't need a wildly powerful machine.  This caused me a lot of grief on my wife's PC until i just broke down and finally went through the process.  Just do your homework first.  Immediately fixed all her issues and she's running an i5 with an rtx 2060.  Old driver directories and audio drivers can wreak havoc on your performance.  I likely would have written if off if my PC hadn't been running it just fine and is the same other than I have an rtx 2050.

8) Raids are fun, but can cause the game to crash due to massive spikes in memory usage.  If you're finding it problematic, particularly on a server, they can be disabled.

9) Entering dungeons/rapid exploration will cause crashes sometimes.  Expect it until it's fixed.  This one is what it is.

10) Most issues you can find an answer to by going to the palworld reddit and searching your issue in the subreddit.

11) IF YOU DIE AND HAVE DEATH PENALTIES ENABLED, YOU CAN RETRIEVE YOUR ITEMS/PALS/GEAR FROM ANYWHERE IN THE BEAM.  YOU DO NOT HAVE TO GO TO THE SPOT ON THE GROUND WHERE THEY LAY.  FLY ABOVE, AND RETRIEVE YOUR STUFF SAFELY.

12) If death penalties are proving an issue due to clipping and falling through the ground when loading in, simply disable them or pick the penalty you deem best until the issue is resolved.  Again though, even if you fall under the map and lose something, you can access it anywhere within that vertical column of light.

13) If your frustrated your pals wont carry food to your cooler/fridge, simply split stacks and fill all the slots in the feed box with food, and ensure your cooler or fridge is the second closest storage container.

All-in-all, I literally can't avoid recommending this game given how well it's performed for me at launch compared to other base builder/survival craft games.  I personally find it absolutely worth what they are asking for it, and the roadmap has a lot of tantalizing features they have in the works.  We really have a gem here.

It's all the bits of your favourite survival games, all rolled up with Pals.
Sure it's a lil buggy atm, but I'm very excited to se how the developers flesh it out.
Having a blast so far :)

This game is unfinished and, as such, still lacking many quality of life upgrades that other games of the genre have.  That said, it is such an interesting take on the genre.  I lost an entire week of my life, thanks to Palworld.  Though the game has lore, it's still lacking in overall story.  I'm really looking forward to seeing what this game has to offer (raid boss for tree... wink, wink).  The legendary pals are tough and definitely deserving of their namesake.  The crafting is fun, but the base building could use some tweaks.  The pal box takes so much room, it's hard to build around it.  Being able to build a chest next to it would be a huge boon when traveling overloaded due to moving bases.  Also, note to developer, add the ability to make circle building please.  Square is so last decade.

For the price of this game, it's a great idea to start with. However, for me, once I get the menial 10 acheivements and catch all the pals to flesh out my 'dex... then the luster of the game is lost for me. I spend a lot of time redirecting my pals to the places I've assigned them to work or pulling them from trees, etc... So, that frustration of 'herding cats' elongates the time I get to play the game. Without that, I'm sure I'd have had my 'dex completed by now. I have 105 pals, last I checked, this includes the 'b' species of pals. My favorite is Katress, despite being a dog person. I love the colors and flashiness of the pals, especially the noct ones. :D 

Other than that, the game is really lackluster past the initial... 'Ohh this is cool' stage. There's no quests to complete past the initial tutorial to really keep you going, other than completing the 'dex. Maybe my opinion will change with future updates and content drops... We shall see... but IMHO, as is, not worth the $29 I spent on it.... maybe worth $15.

If you've ever played one of the other monster catching games and thought "man, it would be nice if I could give this cute little guy a machine gun" or "what if I could run a sweatshop with these guys?" then Palworld is the game for you.

While still in early access, it's more stable than some bigger name games have been at launch... or still are 12 years after they released. >.> It's got plenty to do, and you can fine-tune your game world settings (if you're playing single player) to suit the experience you want. Depending on your play style, you can easily get 50, to 150+ hours of enjoyment out of this game before feeling like you have nothing left to do- far higher if you want to get really in to base building.

Base building is still a little janky, and worker management needs some love, but over all, I think it's a solid game with a ton of potential. I say it's well worth the asking price, even if you're not normally one for survival/crafting games.

As an added bonus, the modding community has taken almost as much of a shine to Palworld as it does to Bethesda games, and are creating a variety of mods including visual updates, quality of life improvements, and even some that alter the core game experience.

I want to preface this by saying, when it worked, the game is a lot of fun and I can tell the devs are trying to make it better in both stability and content, but right now, the game is too unstanble. When I first started playing, it was fine, but when migrating the server to a private server (this can be done and there's plenty of documentation on how), the host will lose all progress. There's some weird workarounds by editing the game files, but I just bit the bullet for my friends and re-leveled and recaught everything (probably a couple days worth of casual play). Then a few days later, my friend's account corrupted and he can't even sign in anymore without starting completely over by clearing the corrupted character data. After doing some reading, I found that if someone leaves a guild and all members aren't online, it has a chance to corrupt a random player's character data which lines up as one of our friends left by accident and came back. A few days ago, one of my friends messaged me that they had logged in and all of our bases were gone. This is a locked down server that I routinely check for unauthorized access, it's all stone bases, so it wasn't a fire. Raids are turned off, so it wasn't destroyed. All the bases were built within the palbox boundaries so they didn't deteriorate. No one has rocket launchers, so it wasn't that either. A few forums mentioned noticing the same behavior if no one had logged in for a few days, the bases would just despawn. So after restarting from scratch twice and a few friends getting fed up with quitting, I can't really recommend the game in its current state until the devs finish ironing out some of the game-breaking issues like these.

If you've got a lot of patience and don't mind restarting your progress over and over randomly some times, there's a good game there and I hope they keep at it since the time I was able to progress, it was a lot of fun and QoL pathes made the game much more enjoyable each time.

yes

1) Pals shouldn't randomly teleport around the base when you quick travel. It results in e.g. mating pals teleporting on top of buildings, and not being able to get back to their station. 2) Pals still stand around getting hungry and don't always reset unless you do it manually. 3) Picking up pals to assign them to tasks is faulty. Sometimes the "Press V to pick up" option doesn't appear, depending on what the pal is doing. 4) Level 2 mining pals should prioritise level 2 mining tasks (e.g. ore) over other tasks (e.g. stone). 5) Sometimes pals just wander around despite having available tasks, even when they're not on a break. 6) Pals should not leave their stations to fight in raids when a. you are not present, b. the raiding pals can't even reach them. Example. I went to a base and every single pal had slid down a bit of mountain to "fight" in a raid (they couldn't reach the enemy) - meaning no cakes, no coal, no honey were being produced for over an hour, and everyone was starving. This happened TWICE in one session. 7) It's too easy to damage your own walls and stations when fighting in raids. Remove friendly fire for allied structures 8) Attacks push enemies through your own defensive walls and into mountains making participating in raids a chore. 9) Production rate at bases seems totally random - sometimes you get heaps of eggs / ores, sometimes you don't, and it seems to depend on things like e.g. quick travel. 10) All of the standard armours come with level 1 cold protection except the most powerful - pal ingot armour... why? If a basic armour can't even be worn at night it's basically useless. 11) Stairs don't work? You can only walk half way up stairs and then you have to jump. Solutions: Give us a GUI to assign pals to tasks and set priorities. Give enemies basic collision detection (???). Reset pals when they are idle or hungry for more than a few minutes. Pals only participate in raids if they are directly attacked or you use an item (ring the bell?) Stop moving pals around randomly when you leave a base, keep them at their station. Calculate production rate evenly when away from base. Give standard pal ingot armour level 1 cold protection.

Ok so I know this game isnt pokemon, but come on......its basically F'ing pokemon. I know it. You know it. The devs know it. Lets cut the BS and address it as it is. 

In my humble opinion and as a long time pokemon fan myself, the reason why this game is good at least partially, is because it is tapping into the untapped potential that the Pokemon franchise never explored with a game. That is, TRUE open world pokemon, with real time battles, survival inbetween towns and gyms, and actual consequences to the player. Again, this game is not Pokemon, and IRONICALLY thats one of the things actually holding Palworld back is that it isnt actually pokemon, but it is doing what pokemon failed to do, and proving just how absolutely starved for good games some of us might be

On its own merits, Palworld is good. Its just incredibly bare bones and basic, right now. I really hope the devs put more meat on the bones of this project because the foundation is rock solid. Like, they arent gonna make a Pokemon killer franchise, because lets be realistic here, Pokemon is not going ANYWHERE, but the right moves made with this solid foundation would go a long long way. I would recommend the game to anyone interested in this concept, even at full price.

It's a fun game. It lacks a lot of story direction right now (EA, so duh), but it is okay. It is essentially ARK with pokemon/digimon designs plastered over it. Unfortunately, it suffers from game-breaking bugs, many of which go against or rob the player of fun experiences. 

The pathing of the pals is bad. They don't do well with walls or stairs, which can limit the space you have since up isn't a great option -- especially since you need massive entry ways for the later, more efficient pals. If you're on a dedicated server, expect to wake up to any combination of hungry, depressed, and/or almost dead pals (or straight up dead). BTW anti-depressants are expensive to make, if you don't abuse certain mechanics with the black marketeers.

Battling is also a bit of a challenge. I've had days, more and more as I play, where pals just circle each other and don't attack until a solid minute or two have passed. Makes catching them easier, but it also feels cheap to just stab an standing target.

This isn't to speak anything of the floor glitching, falling through the world, randomly falling (and dying) pals, and the numerous other "features."

The latest bug I've encountered, which makes the game actually unplayable, is taking constant DOT because of accidentally spawning a clone. Essentially through some kind of mishap, a second you is created and takes constant environmental and hunger damage. This kills you over and over again. The only "fix," at least for servers, is to reboot the server. 

Outside of bugs, there isn't any character customization once you make your character. From my experience this is a common practice, even if I think it is a little silly to wait so long for something that outwardly looks easy to employ.

The story exists in random journals scattered around the world. It isn't heavily pushed or marketed which makes it significantly less interesting. I would like to see more purpose added to the game beyond the tutorial. 

House building also isn't great. You can make cool bases as long as you don't want any corner roofs. Also you have to spend precious tech points slowly gaining most of the decor so things look nice. The weirdest thing for me is the palbases are circular and all the foundations are squares. I didn't understand that design choice.

As a $30 EA game, I do not recommend it. It has its fun moments, but at this point in time, the bugs outweigh the enjoyability. 

TLDR; The game has many bugs that make it not fun to play. For the price tag, that makes the game not worth it. Many QoL features are also missing. Scattered story. Put on wishlist, but follow development if you're iffy about buying.

Amazing game. I picked it up without looking at any pictures, reviews or videos of the game, totally blind. I played at first on a server with just a few people that ended up becoming 12 people later. Restarted as a duo with a friend for 20-30 hours and then restarted again as a solo. I can speak for all parts of the experience from vanilla to boosted resources and everything in between. Virtually no server issues on launch. 

As a solo, the game can be quite a challenge on vanilla. I recommend setting egg timers to 0 and just breeding pals for good traits after about level 30-35. It not only provides more passive exp, but progresses your available pal roster.

This game seems to have quite a bright future. Some have theorized a certain landmark in the game in the northwest to be the center of the map, indicating a further 3 quadrants may be added in the future. I hope they run away with the idea of map expansions. I have waited a long time for a game like this.

TLDR; Had the best launch you could expect, is receiving updates, lots of progression. Great experience solo or with friends

Im sure everyone has heard the comparisons by now, pokemon, ark, rust, etc. Im here to say bump all that and judge this based on its own merits so for ANYONE who is looking at this you have a very good idea from someone who had done all but max out every single pal in the game whats good / bad / ugly. The review is obviously my opinion but i love this game. The game was built with FUN as the 1st priority, you will find easily as many hours as i have or more figuring things out, trying stuff, and exploring (if you dont google everything and wheres the fun in that), and building an "empire". This game has a little something to entice everyone WITHOUT offputting ANYONE. If you like crafting survivial, its here, 3rd person shooter its here, having companions that you can strengthen and "customize" its here, character building and tech its here, building castles its here, difficult challenges and problems to solve its here, exploration and world "building" its here. The graphics and gameplay are awesome albeit a bit clunky, however theres charm to the art style which will remind you of BOTW. Combat will remind you of dodge mechanics seen in from software games, and combat can be fun with different movesets and boss variations. There are however some bugs and glitches that will drive you up a wall sometimes. We hope Pocket Pair will fix these things before giving more content because i personally think content here is ample but we NEED to have the smoothest and seamless experience this game COULD be. You also have some issues with pals pathing, being stupid, or otherwise bothering you. Character movement is again clunky, and aiming, shooting, etc can be rough and unpolished. All things an early access title is expected to have.... the goal being these issues are addressed sooner rather than later with the roadmap content updates they have planned being on the backburner (please). This game is EASILY worth your $30, or less depending on sales when you compare it to the AAA GARBAGE that is being put out in the same genre or things this game is compared to. I dont think anyone ever wanted Ark, pokemon, etc to be THIS game but i tell you what compared to the hot BS pokemon is putting out, the buggy and BS MESS ark is now putting you through from a greedy developer, and more thats so prevalent now a days in this industry Pocket Pair SO FAR has been a diamond in the rough of good stuff for gamers. I sincerely hope they continue this path and make this game absolutely colossal in the coming months / years and when its time to lay Palworld to rest (inevitably at some point) i hope Palworld 2 or whatever they make next shares the fun nature of this game and delivers on what so many companies today fail to do; make a fun sandbox of a game for gamers to explore, have fun alone or with friends, and sink time in without feeling its a waste or takes too long to get going. 
---{ Author }---

The game looks incredibly good (imagine pokemon games looked like this, ouch). There is a considerable variety in "pals" although I hope more will be added with future updates. The overworld feels alive (unlike pokemon legends arceus) and there is plenty to do wherever you go. The game gives you a large amount of all kinds of settings you can adjust as you like before entering a world. Building your bases is fun too.
 
A few negatives:

1. The sound seems glitched sometimes, if you leave or faint in a boss battle, the fighting music often continues instead of the normal overworld music playing. 
2. Limited bag space is very annoying, even with pal skills that increase it, if you hit the limit (which you will if you active loot rs) you will move much slower than a snail, the slow down is too ridiculous, though limited bag space should not exist at all. It forces the player to constantly return to a base and come back to the rs location, over and over and is just a huge waste of time. 
3. Some attacks (at random!) by enemy pals and bosses come out instantly, which is a huge flaw. A player can not dodge something that has no indicator, and no charge.
4. Wild enemy pals have no aggro range limit, they will follow the player until you defeat them or you die. Any WoW player will know why this is another big negative.
5. Once you fast travelled, you often get attacked by nearby enemies as soon as you spawn near the fast travel loaction, which can easily result in you getting spawn killed. There should be nothing in close proximity to any fast travel location.

Keeping it at a not recommend until these issues have been fixed.

The game is far from polished; it has some minor bugs and glitches, but that's to be expected early on in the game's life. When I started my game I was unable to use the character creator, and it kept giving me a error message. That aside however, once I get in game it runs well, but has some frame drops in new areas, especially when in fights with pals that use a lot of particle effects. I have the minimum specs, so this is to be expected though.

Overall, I do really enjoy the game. It's fun and engaging, and even a bit challenging in higher-level areas. It can feel grindy sometimes having to get more resources, but that's what pushes the player to find new pals that can do the work for you. 

Overall, this game is definitely a banger and worth playing. In a few months I expect this to live up to it's full expectations, especially with the frequent updates.

All of the typical 'Early Access' bugs aside? This game can easily be described as Pokemon meets Ark, as I'm sure just about everyone is aware by now. A friend of mine and I just rented a private server for a year and we're having a blast with it. This is the kind of game that Nintendo should have released years ago, and this game will probably stay pretty popular until they do. 111 different kinds of creatures to capture and breed in an open world sandbox setting that has all kinds of PvE opportunities and base building.

That said? I do have a few small gripes with what seems to be some core features, not bugs. Bear in mind that these are mostly opinions on my part, though, and not really factual statements. I'm sure there are those who enjoy some things that I don't and vice versa.

1st.) Pal Sphere capture rates: Unless you're playing on casual mode, or have otherwise tinkered with the settings? The initial blue spheres become obsolete almost immediately. Aside from the first three pals out of 111? These things are basically useless, you're more likely to accidentally kill the pals you're trying to capture to get their health low enough for the capture chance to be worth it. It would be one thing if these things weren't so resource demanding to make, but by the time you're set up to make these handily? They're already practically useless and you're on to Megaspheres, which are even MORE resource intensive.

2nd.) Player attack targeting: So... there's a targeting reticule, but your attacks may, or may not, actually go where that's pointing. More often, they'll just automatically try to target whatever Pal happens to be within your line of sight and closest to you, which has gotten me killed on many occasions when my attack veered way the hell to the right and hit a level 35 Mammorest instead of the level 5 Lifmunk I was ACTUALLY trying to hit. That REALLY needs to be fixed, like, ASAP. Please and thank you, devs.

3rd.) Map glitches: This game is SUPER early release, and I understand that. Thankfully, the devs foresaw this issue and included a 'respawn' button in the options menu in case you get stuck. But the sheer number of map glitches I've experienced in my nearly 100 hours of game time thus far has been kinda ridiculous and could use some serious and immediate attention.

There are other minor gripes and complaints I have as well, but most of those are just the result of the game being as early out as it is. I would still highly advise anyone interested that they buy this game now before it becomes completed and the price increases further. You're going to regret it if you don't.

For being early access, this is an incredibly complete game.  While there are some glitches and bugs, none of them are completely game breaking.  If the game is already THIS good while being in early access, I cannot wait to see what it's like upon full release.

This is a great game, if you're into "cozy" games, particularly because there are so many settings that you can mess with to tailor the gameplay exactly to your style.  Don't like raids?  Turn 'em off.  Hate the idea of building degradation?  It's gone.  The ability to make those individual changes goes such a long way to making these game enjoyable for everyone.

My biggest complaint about the game is the lack of auto-run.  If you've got wrist issues, this WILL begin to impact your gameplay and limit your game time.  Seems like a fairly simple add, but as it wasn't included in launch of the early access, I'm not terribly hopeful it will be added later on.

If you like base-building survival games, this one is all right. It's not super deep in the survival department, and the base building still needs some work, but it's still in early access for a reason, and the devs are still working on it slowly but surely. (Very small dev team, from what I understand, so things take a bit.)

If you like creature collecting RPGs... Well, despite the constant comparisons to Pokemon, this game isn't for you.

What this game is, is a fun, creature collecting, base building, survival, action-adventure, exploration game with some RPG elements.

I don't really care what moralists sayâwhether it's somehow inspired or copy-pasted content from Pok*mon, or even if it was AI-generated (which I don't really think). It's something that gave us many hours of fun, so the game is worth every penny. Of course, the game is a product of "amateurs" in UE5, so it still has bugs (the pathfinding bug is the only one that really annoys me), but overall, it had a smoother start than most triple-A games. It offered more content and was more enjoyable than most triple-A games.

If you are a gamer and don't care about some copyright nonsense, then I can recommend this piece. Hopefully, developers will surprise us with more additional content in the future.

Look, it's early access, it doesn't have all the features, but MAN is this game fun!  Treat it like any survival game, just with Pokemon you can capture, kill, eat, and make HAPPY labor at your camp (unless you want to work them to death, in which case, go ahead!).  Hatch eggs, put your pals through a blender and feed them to others to make them more powerful, and roam a whole world riding beautiful/deadly monsters!  Oh, and give them guns and artillery to blow stuff up.  If you like a stupid satire that has a happy, bouncy, fluffy tone to it, all the while involving death and violence without any blood whatsoever, then play this game!  It's dumb, it's fun, it's dumb fun, and if anyone has a problem with the tone of this form of entertainment, know that no actual animals were harmed in the making of this game.
