It's good. It isn't amazing. Its not ground breaking. It doesn't do anything new or unique that hasn't been done before in some other way. But what this game does right It goes all in on making it one of the best early access survival/craft games you can buy. People always compare it to pokemon which is honestly stupid and ignorant, because this game and pokemon have nothing in common except from creature capturing. The combat isn't built around RTS and pals aren't really scaled at all for combat. The typings don't flow like they do in pokemon and each thing is only strong to one type (except fire which has two strong types). If you want to compare it to anything, this is Ark meets Breath of the wild. 

Starting off with the pros, the game drops you right into the world and let's you go do whatever you want. There are several starting locations you can respawn to, but you're better off just staying in the area it drops you in.

A few NPCs will guide you on what to do, and the tutorial system holds your hand through how to build a base and level it up. Once you hit level 20 you can go challenge the first boss and the boss fights are really fun. You have free range to adjust just about every single setting in your world down to how much damage you deal, how many pals spawn, how much damage you take, experience you gain, etc, etc. The freedom of the game is the best feature and i don't think enough people really appreciate that.

Another huge pro is the freedom with building and how easy it is to just get into. Most survival/craft games make it a chore to build and limit you on what you can do. Palworld let's you do pretty much whatever you want. You get up to 3 main bases you can leave pals at, and you can craft small bases anywhere on the map. There are a few restrictions to building that I hope gets fixed in the future (snap tools being added, place stairs easier and where ever I want). The real fun of the game comes from making your own bases and defending it from raiders, and i can't wait to see how this improves in the final release.

The bad is...well a lot. Unfortunately cheating is a massive problem right now and the developers are working that out, but playing on public servers is risky. Thankfully when they add in EAC it will be optional to turn on for private servers and single player which is amazing.

Secondly after the 15 hour mark the game becomes a long, tedious grind where you have to strategically place your bases for farming rather then what's fun, or else you'll be wandering around. You can technically capture humans which is funny at first, but loses its appeal as you realize you can't really do much of anything with them. They will only attack with fists even if they are armed with weapons, and working around the base they are decent but not decent enough to replace a pal. The one exception is the black market dealer who you can place in your base and buy things from.

There's a lot more I can talk about and break down but I think this is enough. If you like survival/crafting games, enjoy base building and third person shooting then you'll enjoy this game. If you go in thinking it's a pokemon clone you'll be disappointed because as I said above, this is more like Ark.

I've given the game plenty of hours.
Sum of Gameplay: Exploration, building, traveling and discovery, A LOT OF GRINDING OF RESOURCES, simple combat mechanic, and guns (though not that easily crafted).

The good of this game is that it gives satisfaction on progressing through the game and being able to discover new things as you travel around the game's world. Yes, some of the models is similar to Pokemon's but they at least give it their twist on the mechanics to make it not feel like you are playing Pokemon. Sure you have the models, the "gyms," and the "spherical balls," but you can just beat them up yourself, make them your pal, and put them to work or sell them at the black market.

     The bad is that it's revealed to be a survival build game with a lot of grinding to the game (especially ore). The biggest fix I think to satisfy this downside is to allow servers to edit stat limits especially to weight since you're going back and forth a lot for mining.
     The main point of the game that got everyone (even you) to buy the game is that they put guns in the game. The issue is that you'll have to play at least 4 hours (or grind experience really fast) to get your first gun which would be a musket. The advertised gun in the gameplay trailer is at the very end of the game after playing for weeks 6 hours a day with LOTS of grinding for the resources to make the gun. And that's even if you have the points in the game to make the gun, in order to get anything in the game you need to both level up and get points which is obtained through grinding anyway.

     If the grind is an issue though you can tweak this in the game to receive more materials, but the stats of the character cannot be changed so hauling material back to your building is still an issue (You can either get a pal that can handle your weight limit or you can level up and put points to your weight limit, but then that's the only stat you would be focusing).

     Just so everyone knows, they did remove some trailer videos from their page which dwelled into more of the mechanic of "sweatshopping," but this was removed since they didn't really have a means for people to actually mass produce without you getting your hands dirty.
     There are bugs in this game while this review is posted, but I will not include them here since the developers are REALLY on top of things concerning to be an issue.

     Yes, the game is completely fun. Just that you do have to do a lot of repetition to progress and unlock the cool stuff you are actually interested in.

Palworld is great. It's intuitive, has a great gameplay loop, rewards you for trying clever things and is satisfying in short play sessions or in a longer binge. It's relaxing and empowering, simple and dynamic. It's not a rip off of anything - it's a mashup and a delightful one at that. It has some bugs (pals getting stuck on top of things) and I can feel the content starting to level off after nearly 40 hours and hitting level 39 or so. But for an early access game that costs $30? Worth it.

But if you are a person who likes to explore, don't read too many guides. You'll get it easily enough.

That being said, those first few sessions are easily worth the asking price in my opinion. If you have friends to play with it will be even more worth the payment and last longer. Fun while it is, but I won't be returning unless there is a notable update to the game as replayability pretty much doesn't exist here as the grind stops being fun at about level 25 and is dreadful come level 30. I can only hope the devs fix the bugs, add features and make some quality of life improvements but from the looks of it they have stuck with their other games so I'm not too worried. Can't wait to see more from the devs of Palworld!

If you've ever imagined Pikachu with a Gatling gun or Dragonair toting a missile launcher, then Palworld is about to turn those fantasies into reality.

Picture this: roaming through the Palpagos Islands, doing your thing, when suddenly, a wild Pal appears. But instead of throwing a Pokeball, you whip out your trusty shotgun and go full Rambo on it. It's like PokÃ©mon meets Fortnite, and let me tell you, it's as crazy as it sounds.

But Palworld isn't just about catching critters and turning them into soldiers. Nope, it's also about survival and building your own little army of Pals. Need a guard for your base while you're off gathering resources? Just drop your Pal into your base via PalBox and watch the chaos unfold during a raid.

Sure, Palworld has its quirks. Some say it relies too much on shock value, and others grumble about its not-so-original designs. But let's be real, who cares when you're riding into battle on the back of a machine-gun-wielding giant yellow rabbit or unleashing a barrage of missiles from the back of a dragon?

In the end, Palworld is a rollercoaster of ridiculousness that's as entertaining as it gets. So grab your Pal Sphere, load up your favorite firearm, some grenades, and get ready for the wildest gaming adventure of your life.

I can't speak for the multiplayer side of things, only played the single player mode, gotten 70 hrs out of it, starting to run out of stuff to do but have enjoyed myself so far. 

Games basically Ark without the bloated install size, more quality of life, cuter creatures and a more straightforward taming mechanic.

Only real issues I have had are some of the bigger Pals getting stuck on buildings in bases we can make, kind of hard to avoid though considering we can catch the various world bosses and they don't shrink in size after you catch them. Path finding could use a bit of work both in are bases and in combat both for are Pals and enemy Pals.

As for the black company treatment side of things, despite it being one of the most mentioned things about the game you really have to go out of your way to be an A hole towards your Pals, I left their work settings on normal, only downside was it took a little bit longer for them to get work done, you can play just fine without needing to mistreat your Pals. 

Once you get the Jet Dragon mount you will probably never be able to go back to any of the other mounts, it's so fast it makes you wonder if you even need to use fast travel.

Late game basically boils down to hunting for rarer schematics for weapons, armour, catching more Pals, breeding, Pals with desired passive traits and making your favorite Pals stronger. Tearing down your bases and rebuilding them more to your liking.

Anyway I look forward to seeing what they do with the game going forward.

I understand this game is in Early Access, but it was not ready to be released. Don't get me wrong, this game is and will be incredibly fun, but it is WAY too buggy. Randomly teleporting, getting stuck in walls, having Pals get stuck in walls, dash abilities ending up in random locations, having my weapons glitch so that I can't use them, and also having spheres glitch so I can't use them either. These are just some of the many glitches that ranged from 'annoying' to 'frustrating'. It wasn't until recently where my character became glitched to take damage at all intervals for no reason. Have to Ctrl + Alt + Del to close game, manually quitting doesn't work. Restart game? Still taking damage. Respawn? Still taking damage. Close server and restart it? Fixed for 5 minutes then back to constantly taking damage. The game is now physically unplayable for me after 70+ hours. This game somehow has more glitches and bugs than Gen 1 in Pokemon. 

Don't buy the game yet. Wait for it to be fixed. I know its a small team of devs and I spent a long time defending this game, but it wasn't ready. Its too broken. Save your time. This game had potential to be more than a fad upon release, yet it makes Cyberpunk's release look like a polished product.

I mean, c'mon. It's not Pokemon with guns. That's like saying that Digimon is Pokemon with an internet connection.

TL;DR: Play it, or don't. It's a solid little bit of fun. There are some polish issues, and the menus are a little clunky, but the character controls are smooth, gathering and crafting are relatively painless, there are plenty of drops and pickups, and the Pals are equal parts adorable and terrifying. 


What it IS is a solid survival game with easily recognizable, solidly built survival and exploration mechanics that have become nothing short of an industry standard. Try playing *anything* survival-based without movement mechanics, transportation mechanics, clothing, weapons, crafting, etc. Yes, it has a glider. Yes, it has guns. Yes, it has pickaxes and axes. Yes, it has tiers. What next, are you going to call it Minecraft with Pokemon? That's called Pixelmon, thank you kindly. Pokemon with servers? That'd be PokeMMO. Let's move on to the real meat and potatoes here, yeah?

Palworld looked cool from the second I saw it, and I wanted to at least give it a shot as soon as I saw a giant blue dinosaur with rocket packs on its back. The second I jumped into the world, I realized it for what it was: a love letter to every ARPG and Creature Collector that ever came before it. I can see elements inspired by Horizon Zero Dawn, Fortnite, Pokemon, Minecraft, The Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, Tomb Raider, Borderlands, Monster Hunter, Mario....the developers clearly looked at things and went, "Alright, so this was successful. People enjoy it. It would fit in our world. How do we make it ours? How do we make it better?" Did they succeed? 

Yes and no.

Here's the nitty gritty Pros and Cons of Palworld, in my opinion:

Pros:
- Clean, colorful style
- Highly customizable for repeated play
- Recognizable creatures
- Good balancing
- Decent progression
- Ability to upgrade catch rate
- Solid exploration options
- Plenty of pickups
- Well-executed open-world environment
- Multiplayer Option
- Devs that care and communicate

Cons:
- Pals get stuck a lot (logging sites especially)
- Stat Points feel like an afterthought
- Run out of space quickly, in both backpack and storage options
- Polishing issues in the environment (collisions and gaps, mostly)
- Weird loading errors occasionally
- Can't really reliably command pals in your base
- Menu navigation is, honestly, super-clunky
- Keyboard control scheme feels weird

Look, it's not Ark, it's not Pokemon, it's not Fortnite.

It's Palworld.

Give it a go, or don't. If you do give it a go, I have one piece of advice for you:

Don't make the giant leaf mammoth mad until you KNOW you can handle it. Not think. KNOW.

Also, you can play a normal game and just turn off the lose items on death thing. It's in the settings.

Also also, put some bloody clothes on. 

Also also also, don't forget to free the pal in the cage when you come across the campsites.
i killed him

Strong recommendation: For games with shooting and aiming, when the player uses a controller, please do not lock the mouse aiming, or automatically switch the input mode to keyboard mode when using the mouse. It is strongly recommended that mouse input and controller input can coexist.
We controller players really like gyroscope aiming, but if the gyroscope is mapped to the right joystick in Steam, there will be a dead zone inside the game itself, resulting in a poor experience and subtle movements will be ignored. If you map the gyroscope to a mouse, the aiming accuracy will be very good, similar to the air mouse effect.
But after mapping to mouse, as long as mouse input is found in the game, it will be switched to keyboard keys. For example, the x button of the controller is used to pick up things. When the game detects mouse input mapped by the gyroscope, the button will flash and change to E/x, and various skills will not be released normally when riding a mount.
Gyro aiming is really good news for the majority of players, and also good news for the gaming industry. I hope kind-hearted producers can consider this suggestion.

I've quickly managed to pump a bunch of hours into an early access game. This, in and of itself, doesn't seem like that big of a deal - and for many people, it likely isn't. For me, though - it simply . . . is.

I tend to shy away from EA games, or at the very least piddle around with them for a few hours and then shelve them until they get more gameplay. I'm not one to play a game for hundreds of hours, and then do it all again every time there;s a major update. But, with Palworld, I got . . . hooked. I don't play survival games. I don't really play creature collection games. I don't play (many) crafting games. I enjoy Sun Haven and Stardew Valley for farming games, so I thought that aspect alone might get me going awhile.

It's here the game "got me". The game is in EA so it's janky. Pals pathing is terrible and you have to constantly monitor them getting stuck in walls, or refusing to climb stairs. I have crashes when I exit to the main menu and try to go back in. The AI enemies will take off running - straight into a wall. There's not a lot of variety for crafting and farming in it's current state, but what IS there is addictive and fun and it gives me that "Lemme just do this one thing before I log off" and then I wind up playing for another 90 minutes. And that right there is why I say, yes . . . I recommend it.

I kinda expected this game to be a pile of slop that I'd just enjoy for a little bit based on what I saw people saying, but it's actually good! It's really cool having a monster tamer with *this* much interactivity with your "pals". You can throw em out to run beside you whenever, manage how they'll help craft stuff at your camp, and you can mount and manually control the moves of a pretty surprising number of them. Once you get some faster mounts the game really opens up. It does really feel like a really good implementation for an open world pokemon-type game. The pals are tied in with pretty much every aspect of the survival gameplay and I really like it.

It's not really beating the "copying pokemon's homework" allegations with some of their designs though, like Lycanroc was pretty much ripped into this. He's one of my favorite pokemon though so meh, I like him here too. There are a lot of pretty original pals in here that are cool though, and while they really didn't go out of their way at all to differentiate their designs from pokemon, I think we can let games share concepts like "water type penguin" or "round sheep" without much fuss. I expected to go into this game and point and laugh at a bunch of plagiarism, but was pleasantly surprised. Any monster collector game is going to feel like pokemon since they dominate the genre, but this is a fun game and does a lot to show cool new directions that this genre can go in.

Also the voice acting for human NPCs is tip top notch

Strong 7/10 (bugs included in score)


Strong 7/10 (bugs included in score)

Pros:

- Easy to learn survival system, combat, & pals (tutorial included)

- Informative & helpful UI/Menus

- Over 100 different Pals to catch. Have many uses for combat, resource gathering, traversal, farming, cooking, breeding new pals.

- Buggy, but fun AI & resource automation at home base. Using pals to farm resources at base is extremely useful & very fun to look at.

- Pals have unique animations & personalities

- Can play relaxed at base helping pals, & farming local mobs & resources, building a nice house or explore world and find new pals, tech, & syndicate bosses

- Great pokemon/monster catcher combat fantasy game

Cons:

- Items randomly disappearing when disassembling storage. lost many important items and hours of progress farming and processing resources.

- Clunky gun combat

- Lots of pop In when traveling or flying, hard to see pals at high heights. Needs better fps performance/stuttering

- Pal AI during combat is buggy, especially with large/Jumbo pals & pal melee attacks. Pals also constantly getting stuck in base & hungry, especially when mining ores on non flat ground, or on mountaintops

- Can't assign pal priority tasks

Bugs:

Clicking Right stick works to sort inventory while swapping with storage items, but not in the actual inventory menu

Pals constantly getting stuck while at base and dying from hunger & simple injuries

Pals getting stuck in walls when escaping a pal sphere near walls, or in small areas

Pals Idle and refuse to work

Pals are obsessed with moving my repair kits from one storage to another, all over my base

Pals ignoring tasks when thrown to assign

Pals spawning stuck on top of objects

Pals keep falling off edge of mountain base and getting stuck, slowing production

Pals keep ignoring kindling tasks

Pals ignore ore that is partially clipped in the ground inside base

Pals getting stuck inside wood defense wall

Enemies clipping into ground and mountains when invading base & confuses pals

Base invasion notification doesn't appear onscreen when using pal box or menus

items randomly disappear when disassembling storage

Would like:

Allow transfer of items between bases

Assign resources to be stored in specific storage boxes by pals

Add top down base editing option to move around and place objects

Let players assign priority task list to specific pals

Let players adjust pal size to small for easier base navigation

This is a very hard decision to say if I recommend this game or not. In it's current state it is very buggy. However the game is so just so much fun. Don't dismiss this game as a Pokemon clone. It's the perfect hybrid between Breath Of The Wild and Pokemon and really is better than both of them. The gameplay is sublime very challenging and complex. Ironically, this is (Mostly) what I had hoped Pokemon's Legends Arceus would be, build a small town, populate it, deal with wild 'mon attacks on occasion, make 'balls, deal with life in the early days before everyone was a trainer and the world was still HEAVILY in the favor of the 'MONS... But I do got some things to say both for and against it...
Pros:
1; You are pretty much free form in what you do, how you play, where you go (mostly) and what you build(mostly).
2; A lot of pals, some breeding exclusive, some you need to be maxed level, with maxed level pals and the best gear and still struggle against.
3; Overall plays as a mix of third person shooter, base builder, monster team builder and bits of other genres mixed in to make it a unique overall game with some (VERY HILARIOUS) issues that crop up.

Cons:
1; Building is VERY wonky, and you'd think Foundations would snap to stairs if you are going downhill but you (For Now) will need to find various tricks to put foundations to build a second level up stairs on say a hill or a rock to make a bigger base...
2; Some of the things the game tells you to do are pretty much a 'find it out yourself, newbie' on what the hell it means.
3; On occasion while playing my base literally just clips through the ground, and would wind up stuck underground with no way out, so be aware the building is still VERY wonky, but still fun. Also Pals AI for pathing... its utterly stupid and somethings instead of going up a flight of stairs would run against the stairs connecting foundation starving itself due to said stupidity...

What this game lacks in depth, it makes up for in charm. Palworld's hype is centred around the latter, yet you may want to hold off on picking up this game until it has addressed the former. 

While there are elements of survival and base automation, the game centres around hunting creatures by either capturing or killing them to grind through a tech tree. 

If you want to treat your Pals kindly, you will have a hard time enjoying this game, since it is exclusively cruelty that is rewarded.

[b]Updated after 17 hours of game play.[/b]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The start of the game has you capturing Pals and building a base, and I found a lot of enjoyment in getting set up. Despite being a survival game of sorts, I had no struggle with inventory management and picking up early resources, the biggest frustration being unable to move buildings and workbenches. Pals help out around your base with delightful mannerisms, giving you a sense of their character. You are also given plenty of time to learn and experiment with the basic mechanics of combat and base building, which I appreciated. 

Pals assigned to your base can become stressed, and they might "slack off" and stress eat through your food supplies, but there are no early game mechanisms for the player to address this issue other than 'storing' the Pal away and replacing them with another Pal. More experienced players seem to opt to "butcher" the offending Pal before replacing them. Pals get stuck regularly, many buildings require manual feeding of resources, and your base visits will always be a micromanagement chore.

I played fully solo on normal mode. You can adjust grind settings, but I found doing so was a band-aid solution where grind is still unavoidable to craft mid-game items.

[h1]What Could Have Been Better?[/h1]
[b]I wanted to feel my character was struggling to survive on an island of magical beasts. I would have loved some early game structures and better variety of options to address Pal's needs.[/b] 

Rather, the game is content with having you grind to collect as many Pals as possible and gives you no reason to form an attachment to any of them. Why give the creatures so much personality and then treat them as disposable in the game mechanics?

In fact, Palworld seems to nudge you to believe that that Pals are to be treated with disdain. I can only assume such disdain is used to justify repetitively capturing Pals to grind experience points. For an open world survival game, Palworld's has an over-dependence on extrinsic reward. Why is the game telling me I need to collect 30 Pals as my first objective? Why do I need 10 of each species to get bonus experience? Surely the player should be the judge of how many Pals they need to manage their base and accompany them on journeys? 

Instead, grinding is used to compensate for lacklustre world building. Minor adjustments to the tech tree could make it more balanced. The NPCs scattered around do little to help enrich the world building, and their shallow dialog detracts from it if anything. I would have loved if Palworld did not feed exposition in the form of dialog and on-the-nose shock value, but rather introduced implicit storytelling. 

[b]Building a community of creatures and collecting new species, especially of a more challenging variety, is where my enjoyment was rooted.[/b] The real-time battles are certainly fun and the game might be worth it for that alone. One frustration I had with combat was the risk of accidentally killing Pals before you can capture them, even after repeated capture attempts despite an enemy being one hit from death. Again, the grind comes in of crafting increasingly more powerful Pal Spheres to capture them.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Palworld seems to try to appeal to audiences of creature capture and monster hunter games who were looking for something slightly different, but not too different. I like the idea of creature capture games, but I was never able to get into the series of games Palworld tries to imitate, and I suspect this is why Palworld falls short for me. I do not like grinding without meaning. The addition of a story, or more focus on the role-playing aspect of the game would have certainly sold me on the concept. Or at least better base building & management mechanics beyond butchering misbehaving Pals. Palworld explores dark elements like slavery, but offers no moral contrast - shock value without meaning. 

[b]I would love to be given choices that would allow for me to form meaningful connections with my Pals or with the world itself, but alas, I must capture yet another dozen Pals to grind through the tech tree.[/b]


[h3]Updates[/h3]
[list]
[*]The treatment of Pals gets worse as the game progresses. If you want to treat you Pals kindly, you will have a hard time enjoying this game. Its difficult to ignore that Palworld prioritises being edgy over making its game mechanics enjoyable. Take the Butcher Pal command - few players enjoy sitting through the butcher animation to get those bonus resources. Why not add a "release Pal" command alternative, or NOT give bonus rewards for butchering? In Palworld you play as Evil or Very Evil, there is no in between. I would just prefer if I had more options.

[*]I am coming from survival games like Sons of the Forest and Enshrouded, where survival, exploration, and base building/management are the focal points, and where the grind is more immersive and intrinsically rewarded, allowing the player to measure their own progress and do things in their own way. Palworld is very restrictive in how you play, effectively giving rewards for completing a checklist of tasks.

[*]I have expectations around bugs and content in early access games. I've played too many EA survival games with known bugs that persist years after release out of EA. Pocket Pair does not have the best reputation maintaining updates for their EA games. 

[*]I maintain that even after 15 hours, Palworld feels shallow as far as survival games are concerned.
[/list]

Unacceptable state

This game really captured me and I enjoyed it with all of its bugs. I could potentially go past them. But after having two stacked bases, with very rare resources, items and materials, everything was lost from a simple action of leaving an inactive guild. Yes, without a warning, both the bases exploded, leaving me only with all my pals but zero resources. Feels like a lot of hours went down the drain for no reason. Very disappointing.

Now let me tell you about the bugs i turned a blind eye to:
Combat glitches - enemies get flung through walls and get stuck there. No, it does not happen once in a blue moon, but in almost EVERY single combat, especially in dungeons. Rookie design error.
AI stuck - not just being stuck into walls, but the AI of your Pals and enemy pals freezes occasionally. Leaving them to be easily picked off.
Base chaos - a lot of Pals are huge and the base is always tiny. When Pals are in front of a box or PC you want to use, they block your access. Also when you have two objects too close to each other it will be a pain to try selecting one or the other. Also, your pals get stuck, or refuse to do the jobs you assign them to (sometimes they do, sometimes not)
Empty husk of a world - with lots of treasures given generously to distract from the fact that there is no story. Just landscapes with spawns. And 5 towers, which are the equivalent to gyms in Pokemon, but can in theory be all completed within half an hour if you are high enough level.
Lack of elemental thematic - while I really enjoy the 9 distinct types and a simple circular type effectiveness chart, there is not much "theme" that sets the various types apart. The game has just a handful of moves for each type, and everyone can learn any move, which kind of kills the themes a bit. 


I turned a blind eye because I was sick of Pokemon games, and this is a very fresh take with a lot of elements I wanted to see in Pokemon and some fresh ones that I did not know about.

But when a game wipes ~30 hours of progress, it's too much, and I can't overlook that. It's the biggest sin a game can commit.

But Early Access!

Yes, I understand it is early access and it is a very ambitious project. And I was really really patient. But If you ponder purchasing this in Early Access, I'd say give it a pass unless you are a massive Pokemon fan. It's got a really long way to go and the mechanics of the game are not there yet. And beware of progress wipe!

I am recommending this, because at it's core, it's a good game, and the devs seem committed to supporting the game and getting to a place where it is fully playable.

HOWEVER. Losing 2 40+ hour saves to the ether is a BIG freaking problem. I attempted to recover those saves via the support, but no luck. Be warned, the game, in it's current state for me at least, crashes constantly, sometimes leading to your entire world disappearing.

I'm gonna give this game a good level of depth for this review. Before I say what I find is important, I must emphasize that I'm not writing this review to hate on this game. I don't wanna put this game down. I want for this game to become better, A lot better. What I see here is a great concept and a good mix of multiple games (Such as Pokemon, Breath of The Wild, Minecraft, Fortnite, Elden Ring etc.). This game is basically a mix of these games and many more. And though I like the idea of this game itself, man does it have so many issues that make this game an absolute slog to play through.

For starters, I LOVE the Pals designs in this game. They look amazing man. Honestly, these designs are better than modern Pokemon designs. And I mean that wholeheartedly.

I also love the boss battles and how they're designed. The combat itself even! I think the combat in this game is fairly balanced, and the level system/catching system is fairly evened out so that its enjoyable and good for this game. Honestly, this game has a lot of merit in its capabilities. I also think the fast travel system is... fine. Kinda a worse version of breath of the wilds fast travel system, but it suffices. I really am looking forward to future updates in hopes that these things, and MANY others things are improved upon in the future.

Now for some of the bad stuff. One of the lesser and more minor issues is that the map feels incredibly bland and empty. I understand that this game was released in early access. It was released that way to garner attention and hype for this game, hence garnering more money for the team as well. I can also understand that the devs may have released this early due to wanting some perspective from the fans too. But look, none of these reasons are (In my opinion) good enough to justify releasing a game in such a bland, boring and broken state, and calling it GOOD. As you go through the map at around maybe mid-game (Which in every world the map is the same for everybody which is incredibly lame) you start to see the same pals over and over again. So many places in this game feel insanely empty, and thrown together. So much so that I was literally able to walk INTO the map structures in some places, which in my opinion isn't a HUGE issue, but it is embarassing on the devs part and really makes even the 30$ price tag hard to justify (Again, EVEN if it IS early access). This game feels rushed and bland in so many places, to the point that it literally lacks its own identity. And that would be okay, only if it wasn't such a BAD copy of the games its trying to duplicate.

Speaking of this game being a bad, bland and broken copy. The graphics and characters (Not the Pals, Just the characters) look like they were ripped straight out of fortnite. In fact, the whole games graphical style looks like an empty version of the fortnite map. And I don't even like fortnite. Ain't play it fr in 5 years. Yet the first thing I said when entering a world was "Wow, this looks so much like fortnite". And it doesn't get better graphically later on at all.

Moving a bit faster here, The stat system is like a 5/10. I'm sorry but the whole weight thing is garbage and makes the entire game feel like an empty slog. They should replace the weight system with a speed system so the player could run faster, considering it takes until like lvl 37 to get a mount for an ACTUALLY POWERFUL PAL. All the pal mounts at the level 20's are available for using Pals that are bad for your main team since they're weak and underwhelming in combat. And running in this game without a mount is so slow that its just awful. Thats just how I feel about it.

Bugs, glitches and crashes roam around this game like wildfire. They make the experience much worse, so please be ready for them. Ik a lot of people say this but I don't think the brokenness of this game is still emphasized enough, considering how much it really ruined my experience of the game. Falling through the map, crashes, pals stuck in trees, pals stuck in buildings, its endless. And Ik peoples excuse for it will be that this is an early access game, but that just doesn't justify releasing such a badly broken product in my opinion.

Soundtrack is not great. Very generic boring songs, but I can get past that since it doesn't really matter too much for this style of game.

The building. The BUILDING. What happened here?! The building is so terrible man. Idk how on earth they managed to make it as bad as it is honestly, and Any new players gotta see it for themselves. It feels so clunky and innaccurate, like, again, a worse version of fortnite. 

Moving even more quick here, the food system is pretty bad. Just make a bunch of berries and cook em and you're good, no diverse food selection needed. But 9 times out of ten your pals won't even eat any food set for them since their either too big and glitch inside the walls of the base, or they just don't feel like it, so they start starving anyway. That gets very annoying as well, and that problem never stopped for me throughout my almost 50 hours of playtime in this game.

Theres so much more I can say but MAN. This is Palworld. I wish the best for this game and I really hope it improves. As a matter of fact, some stuff I would love to see from it includes,

- Randomized Map seeds
- Bringing your single player pals into online multiplayer for battles and trading.
- Wonder trade system, similar to Pokemons.
- More fleshed out environment in maps and less generic dialogue for npc's.
- Lots more Pals
- Fixed building system
- Speed stat
- Less berries around the map to balance out the food system
- MORE WAYS TO GAIN GOOD AMOUNTS OF XP, PLEASE!
- Dungeon Map (Dungeons suck to walk through)

And so much more.

That is my review for Palworld. Also for the record, I got almost 50 hours out this strictly due to the Pals themselves. I really like their designs and battle mechanics. So I made the goal to try and catch all of them. All of the issues I mentioned made this game absolutely horrible to play through for me, But I still managed to get around 90% of all the Pals. I also played this game in multiplayer with people, so that's another thing to mention. I'm likely done with this game for a long time until more updates come out.

That is all.

[b]Rating:[/b] âââââ - Great
[b]Time Played:[/b] 34 hours (Level 35 - Approx 330 Pals Caught)
[b]Difficulty:[/b] Normal (with XP and Night Time Modification)
[b]Server Type:[/b] Dedicated Server with Friends

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
	- Mix of creature collecting, base building, and survival elements.
	- Taming a variety of Pals offers endless possibilities for base building and navigating through the world.
	- Game is often touted as 'Pokemon with guns'. Better similarity is 'Ark Survival with Pokemon'.

[b]Story\Dialogue:[/b]
	- Story Non-existent with minor lore through notes and environment.
	- Dialogue is witty and often humorous, adding depth to the narrative experience.
	- Palworld has a satirical undertone with guns, physical abuse, sweatshop factories, butchering and exhausting Pals for progression.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
	- Vibrant, charming clean style bringing the world of Palworld to life. 
	- Well-designed environments and character models.
	- Many Palworld Pals are clear derivatives of Pokemon which can be immersion breaking to some Pokemon fans.

[b]Before you Play:[/b]
	- Recommend playing this game with friends in a guild to make the world feel a little less lonely. The game is still enjoyable solo however.
	- You need to enjoy the 3 elements of creature collecting, base building\crafting and survival. If you don't, you won't progress far in the game. Co-op doesn't alleviate this.
	- Plan the best locations for 2 bases before building. The first for Main base and the second for a Ore Mining base.
	- Game focuses on catching multiple of the same Pal's to get XP.
	- Progression slows to a crawl at Level 25. Focus on catching 10 of the same Pals each to maximise XP. Alternatively: modification of XP gain to x2 at Level 25 and x3 at Level 35 is suggested.  (Max Level is 50)
	- Night time can slow the game down to a crawl. Best to half the night time or get to Level 22 to get a hip lantern.

This is a weak recommend* ** ***, with asterisks.

* The overall quality is good for an early access game. There are glitches and here and there but it is hopeful they will be patched and improved later
** I don't find a particular "great" part of the game, but the design is good enough to keep my interest. However, I only say this based on this game alone, without "context". If with the context of comparing with other certain games, my assessment for this game would range wildly from 10/10 to 0/10 from different aspects.
*** Might change later when I progress more or when the game gets more updates

This game was fun for a while, but the appeal wears off fairly quick. The combat system is very simple and boring. I have made it to level 43 and really have no urge to finish the game at this point. It's the same thing over and over again, and there really isn't any type of reward when you finish a boss fight or something. (the boss fights don't even feel like an accomplishment) (Also seems to get really "grindy" around level 40 as well.)

The appeal at the beginning is discovering all of the different types of pals and what they can do. When you realize they're all pretty much the same, except visually, you start to question why you are even playing the game still.

I think anyone could get a solid 15-20 hours of fun from this game, but the fun drops off dramatically at some point due to the fact that there is really nothing to do; the world does not feel dynamic. Sure the pals are cute but that's about all this game has going for it after 30 or 40 hours of play time. I would still recommend it somewhat because I think there are people out there that this game will be perfect for and that it will entertain them for an amount of time that is worth the price.

first time i seen anything for this game i assumed it was just a pokemon style mod for a game, then i seen some people playing it and learned otherwise, so gave it a go and it turned out to be better then expected, but not without major areas needing improvement.

visuals are nothing amazing, just a technical pass, but yea pokemon style so well it not gong for cutting edge visuals anyways by design, so yea, just a pass, can be forgiven, nothing amazing to be seen. 5/10 visuals.

audio, technical pass, nothing amazing, but annoying on the combat music kicking in all the time. 5/10 audio, should be better, but early access, will wait and see.

AI is dumb as rocks, technical pass for what it needs to do since its just a pokemon style game, but it could do much better if the AI had half a brain, 5/10 as is, again will wait and see.

Gameplay concept is good, but not well implemented as of yet, it has some fun elements, but get tied in with poor implementation or lack on content as things progress, balancing issues, progression issues, repetition, building issues, basically the longer you play the more obvious the issues become, its a game that is clearly not finished in development = a good thing as this means the devs arent treating is a finished game or that = a instant thumbs down.

they have made a stack on $$$, so they have no excuse at this point to go the full mile, the full distance to make this game good, so for now its thumbs up as its a good start, but it better keep going and i expect to see some major content drops and changes by June 2024, otherwise the dev has no excuse, zero, none, zip, they got more money then they could dream to get and unless Nintendo drags them into court, they can afford to get people working on this game full time and get the content out, since base, core game and functionality is already there.

Far as AI bs used to dev the game? havent seen any evidence, just claims this far, plus AI isnt a fullstop label and most people who bitch about it, have no idea what they are talking about, have no clue how it works, their entire education is a youtube vid by a idiot and at the end of the day it doesnt matter long as copyright isnt infringed and it hasnt been AI or otherwise as this game currently stands, so who cares, most the Pokemon copy/paste claims are a bogus and depend on stupidity to believe it or fanboyism to drive it. Nintendo is a absolute starved beast when it senses the slightest opportunity for a legal case, yet they have done zip... After all the same case could be made against them, if per say we imagined they won a legal action, others now would have a case against Nintendo, as Pokemon are hardly original to Nintendo. virtually every game would come under scrutiny, so no surprise Nintendo are not doing anything, because the Pals are not direct overlaps, eg direct infringement.

its also Nintendos fault for not giving gamers what they want, much like how the indie seen keeps growing for the same reason AAA just dont care to deliver the goods, when someone else does they will make $$$, its not rocket science, so i hope to see more of it, especially as AI make it more viable for people who lack technical skills, but have all creative skills to make a good game.

then recently the game developers responded to the drop in players after a few weeks. and let me clarify this, they are legends.
their response was if you play palworld we love you, if you don't anymore we also love you no hard feelings. go play more games more genres more types of games ect ect aka, they are not salty about players playing different games.

It's like craftopia, ARK, and pokemon mixed together. 3rd person, over the shoulder, open world, survival/crafting, base building with loads of fast travel points in the beginning area and less as the areas get more difficult. You can have a total of 3 bases with pal workers (I personally think there should be more). You have a pal box with 16 "boxes" with 30 slots which sounds like a lot of space but this game gives you more exp for catching pals and for those of us who like to get the best stuff quick that space gets used up quick. You can also tier up pals by condensing them amount of pals needed growing (4, 16, 32, 64) making it to where you need 116 of the same pal to get a max tier pal which is a grind of itself and taking up 116 slots out of your 480 slots which is almost 1/4th of your palbox. The game is loads of fun with friends or even by yourself. I have had loads of fun with the game and it still has some early game bugs like if you are fighting a boss sometimes they will get launched into the sky and be right back at their spawn location sometimes with full health but thats if they come back from the stratosphere. Pals get stuck on literally everything which causes them to starve if you are not paying attention to them cause you're grinding out levels or a new saddle. You have no actual control over any storage organization when it comes to your pals and it seems like they just put stuff wherever making it difficult to keep your storage consolidated. You cant build on water so dont make my mistake and build your main base at a pond with a waterfall (did it cause I liked the view and thought the palbox had more base building space then what it did). Would be nice to have more base room as well. Overall though for it being a new game and all I give it a 3.5/5.

This is coming from someone who was on gamepass with this game and fired it up because it was free.

I 50'd a character... then had it crash on start of the game repeatedly and thought the save was borked and started and 50'd another character.  The crashes on gamepass were so bad I switched to Steam.  This is a much more solid and stable version, as there have been no crashes yet and gamepass was crashing for me multiple times on start of game, then it would either freeze or crash every 20 minutes or so.

This game is Ark, instead of Dino's you have other creatures that can help you around your base, doing your work for you (usually much better than you could).  I expected to not enjoy the game but was pleasantly surprised.  I don't believe this game is prefect, it's far from it.  It's not going to blow you away with amazing graphics, the AI needs work and the game will drag for you in the 30s and 40's.  It may get sued, it may not be the most original game out there, but it's surprisingly fun.

If you enjoy spending 5 minutes fighting something and trading out your pal's trying to keep them with agro while you whittle it down with your crossbow, dodging attacks and then cheering when you finally have the capture succeed, this is your game.  If you enjoy spending 2 hours making your base reach to the sky to see if it can be done, this is your game.  If you enjoy finally beating and capturing a max level world boss, powering it up and then building a team of equally unfair pals, then marching them into a huge boss fight with the timer ticking and your not sure you have the damage to beat it but you go all in anyways and spend a ton of resources nuking it with mines, rockets and grenades, this is your game.

"Interesting", but not "GREAT"

This game is a mash-up of a lot of other well loved things.

It's good in this sense, because you see so many things you like coming together, and to see HOW.
From Ark, to Conan Exiles, to Pokemon. There are even Dark Souls influences and more!

For anyone who plays a lot of games, it's well worth exploring for that reason alone.

The down side however, is that it tries so many things, it'll inevitably be weaker than the originals. You have to allocate your effort points somewhere, and this game did it on "merging genres".

Which means, its down sides include:
- no real automation
- not as "pretty" as satisfactory or ark
- the building mechanics are very basic, and incredibly restricted (area size). They don't even come close to measuring up to Valheim, or ark
- the breeding mechanics cost a lot, and don't get you much (not infinitely scaling like ark)
- the combat is too easy, and bosses fall absolutely flat compared to Dark Souls. (these are more time trial bullet sponges)

Should you just play those other games instead? No
Because this is a very interesting thought project.

And it's hilarious just to see what memes they manage to pull off with JUST "Pokemon" and "GUN!"
Hell, just getting in to a fistfight with a terrified pokemon to catch your first is barrels of laughs.

Overall, it feels more like a play-and-put-down kind of game. 
But still worth it to see the magic.

** New update** Changed back to recommend after factoring in the complete lack of normal greedy tactics by most other gaming companies. This game is well worth the 30 bucks.

**Update** After much more time in game the bugs are becoming a much bigger problem. There is no end game. So, after a week or so you will hit a wall...and then the bugs just take any motivation out of the game. The breeding pen -- the core part of the game -- is the biggest bug-filled pos! Soooo many issues with it. So, I am changing to not recommend at this point until bugs are fixed and more content delivered. Potential is there, but we'll see.

If you like ARK you will love this game. I am really enjoying it, and I am trying to avoid watching too many videos that spoil the fun, but I can already tell I am looking forward to restarting -- mainly for better base locations. The world is huge and the modes of travel make it fun and interesting. the flying mounts are nice but dont ruin the travel as you are stamina dependent. Well worth the $30!

You gotta play this game blind.

Making the effort to avoid as much info on this game as possible has got to be the best decision I could have made.

I haven't felt such wonder and awe playing a game since gens red/blue, crystal, and ruby/saphire.

This one time, I wandered too far from my camp, and forgot my torch. As night fell while I wandered around some old ruins, I can still vividly remember the shock and awe I felt when a shrill cry heralding fell wings, lit ablaze, icy blue and haunting, bore down on me. The panic I felt as I scrambled to switch to my crossbow and throw out one of my pals, only to realize that I'm almost 10 levels under. The exhilaration as I'm down to my last pal, out of arrows, and I just barely manage to catch it with 4 balls to spare from the 60ish i started with.

I remember the absolute hype I felt when I stumbled upon katress for the first time. The feeling I had when I stumbled upon wixen for the first time can only be described as "seeing the yu-gi-oh duel city duel disk sitting on display across the aisle at toys r us"

My most recent highlight memory from this game was when I was out catching a couple box worths of wixen, and as I made my way along the coast next to their spawn point, I saw what this majestic looking Phoenix soaring way up high through the air over the bay north of the lava river. Gentle sways of still, flowing red wings of absent flame. Bright, striking yellows piercing through billowing crimson plumage. Too far off for me to get a name out of it or show up in the paldeck, so I could only sit and wonder. I spent a solid 2 or 3 mins just sitting there staring at it as it gently glided by. I'd been spending about 9ish irl hours in this area hunting for wixen captures, and this was the first time i'd seen it. I continued on my way, coming back to this area regularly for more wixens. It had been a solid 3-4 irl days before I decided to take a break from this game, and I had yet to see it again.

TL:DR: 6/10 good (unfinished) game/potentially 8 or even 9 later on. little something for everyone. Easy to Hard modes with a custom setting that has more choices then a Bethesda character creation screen. Fallout 3 lovable jank levels on a LENOVO computer with intel core i7-9700 cpu, 16 GB ram. Virtual memory 38.4 GB. Intel UHD Graphics 630 Graphics Family. It's worth the money, even better if you get it on sale.
If the Devs see this: look at Azure Dreams monsters for inspiration next. U-boat is my favorite. ^.^

At lvl 41 and 184 hrs at the time of this review: 
It's been a long time since I've felt this feeling from a game. Like FANF, Undertale, Poppy Playtime, ect. had before in the past. It feels like the beginning of something big. These games gave you curiosity about the world and the people in it. It gives me the feeling that it CAN become something great, OR it can become another shit game rotting on the pile of poor decisions of the devs. It's tittering on that that knifes edge right now,  

I had a hard time getting the game to stop crashing first. I finally started to start working after I used -dx12 in the launch options section in the General settings of Palworld on steam. There are youtube videos to help with those issues, but the devs REALLY need to get that fixed so you need to jump though hoops to play. That or I have a shit computer. 
As for jank, bugs, and breaks: nothing too game breaking. In the beginning caves/dungeons I gotten above the map by using the grapple hook in the center of the big open areas. You can short range teleport pals into walls if you fail to catch em since they come out up and to the right of where you threw your sphere. A list of other things. Annoying sure, but like I said above it has jank levels of Fallout 3. Annoyingly lovable jank you can tell your friends about and have a good laugh. Now with the computer specks I listed above I can run Palworld on low graphics somewhat comfortably while running youtube and a web browser (not recommended to run anything at he same time as Palworld). Palworld is a CPU hog to be sure for me at least. If the the Pal jank becomes too much then just slaughter the offending pal to teach the game a lesson.

Now Palworld is made for the long range attacker. Sure you can make a bat or a spear, your bread & butter is going to be your long range stuff/pals which attack mostly with mid to long range attacks. No claws or biting. Guns take a bit to get too. Game play is fine/fun. Building is fun but base space is limited, but you can have multiple bases. (everything deteriorates outside of the base till it breaks). The world is enjoyable, varied, and memorable enough to be talk to someone else about it and have them understand where you are talking about.  Dungeons aren't that varied in shape or Pals, but make up for it in looks. A hot area will look different from a starting area dungeon. OH you can slide in the game by pressing the crouch button while running. 

Catch over killi is the name of the game in Palworld. You get more EXP for catching rather than killing. Also get the items when you catch them as well. Pal spheres disappear after use, so if you miss you waste a sphere. Pals themselves are helpful (when not bugging or being difficult) and your workforce. Unless to like the F key on your keyboard a little too much and wish to wear it out, Pals are your to to for base building, resource gathering, food growing and manufacturing. As well as for protection, riding, and gliding. Early levels means you can't have guns, BUT you can build guns for your PALs as a unlock-able limited PAL move. Or (with other unlock-able moves)  turn your PAL in to the weapon like a grenade, grenade launcher, flamethrower, ect. They are upgrade-able. Some PALs are just suited to base work. It's possible to breed pals/find eggs and get PALs you haven't seen or too high of level to catch at the time. 

Story: No story per say. You're on a "deserted" cluster of islands with ancient civilization traces all over. Deal with it by force.  There are journals to find, but that's it. The NPCs mostly look alike, with no in depth personality or looks. About one or two lines of dialog for each.  One friendly small settlement with 6 or 7 people in it. A weak part of the game. I would like to see some personality given to these NPCs in the updates. Maybe a quest or two. Different clothes and faces too. 

I've gone over what I thought was important to talk about, and will add more if I remember/new stuff changes the game drastically. It's a good 6 almost 7 out of 10 game and I feel worth your time and money. Even in it's current early access state. Also more and more mods are being made if you're into that. I could see this turned into an manga or anime at some point. Hope this was worth the read and thank you for your time.

*edit over the 100hr threshold*

So I reached max level, explored everything and just have the final 2 bosses left, but I think that's it for me until the next major content update. A lot has been said about the good that this game has to offer (its a great game!) but I want to mention the stuff that I think is genuinely an issue.

There are problems with balancing that become apparent later, XP doesn't scale enough as you level up (single player) so you end up grinding for hours to get nowhere. Then the bosses require different teams of pals to beat, so you end up grinding again to level your pals up. The only way to make this actually work without getting extremely tedious is to adjust the XP level rate in your world options once you hit level 30, but its impossible to guess what the correct rate would be and having access to this multiplier is tempting to just max it out. 

My 2nd issue is with bosses always getting agro on the player. No matter how much damage your pals are doing, the boss will always target the player every 2nd or 3rd strike. You cannot possibly get enough health or firepower to counter this so you have to run and dodge constantly but your stamina bar depletes really fast. If you get too far away you can't monitor your pals health so boss fights are super tiring to do.

3rd problem is large pals, they can't be used in dungeons or caves since they get stuck, they're useless against bosses because they get stuck and dont attack. The strongest pals are freaking huge (looking at you jormuntide) but not usable because they get stuck. Flying pals constantly fly out of your base and get stuck and die or somehow fly inside rocks and get stuck in there. Bulky pals get stuck in trees, builds and items and die. Basically you have to keep only small pals on your base unless you want to spend all your time babysitting them but even then, the humanoid ones somehow get trapped inside rocks too. small pals are the least effort to manage but most useless skills. 

4th The building is pretty bad, it's extremely basic and very clunky. Pals can't navigate through it well and it doesn't snap to terrain well either.

Final issue I have, the last two zones (desert and snow) are really bare and boring, there's very little incentive to explore and continue once you reach level 40 as these areas are very clearly unfinished. I think once you've cleared the fire zone the rest is worth waiting on for the team to update and polish. 

In general though this is still a good game and has scope for many more updates and continuity of play, it has potential to be a long running game if the developers wish to maintain it. I'd love to see classes with player skills as there are 3 different starting zones this should be possible. More equipment and variety of weapons and tools. More villages or more developed ones and more interesting NPC's would be great, NPC quests and challenges would be welcome as well. I look forward to seeing more pals and new island in future updates :) It's a great game and I will definitely return.

This game has so many features we have been begging a certain creature-based large corporation with a rat mascot for, for years! While the comparisons between that game series and this one are fair; it is important to note that they really are NOT the same game. There are vast game play differences. Interesting catching/breeding mechanics, beautiful landscapes, well designed leveling system, and decent survival mechanics all combine to make this a really solid game.

It is still early access. There are going to be lots of bugs, so please be patient. I've run into my fair share (and my partner can't really play in on her Linux PC). But it is worth it and I cannot wait for more updates and bug fixes!

The world is huge and very well designed. The scope is quality. The guns, armor, and travel modes are great. Exploration is fun. Combat is cool. 

 It would be better without the Pals.  

The crafting tables become obsolete once you advance tech. The pals are glitchy. Pal response time in combat is slow. For it to be the "selling point" of the game Pals should engage when spawned not after multiple attempts. Enemies fall through the world. Bosses get killed by humanoid type NPCs through the ground resulting in respawn timers. 


Building is trash. A single shrub on the ground hinders snap points.  After the "Hype" this game is just another spot occupying the library that won't be accessed even with future patching.

First Impressions:
For an Early Access game, it is already well fleshed out. I am impressed with the number of systems in this game. Creature capture, base building, weather, day-night cycle, crafting, climbing, shooting... Many games struggle to implement half of these. So far (about an hour in) the game feels the right amount of scary and chill. Night time brings cold and some Pals that will one-shot you. But it is also chill enough that you have time to explore, catch Pals, and build a base without having to micro-manage every second. I am definitely looking forward to seeing what all this game has to offer.

(Edit) 115 hrs in:
Not going to spend a lot of time here as the game is wildly popular and no one will see this review anyways. This game is pretty amazing. Honestly, the marketing/buzz did it a bit of disservice. There is surprising depth to this game. Many times I encountered something and thought "wow, some thought went into this"; the breeding system, the type advantages, and team composition to name a few. You could spend an entire 2 hour session doing just one of these: upgrading your base, raiding dungeons, hatch and breed pals, prepping for and fighting a boss. Each of these activities has its own pace and feel. It is nice to be able to change pace in an open world survival game.

Are there some bugs? Yes, mostly minor things from my experience. 
Could the NPC navigation use some work? Yes, sometime npc's will get caught on walls or rocks.
Could base  building/defending use tweaks? Yes.
Does any of this make the game not fun? No, it is a blast and deserves all the hype.

It's Pokemon with guns and Fortnite!

Overall Score: 8/10

Pros:
+ Cute Pokem- I mean Pals
+ Great Pal animations
+ Great customization, although I want more depth like making face type and beard separate.
+ Great graphics, even at low settings
+ Great world and atmosphere
+ Ok UI
+ Ok combat system
+ Ok soundtrack
+ Ok building mechanics

Cons:
- Assigning Pals can be clunky
- Pals pathfinding
- WANTED mechanic being too basic
- Optimization issues: FPS drop in certain areas
- Some bugs and glitches (from other people. I haven't encountered those so far)
- Capture rate. IDK if the Lifmunk effigy bug is true or not
- A bit grindy (given that this is survival game), although you can tweak and customize difficulty and exp rate.

Things IDC about:
- Public multiplayer. I think this game is not designed for that. It is designed for single-player and co-op experience
- Story. Do we need some?
- "Pokemon ripoff." Like c'mon. Really?
- "Ark ripoff." Like c'mon again. Really?
- "Zelda ripoff." *sigh* no!
- "AI art and asset flip." Hypocrite! ik yall using ChatGPT in your homeworks or resume or coding or whatnot! And this has been debunked lmao
- Slavery and animal abuse. It's player's choice afterall. You can enslave them or not. It's a free country. You do what you want.

It definitely has similarities to Pokemon, but i believe that there are always gonna be games that are similar to another game. I genuinely believe that it has enough differences to be it's own standalone game even if it did take inspiration from some of the Pokemon available.

Just finished with all bosses and paldeck complete. Solid start to the game. Clearly still early access. If you want a full fledged game, this is not for you. While it has some jank, as to be expected, it is surprisingly polished in many aspects. However, the AI is what is REALLY lacking here. Whether it's pals freezing at your base and starving while you're away. Or, your in a boss fight and your pal gets stuck inside a pillar (looking at Faleris specifically). There are many things I hope they fix and implement over time, such as improved building, but overall I really enjoyed my experience. As someone who loved other games like ARK this feels like a spiritual successor in a much more stable bag.

Few things to keep in mind:
1. It's a beta from an indie studio. Keep that in mind while playing, there are spots in the map where you can fall through. I recommend playing on easy or enabling keep items on death just in case of this issue.
2. It's a mix of ARK and Pokemon. Honestly, it's well done, and the multiplayer works well - Highly recommend.
good gameplay loop and a nice world to explore, I definitely would like there to be more to the game but it just went into early access and the road map looks quite promising.

Still in the beginning hours at the time of writing. So here are my biggest PROS & CONS

PRO
. Pokemon with guns description is apt despite the core gameplay loop owing more to titles like ARK. Letting the player get involved in the thick of battles is not only great; but makes it feel like the title Pokemon should have evolved in to by now.
. The pals automate alot of the tedium around the crafting survival genre, keeping micromanagement to a minimum & letting you do what you really want to. Explore & capture pals.
. Like grand strategy, crafting survival titles usually bore me at some point, here though it's addictive. Thanks not only to automation from the pals, but also handles progression. You're given a to do list of base upgrades to accomplish & once done, bam you can unlock more research for further upgrades & better equipment.
. Takes the darker elements of it's universe & does what Pokemon refuses to do; embrace them! Kill & eat pals. enslave humans, work your pals like they're in a Chinese sweatshop & the pal Lovander exists in lore & game as blatant (parody) horny waifu bait!

CON
. The pals look like they don't belong in the game's world. Same problem as Sonic Frontiers. The world looks photorealistic while pals & humans are animesque. So there's this jarring clash of artstyles.
. The core crafting gameplay is copy & pasted from the devs prior, & still in early access, game Craftopia. Which itself was basically Breath of the Wild crossed with ARK.
. Bugs & glitches are still fairly common & mar the experience. During the first syndicate raid on my base, one thug didn't even reach it because his foot got caught on a bridge. Then after getting dislodged he kept hovering in the air. This may be in early access but it is very stable so when these happen it can be annoying.

Overall I'm glad I got it. The game kicks ass & can only get better as updates are released.

For me this game is like a mix of Conan Exiles, Grounded and PokÃ©mon - in both positive and negative ways.

Building needs still a lot of work (like you should be able to place foundations on top of another and there should be more variety in pieces (triangular foundation, please)). Also path-finding of pals needs fixing (they get stuck or drop through the floors in base quite often).

Still ... this game has a lot to boast about and if gaming system is not that innovative on it's own, it's definitely a successful mix from others. For me it keeps interesting even after playing quite some time.

No longer playing it but definitely loved every second of it. 
This game requires you to significantly grind your way, which is kind of annoying but still keeps it challenging; 
 I'm particularly impressed by the dev story and how they managed to put up this masterpiece with only a small crew of students and some more experienced devs. The experience of leveling up your base, getting loots and fighting bosses is surprisingly satisfying, if feels like you don't need the game to tell you how to play, because you're always entertained and focused on your next goal, in fact, this is what makes it different from other games. You can do whatever you want, however you want and still reach your goals. Best thing about this game is also the fact that you will most definitely have fun whether playing single or multiplayer mode. Easily my favorite open world survival / crafting game

The game in its current state is riddled with game breaking bugs. It is quite literally unplayable at times. My experience has been on a dedicated server so if you're planning on playing with friends on a dedicated server, expect the worst and hope for the best. I would assume playing the game solo, locally on your own machine would work just fine. But there are constant bugs such as: not being able to swap to a weapon, falling through the ground, rubber banding back into enemy skills, pals not respecting fixed assignments and just doing whatever, entire secondary bases freezing with no production if you're at a different base or out exploring the world, pals getting stuck when pathing which leaves them starving and debuffed. The list goes on, but you get the idea. It's hard to know how many of these issues are rooted in the hosted server specifically versus in the game itself. But given that it just released and their warning about bugs in dedicated servers, I suspect it's the latter.

I cannot recommend the game for multiplayer in its current state. I would say just follow along with development and if they squash a lot of bugs then try it out later! The concept is rock solid and the gameplay is fun (when it works). I do like the game and plan to revisit it in the far future assuming the devs stick with development and make the game playable in a multiplayer capacity.

Verily, let me regale thee with words of praise for the prodigious marvel known as Palworld, a veritable tapestry woven with strands of joy and mirth. I have ventured into realms both real and fantastical, yet none hath captured my spirit as Palworld hath done.

From the moment mine eyes beheld its radiant landscapes, adorned with creatures of whimsy and charm, my soul was enraptured. Yon creatures, companions of feather and fur, doth frolic and gambol in fields of verdant splendor, invoking a sense of wonder that doth stir the depths of one's being.

The tapestry of gameplay, intricately woven with threads of adventure and camaraderie, doth beckon the weary traveler to embark upon a grand odyssey. In Palworld, one doth not merely play, but partake in a symphony of creation and exploration, where each encounter unfolds a tale of friendship and loyalty.

Oh, how my heart doth swell with delight at the sight of these creatures, loyal companions in the face of adversity! From the humblest of beginnings to the loftiest of heights, they stand by our side, steadfast and true, a testament to the bonds forged in the crucible of adventure.

Yet, it is not merely the companionship that doth captivate the soul, but the myriad wonders that abound within Palworld's embrace. From the bustling markets teeming with life to the tranquil beauty of the countryside, every corner reveals a new facet of this wondrous realm.

And lo, let us not forget the trials that await the intrepid adventurer, for in the crucible of challenge doth one's mettle truly shine. From perilous dungeons to towering citadels, each trial is but a testament to the indomitable spirit that resides within us all.

Let it be known far and wide that Palworld is not merely a game, but an experience unlike any other. A symphony of sights and sounds, woven together with the threads of imagination and wonder. I offer my benediction upon this masterpiece, and pray that all who venture forth may find solace and joy in its embrace.

Oh, gracious Creator of realms unseen,
We beseech thee, hear our prayer serene.
For Palworld, a land of wonder untold,
Where creatures roam and mysteries unfold.

Bless this world with thy guiding light,
Where friendships bloom and spirits take flight.
Grant us courage to face each trial and test,
And wisdom to journey at our very best.

May the bond between us and our companions dear,
Grow ever stronger, year by year.
In Palworld's embrace, may joy abound,
And in its beauty, may love be found.

Guide us, O divine, through valleys and hills,
Granting us strength to conquer our ills.
In Palworld's embrace, may we find delight,
As we wander its realms from morning to night.

So let us cherish this world so fair,
With gratitude, love, and utmost care.
In Palworld's embrace, may our spirits soar,
Now and forevermore. Amen.

This game...ahh, so good. I am going to tell you that you can play this game several ways. I am currently playing the game in a world of wonder. I am not power leveling, just playing for several hours and in that time, hit goals, and discover something new. Today I just used my crafted saddle on my Nightwing and soared around my base island. Along the way, unlocked chests. I also utilized my Average Feed Bag and was able to automatically feed my pet and myself two types of crafted food. I also crafted buff items that help activities in the base. 
     I love this game. Its like a vacation for me. No need to get a whizbang to be the best in five minutes guide. Just play, enjoy, battle, and level up. I love my base, and the ability to craft things within it. I love having my pets all doing things to help out. I think this game is worth buying and trying out. I play solo. Down the road I will go to a public server game and play with others. Even though this game is early access, I havent had a crash or experienced gamebreaking bugs. It got a good amount of polish on it now.

[h1]A game that can actually run on common GPUs[/h1]

So far I'm really enjoying this game, even with the bugs for an early access game. This is a dev team worth it's weight in gold for there open responses to controversy, and their explanation of the intention behind an early access release.

I despise games that only target new GPUs to run them leaving a minute amount of people that can actually play it, then having the balls to charge $110. As much as many want to believe that Palworld is a ripoff of Pokemon or steals UI elements from Ark or Zelda, word of advice? grow a pair. Palworld is inspired by the best aspects of others games because news flash, they're good ideas. Creativity has given life to this game through the assistance of AI (it's an efficient tool that expedites production).

Overall I'm enjoying this game, fairly similar to Ark grinding for resources, with the help of pals to speed up the process. Definitely some mechanics need altering for flying creatures stamina and speed wise.

Palworld is the famous recent and very viral games that play like a bit like ark survival but with creature very similar to pokÃ©mon , there is not a lot's of new ideas here but the way the game combine ideas and mechanism from other known game into a single and very approachable package is very impressive.

monsters collection , base building , explorations , crafting , boss fightings , this game is as much busy then any of your typical open world game.

all of the different monsters you collect fill different roles , some farms , some can help you crafting , smelting Iron , cutting wood or gathering rocks.

the game itself is fun and I've already spent enough time in it to consider it was worth the purchase.

yet I'd say one warning is that in it's current form the game is a bit unstable , I've played it on both my PC desktop and the steam deck and sometime even with the steam deck the game crashed a few times.
from what I see , I think it's a memory issue since the game eat a lot's of ram and the usage just slowly ramp up as you play until the game just give up.

if you want to get this to exclusively play on the steamdeck I'd recommend waiting to see if things get refined and optimised for it.
