Kind of feels like all you do is visit copy/ pasted locations and farm a tedious skill tree, bland amalgamation of other more imaginative games; released early only to likely be unfinished forever. Developers abandoned their last project and this is a great distraction from that. The involuntary servitude is funny and creative though. For whatever that's worth.

What is it with small game companies with small budgets making games that are better than like 90% of triple A titles created by big name companies with massive budgets? Considering this is early access, I eagerly await future additions to the game with more funding behind it. Now, all that being said, as great as this game is, it definitely suffers in some ways. In my 42 hours of playing the game, I have experienced a few bugs, but not many and nothing game breaking. For instance, one time I accidentally clipped through the wall because i got on my mount when I was too close to said wall. Another time I clipped through the floor when fighting a dungeon boss, causing me to have to re-do the dungeon, which was a bit annoying but not a huge deal. Speaking of dungeons, I think that they need to be fleshed out a bit more. I haven't done every single dungeon in the game, but the ones I have done were kind of the same thing over and over. There are different tunnels that lead away from the main boss, but they only yield basic chests of mediocre items, and I find myself skipping them and going straight for the boss. Maybe there should be more incentive to make the player want to explore the depths of every tunnel and pathway. And lastly, the AI definitely could use some work. There have been many times the Syndicate thugs just kind of stand there when they should be fighting you. Or during a raid, I don't feel like there is an imminent threat because they just run past me for the most part, and then my pals just obliterate them.

My final thoughts...
I think Palworld is an awesome game, especially coming from a small company with such a small budget. I am having a lot of fun playing it with my friend, and if you enjoy survival craft games, then you will enjoy this game too. But do be aware that there are some bugs here and there. One thing that I think would add to the game as a feature is procedural world generation. You could choose the default map, or your could have a randomly generated seed (or manually input your own seed). Anyways, I do look forward to what the future holds for this game, and I hope that a certain company doesn't sue them.

This game is awesome! It has similarities to Pokemon's concept but totally different in terms of game play and design. Pokemon are targeted for young audiences while this one is targeted to adults. Some of the Pals here has some resemblance to some of the Pokemon but different and unique in their own away. One example of this is Jetragon, Jetragon is clearly similar with Salamence of Pokemon and that is one of my favorite Pokemons. I love this game and spent hours playing it in both normal and custom mode. I had to reach my limit before I changed some settings and played normally until I reached Lv 43. I hit some walls which made me tweak some settings such as drop rates,exp rates, and catch rate. My goal is to enjoy and have some challenge but not to the point that I have to spent a lot of times grinding. tl;dwrite: It's Legends Arceus early access but action/fps combat, more inviting (but barren) world, no story, barely any lore, base building janky but fun except for no shared inventory, and little reason for progression after the first boss.

I should start off by saying I absolutely love survival games and base building. I have tons of these types of games and enjoy most of them. So when I saw this game and it had a mix of pet collecting and a crafting aspect I got excited, but once I got into game I realized how bland and boring it actually was. I know it's early access as well as many of the other games I play, but this was bland and boring right from the start. The movements were stiff and I found it annoying that I couldn't shealth my weapon or tool and had to leave a empty slot open. I like to have a goal to work towards, like cool armor or furniture to work towards and I personally found none of that. After about a hour and a half I realized how dull and bare bones the game was.

The map is vast, but there's nothing to look forward to finding other than pals. I wondered around trying to find something exciting but ended up finding the exit button and closing the game. I'm still really annoyed that I tried to play the game again and find some form of enjoyment but I ended up getting bored, getting up to go do something else to do. Unfortunately for me I left this game open and went afk so now I can't get a refund. Just another dull game I get to add to my list of "I'm nevet gonna play this again."

I have played this on both my account and my husband's before I bought it for myself. I wanted to hate it at first. "Pokemon with guns!" that tag line made me want to hate it, but here I am loving it more than I wanted. 

To break it down: 
Catching system: 7/10 the increasing difficulty is understandable but at times seems just ridiculous because at extra low health any ball should have at least some chance. 

Breeding: 8/10 once you can make cakes efficiently it is a wonderful system though I hated leaving the server up when I am offline so I eventually decreased the egg hatch timers. 

Crafting: 7/10  Steady at first but like all games that get progressive the materials get annoying to farm. looking at you high quality pal oil and others that have to be caught or killed to get. 

Combat: 8/10 can be repetitive but overall enjoyable

Bases: 7/10 Need better building options and mapping but overall decent. I like the option to decorate. 

My biggest issue is I want more to explore and more Pals. I think the idea is great. I would also like more dungeons that vary in levels not as dramatic but maybe in 5 lvl increments. 

Cannot wait to see what they do with the game.

Pros: 
Funnier than the other tamagotchi.

Cons:
Battle is tacky. for a game that's open world of [redacted], should've gone all in.
The gliding Pal (Galewing, that manta and hagyu) isn't usable in combat since gliding is important in battles. 
Switching pal / weapon / sphere is slow with auto-hide UI on top.
Combat on mounts is janky. so many slow casting skills you can't move during. Can't dodge roll mounted.
Pals don't feel too different, all offensive. Should've gone FFXII / DA route with 3 active with gambit + presets on top. 
If pokemon is rock-paper-scissor, then this is that in real time without much of the effectiveness.

Cons Again:
Selling gold coin loses me my money instead.
The repair cost is too high and durability is too low. Good gears require repair using items that aren't sold / auto-mined.
Crafting ammo is too slow.
Crafting pokeball equivalent is too slow even with an ore that you need a specific base to auto-mine.
All bases dont share the same inventory, therefore cases like above you'll need to carry base-focused item (ingot, sulfur). Yet the movement speed when item is full is silly slow.

"Pokemon with guns!" 

At first glance people may think this. When, really, it's more than that.
I like to think of this game as 'inspired by...' more than just ripping it off completely. 
If you're a child of the 90s you'll remember that boom in 'pokemon clones'... Digimon, Monster Rancher., etc...
This isn't any different. This just takes that idea and adds some, at times, questionable situations.

We all had those thoughts back in the early days of pocket monsters. 

"What if you could use weapons in the pokemon world?"
"Why did they never try to catch humans with pokeballs?"
"Other than chansey working at the pokemon center... why didn't the other monsters have jobs?"
"WTF DOES A POKEMON TASTE LIKE?"

This answers all those questions. Well... kinda. 

However, Even though this game looks as if it has a lot of content...  after playing it for a few hours it becomes pretty boring. Luckily, because it's still in early access this means there is a chance they'll add more content later. Also, because it's in early access it means there are a few bugs in the game. The creators of the game seem to be good at patching the issues, though.

If you like builder games, open world survival games, and poke-clones you may find this game interesting.
If not, you won't be missing anything if you pass on it.

Palworld is an excellent game for one that's still in Early Access. But don't go judging its success based entirely on player count. That's a false metric! Naturally, if Palworld were a Finished game the player base might stick around but because it is in Early Access it doesn't have that much content to begin with and players will only play until they've run out of content. It stands to reason that the player base is shrinking! This is to be expected. It's not a full game!! Don't expect the same results that you might get with a Full game! And don't go comparing Early Access games to full games! Or how is it that you can buy an early access game full-well knowing that it's in Early Access and that it's incomplete but continue to expect it to be complete as if it weren't in Early Access? ... And then judge its overall success based entirely on player out turn? Let them finish the game first before you judge it. It's no more a failure than any other early access title. Equally so, its success is also premature if you base it entirely on how many people were curious enough to try it. To me, it's a fun game but it is NOT a finished game!!

Short end: Game should not have been released this early.  The volume of bugs simply takes away from the long term play ability.  That, coupled with no end game content or story really leaves this game feeling like a copy of Pokemon meant to draw attention (successfully so) but doesn't do much to keep you entertained beyond the shock value or what you can do.

Long end: I bought this game for the giggle factor after reading the reviews and being interested in the idea of a "real world Pokemon" experience.  I enjoyed it at first, but there was so very little engagement and a massive amount of frustration with the amount of bugs there are (there are A LOT).  

It felt like I had taken on a babysitting job for my Pals.  They can not walk up the stairs you build, at all.  However, they will somehow teleport items they gather to storage containers they can't get to.  I end up having to go through all of my storage to compartmentalize everything each and every time I go to my base.  They also can't walk around certain landscapes or structures and frequently end up in trees somehow.  They also seem to have a severe case of ADHD, jumping from one task to another, regardless of whether I assign them to one or not.  Seriously, it's like watching a seven year old run around the house from one activity to the next and it's exhausting to try and get them to stay on task.  I don't even have kids, but I have a preview of what it's like now.

There's also the factor of enjoyability.  So, yea I can run around and murder Pals for loot and experience, but what else?  I can build a base to make that easier and store things to assist in the murder of these creatures.  What else?  There really isn't anything as far as I can see.  No reputation, no notable features, no engagement with the NPC's.  

There's also the moral quandary I feel when playing.  I'm literally just going around murdering creatures, enslaving them and eating them with no moral implication whatsoever.  You have so many opportunities to exert some level of dark impulse upon these creatures and I feel bad doing it, even if they are just digital beings.  I know some people would look at this and think I'm silly, but I dunno man, I'm reading some of the reviews and seeing I'm not the only one.  

Anyway, that's my feeling on the matter.  Maybe in like a year or so this game will be more worthwhile, but for now I feel like I wasted my time and money.

I like this game and the concept behind it. It's a fun play and explore new areas and catch new pals.

Few things to consider before buying:

1) The game is very buggy. Yes, the game is in early access but some of the bugs are game breaking. Pals have troubles with pathing, sometimes getting stuck on fences and just starving. Sometimes pals will suddenly teleport to the top of a house. This is very time consuming just spending time dropping pals into the box and taking them back out.

2) I haven't been everywhere in the world, with about 43% of the map explored and I've captured 85 of the 111 pals. Either not enough pals in the game or they are not spread out enough. 

These are the two most pressing issues that I see about the game at this time. Definitely worth a play through, but just be aware of the above.
A small, buggy, indie access title that has more charm and respect for your time than most AAA games.

This game is like Pokemon meets Minecraft meets Valheim. There are a few things here and there, but it is super fun and addicting! If love any of the above this game is for you! I really like that you can create your own base and the mechanics are super easy to use.

It's on the better end of the games. Was pleasantly surprised.
It's more grindy and less focused on combat, but you are able to dodge attacks, as well as i-frame them, so dodging forward through an attack is a viable option too.
There's not much to the story other than small hints you pick up from talking to npcs here and there, but it's not like there's anything hidden or grand either. They are just spoilers on whats to come.
You are given a mission to seek the towers where the bosses are. They are quite visible even from a long distance so you have the goals right from the start on where to go. Thus exploration comes in the late game, when you already have a fast if not the fastest mount avaiable.
For time spent, its:
~5% bossfighting
~5% exploration
~30% collecting pals (the game's actual levelup mechanism)
~60% base management/crafting/farming for crafting
Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade

There are some things about this game that work well but unfortunately there are so many rough areas that it's not yet worth getting, even while it is "early access".

The single biggest issue is the totally wobbly base-building. It is impossible to build consistently and on top of that the AI path-finding is so janky for the Pals that even simple stairs and fixed game-world terrain cause them to malfunction, jumping off into space, running in circles or just getting hung-up and doing nothing.

Other issues such as falling through the terrain, having your Pals disappear or having them all teleported into some group-love pileup and made comatose are also game-breakers that need to be addressed before this title is worth buying.

Hopefully they also fix the logic and balancing issues with breeding trees, i.e. crossing low-level Pals resulting in epic end-game pals which make ll subsequent boss fights a complete joke.

There is a bit of controversy in this game.

Is it a bit like ARK? Yeah. In the "survival and build" aspect, sure... but you could also argue that ARK is like The Forest. Or Rust. So the genre of "Survival Games" is kind of simplistic in that if you have a survival aspect of your game... it's going to seem familiar.

Is it a bit like Pokemon? I suppose. There's cute useful creatures that don't look like normal IRL animals, that have silly names and super powers. But if you want to argue that. Palworld is to Pokemon, as Pokemon is to DragonQuest. In that regard Digimon is to Pokemon as Palworld is to Pokemon. Anyone remember Monster Rancher? That was a thing. What about those rip off games on the phone that are literally Pokemon but instead of pokeballs they use "soul traps" or some garbage like that? What about Monster Hunter: Stories? You catch Monsters... and hatch monsters... and fight with them... and ride them... In either case- Pokemon did not INVENT the 'monster catching and fighting' genre. It just grew larger than any others. Squeaky wheel and all that. 

Is it like Breath of the Wild? Okay yeah. There's some sounds... and the open world aspect of the game that seems VERY much like BOTW. But again- BOTW did open-world right. it's also sorta like Dark Souls in that- where you can wander into an area you have no rightly business being in at the level you are and get absolutely CLAPPED. Then collecting all the effigies is kind of like the Korok seeds... but way easier. Since they glow so bright at night, if you have a flying mount you can practically see all the ones on the map!

So yes, the controversies have valid points, but there is no "New Games" anymore. Everything has practically already been done. The only thing I can say is these guys sat down one day and had a conversation about games and the basis must have been "what things about these amazing games do we hate? I hate how in Pokemon you HAVE to evolve them to make them the most powerful... why don't we make it so you DON'T have to evolve to be powerful, you just make a slurry of OTHER creatures of that particular one and inject it into that creature to make it more powerful! I HATE how in BOTW you can climb anywhere- but you're completely limited by your stamina which is garbage. Why don't we make it so you can have a setting that can make your stamina drain less- for people who would rather just be able to climb everywhere, then the try-hards can leave it at normal and struggle with the stamina, while everyone else enjoys less drain!" etc etc. in that fashion.

I for one very much enjoy all the pals, they do seem VERY similar to other things we've already seen... heck I even have one nicknamed "Totally Not Sylveon". But it doesn't bother me at all, I GREW UP with Pokemon. I was there when Gen 1 dropped. (God I'm old...) so you would think I would be upset about what others are complaining about. But I'm not. It's honestly refreshing to have a game like this... a game where us Pokemon fans thought we were getting after being teased with Arceus. But was slapped in the face when it wasn't continued like that. So YAY for these developers for understanding the need for a game like this... then added GUNS!! That was part of the game I wasn't really into, none of my Pals have the gun attachments they can have... not even I have a gun, just the crossbow at the most.

I just hope Poketpair (in their Discord) allows for the community to draw/create pals that can later be implemented into the game! The possibilities then are endless- and it would create an engagement that most people crave for games like this! Looking forward to new updates and everything moving forward with this... Pocketpair can rest assured, at the very least, they have ONE fan in me :)

I came into this game expecting to be able to shoot little monsters with a rifle. I ending up discovering the horrors of this game. As I first spawned into the world I was surprised by this game, it was quite beautiful, then I saw her. The first NPC, it was love at first sight. I went to click on her to talk to her, yet I bitch slapped her. Then she showed me her real personality, all of her boyfriends came out to kill me. It was saddening. I ran and ran to my own secluded place, and constructed my own fortress of solitude to keep that horrible lady out. I continued to build my base, collecting more and more Pals to help me with labor, to complete my ultimate goal. Several in game days passed my base was better and better, my weapons more damaging, my pals even stronger. Then I knew it was time. I marched my way back up to what I thought was my first love. I stared her dead in her eyes, and then threw my sphere at her. Her time had come, she would be mine. One. Two. Three. And just like that, in my box she would go. No more boyfriends. Just me.

Single Player, This is a very fun game. It has a very large map that is only going to get bigger, lots of cool areas to build, and a whole bunch of monsters to catch, breed, and combine to make your perfect team. I've personally had zero performance issues with this game at all.

Official Multiplayer on the other hand, is a complete waste of time. With zero anti cheat hackers run rampant. I had my name force changed to the name of a hacker so I would be running around as a decoy. Got banned, then unbanned when they realized the hacker was still on the server. Had my entire base completely destroyed while I was offline and all my items either destroyed or stolen.

As a single player game I would definitely recommend Palworld. But in its current state I cannot recommend multiplayer on official servers. I haven't tried playing on a friends server yet, but I imagine it would be fine as long as it is password protected and run on a strong machine.

The premise of this game, its essentially what us guys who played the 1st+2nd generation of pokemon games fantasied about after seeing GTA:SA. Using modern tech and real-time gameplay to become a TRUE king of the world. You can be the El Chapo of the fantasy island's, your drug? Pal-balls you capture your monster or human slaves with, slaves who do your bidding or die if you wish.

As someone who gets bored of survival games easily, the poke-Pal system really adds a layer of fun and collectability to it i feel most survival games deeply lack. I've already sunk more hours into it, having fun all the while, than i have any other survival game I've tried. I regret the purchase of all those games aswell, they got boring fast for me. Not this though!

Its VERY worth the purchase price, no MTX at all (although a skins/cosmetics DLC pack in the future i'd buy in a heartbeat to support the devs, burning all that cash on dedicated servers) and any of the current issues I've encountered thus far are all very solvable by the devs if they do their part in the future, its an early access release so i wont expect some mega-patch next week to fix anything though. 

Make sure you check and recheck the settings of your world save when playing, to customise your playstyle to suit you, many of the more obnoxious and irritating game mechanics can be reduced or removed by your whim via the world settings. Its a huge mark of personal freedom i truly appreciate. This game truly respects your time and you can attain crazy levels of efficiency in some areas with some experimentation.

I have never played a single Poke game in my life, but I truly had a blast with this game. Was a fun combo of many recent successful games/genre's in a very easy to approach/easy to learn (and colorful) package. I will say as I approached the final boss, the last 5% of the game becomes a bit of a slog (which from what I hear, is a common problem in Poke games), and a repetitive grind, but the journey getting to the end was highly enjoyable.

Pros:
[list][*]Plug n Play Action - within maybe 20 of launching the game, you're getting into the groove, learning the ropes and having fun
[*]Responsive combat controls - I often worry about cartoonish bubbly aesthetic games as they sometimes have slow response action/controlls, but not the case here. Controls are super fast and responsive
[*]Huge Map/Lots to explore
[*]If collecting cute anime buddies is your thing, you're going to have a good time.
[*]I sadly played most of my runthrough solo, but my experience with multiplayer seemed to show that that's the preferred route.
[*](Not for everyone, but) Super friendly for younger players: While there are guns, etc. There is no blood, gore, foul language etc. (for some reason the weird obsessed love dinos have a huge fuzzy heart patch over their crotch *shrug*)[/list]

Cons:
[list][*]Pal AI - Number 1 of the top 2 larger issues I had. The Pal AI is pretty... well, shitty.  Whether in a good way (enemy raids on your base simply cannot get past basic rock defensive walls until the last tier of enemies start showing up, and even then, they really can't get it done) or in a horrid way (the AI for Pals doing jobs at your base, especially while you're gone, is successful maybe 50% of the time. Or when you summon them for battle and they just bumble around watching you get thrashed for a good 15 seconds before deciding to help) this is a huge sticking issue the devs need to prioritize.
[*]End Game - Without spoilers, it becomes a game of [stop what you're doing to focus on making nothing but bullets for 10-15 mins] + [try to get your chosen Pals to level 50, but doing so kills resources within 10-15 mins] rinse and repeat. The regularity in timing of base attacks and need for food, plus a Pal AI going bonkers, causes you to have to stop what you're doing to repeat a super repetitive process of farming.[/list]

TL;DR Game was super fun, and worth the price. Had a blast over the last couple weeks playing it. End game needs serious QOL improvements to remove the offputting final grind. Fix Pal AI, and I will be back for a second playthrough by late summer!

Overall a very fun game.

Some criticism; scaling for Bosses levels 40 onwards seems exponential, also xp requirements level 30 onwards seems way too high. This can easily be resolved however by amending the world settings for xp gain.

Some of the end game items requiring a massive amount of ore to be farmed etc, this can make it a bit of a tedious gameplay loop for specific items. E.g legendary pal world heat resistant armour is 200 bars, each requiring 4 ore iirc, 800 ore total. Paired with the carry weight this requires a lot of travelling back and forth to the base.

Of course there are some bugs, but I imagine these will be fixed in time, the only disruptive bugs I have encountered is some terrain issues where I've gotten stuck and pathing issues within the base for the pals (Already being worked on by the Devs). I haven't experienced any save corruption or loading issues.

so a simple summary before a more in depth one. Is the game god? yes. would I recommend it? Already have to any and all who would listen. Is the game perfect? no, but heck its not even out of early access at the time of this review. 

I would say, this games greatest short coming, is the fact its incomplete right now. Cause the gameplay, and main loop of, capture, build, capture bigger thing, build more things, is deceptively entrancing. If you enjoy Ark or rust, youl likely enjoy this game. If you are one of those bastards that enjoys messing with people in rust or ark, give it a bit. They are looking to implement PvP in the coming months. For those saying this is a pokemon clone, keep in mind that Gamefreak has never successfully sued Digimon, nor has Dragon Quest managed to get Game freak on the hook for copying their designs. Not to mention the fact that thei've had years to nip Pal world in the bud, but decided not to. Meaning that there is not much they could do against it right now, And I doubt they can in the future, if the sales numbers are anything to go by. 

Drama aside, at the time of this review, the game is good, and has insane potential, minimal bugs for an early access title, and a bright future. even if you decide not to buy it, it recommend at least following it, cause its going places.

Is it like pokemon? Yes. 
Is it inspired from Pokemon? Yes.
Is it stealing from pokemon? NO.
Palworld is a fun game that mixes the fun aspects of catching creatures, leveling them up (as well as yourself) and battling with those same creatures (like pokemon) and the building of minecraft, and the NPC like pals of sims. 
If you want to mass collect and farm resources, you can do it, but its not a requirement. 
Plenty of different mounts (ride-able creatures) for Land, Sea and Sky.
It also allows your pals to be petted, feed directly from the player as well as emoting (more so player moral support which feels nice)
This game provides players who like to grind out items, battling strong monsters, and exploration, suitable for a majority of players. The ONLY thing I have against this game, is the clipping problems when your trying to build your base, but it is the Alpha so they might improve this in the final game. 
10/10 Game, would definitely recommend.
Also Chillet is the most adorable pal and I will die on that hill!

A fun survival monster collector, it's as if Pokemon, Genshin Impact and Ark had a child! You can summon your Pals to fight with you or ride them. You can also build a base and make them work for you! The best part is that you can do this all with your friends.

You have towers, dungeons and boss fights. Your Pals level up with you as long as you have them on your team, you can also name them and breed them, taking advantage of their special traits. You have a hella large map to explore and collect resources. as well as Lifmunk Effigies (that can enhance your capture rate as you offer them to the statue - just like in Genshin with the Anemoculi, Geoculi, etc.), and chests! You also have to fight bandits (and capture them, yes), sell Pals on the black market, release bandits from bandit camps, discover villages, and much more!

Although there are bugs and a lot of stuff to improve, it's still an Early Access and the dev already said there will be much more content to come!

It's so fun me and my friends played it and hours went by fast.
Game has no PVP, no Story. All you do is catch pals and build a base for the pals to work on. After the first few hours it's pretty much you grinding out levels for the sake of it.
Still needs some work but going in the right direction. Can't wait for full release.

The game does have its issues with stuck pals in your base, especially the tighter you build. Pals won't do their job when you're away from the base.

However, the gameplay loop is fun and addictive, combined with base building. I personally like not having to grind endlessly for a bigger base and Palworld does a good job here.

Long-term however I think this game will not motivate players in its current state. There need to be more challenges, like either more and challenging dungeons or more challenging fights (only allowed to use certain pals or don't use pals at all etc.). In the meantime, as this is Early Access, it's definitely a "what Pokemon could have been" and better. If this game gets endgame content and regular updates, this will probably be one of the best games in 2024.

Palworld is a good game. They've found a way to make a survival RPG interesting and fresh by adding elements and tweaks to the formula to make it interesting. Palworld is special to me because after years of playing pokemon and minecraft and everything in between, I had gotten bored with games entirely, and Palworld's formula got me hooked again. It is so magical to have something to look forward to outside of work again. I'm strategizing how to make my bases work, and dreaming of cool bases to build, and wanting to catch every Pal available because of how genuinely good this game was designed. Palworld makes me feel like a starry eyed kid again, and that's special to me.

Did Palworld rip off Pokemon? In a world where there is a pokemon for literally every animal imaginable (and unimaginable), a teapot pokemon, car key pokemon, and literal garbage pokemon... I guess the real world ripped off pokemon, too.

This game is surprisingly good, fun, and addictive.
Its not just "Pokemon with Guns" or "ARK Survival + Pokemon + Zelda" they have their definitions

This game is about catching Pals (Monster, pokemon or whatever).
In-order to catch Pals you need to weakened the Pal and use the Sphere to capture them.
In-order to fight the Pal you (and your Pal) need to get stronger or get a better equipment,
In-order to capture Pals better, you need a better Sphere,
In-order to get stronger and have better equipment, you need to grind (gathering resources etc)
In-order to grind easier, you can use your Pals
In-order to get a better Pal you need to explore and get stronger
When you explore, you met something new or interesting
And the loops goes on

The objective is centered around catching new Pals and fight with them and using them in your base. The sub-objective for that is very well thought and make the grind fun.

Overall, this game is overwhelmingly fun for me. I highly recommend it.

Several Hours into the game, I can see why this became quite popular.  It took some of the most enjoyable mechanics from several games and turned it into something interesting.  Truly a great open world experience.  The bugs are crawling, but instead of making the game frustrating, they give us more things to exploi... I mean experience.   

But the thing that kept me interested, was Palworld's very fast, almost zero loading times aside from initially loading the game.  No lags or sudden fps drops either.  That's coming from a base with 200 campfires...which would be enough to freeze the screen on my other games.

It also gives you a sense of morality, but then winks at you and turns its back while you do you.

I hope devs change their mind about that. It sucks to rely on RNG for passives.

A surprisingly violent creature collector game. It features so many unconventional activities, it turns into a meme. I didn't expect I'd end up playing as a poacher and a slave trader, but here we are. 

Apart from forcing adorable creatures and people into unpaid labor, there are many aspects of this game that every player can enjoy: base building, farming, exciting treasure hunting, and intense raids and boss fights. The learning curve is thoughtfully designed to ease players into the main gameplay loop without overwhelming them with complex mechanics, so they will always leave their base with a clear task in mind. The world feels consistent with regions smoothly transitioning into one another, and each region having a distinctive landmark or property that makes it unique. The gameplay area is not limited to the player's base plus a couple of fruitful locations for farming; exploration and free roaming are very rewarding, providing uncommon resources and refreshing encounters.

Every encountered creature possesses distinct traits and personality, prompting players to optimize their choices for character progress, taming and bonding with one Pal, only to replace it with a stronger version ten levels after and dispose of the one no longer needed. This game is both extremely fun and disturbing, and it sets high standards for early access releases.

How to make a grilled cheese sandwich

ingredients
4 slices of sourdough bread
2 cups of shredded cheddar cheese
5 tablespoons of butter, softened


Instructions
Spread 1 tablespoon of butter on one side of each slice of bread.
With the butter side down, top each slice of bread with about Â½ cup of cheddar.
In a skillet over medium heat, melt 1 tablespoon of butter.
Add two slices of bread, butter side down.
Cook until the bread is golden and the cheese is starting to melt, about 2 minutes.
Flip one piece of bread on top of the other and continue to cook until the cheese is melty, about 30 seconds more.
Repeat for the second sandwich, wiping the skillet clean if necessary

Update after 100%, 282 hours in:
This game is more fun than I thought possible. I can't stop playing, even after finishing the game, that desire to collect all the pals, make an awesome base or bases, even thinking about playing a nuzlocke challenge some time in the future. What a game! 
I was expecting it to just be kind of an edgy pokemon, but man has this game surprised me. There's so many cute monsters to catch, and they all have something to offer, skills, work, some you can even ride!
There's absolutely no expectation of you to mistreat the Pals, by the way, I'm doing great on hard mode and all my pals are well fed, have a nice place to sleep, even a jacuzzi to relax in.
The combat is a little clunky and in hard mode you basically have to only focus on dodging and hiding from the other pals, but it's so much fun, catching is a real challenge in this game.
All in all this is the game I've wanted since I finished a certain game's silver version in the year 2000.

Palworld provides a blend of several game mechanics into a surprisingly well executed, fun, accessible package.  There's a huge amount of content here, and the sandbox, open world nature of the game lets the player proceed pretty much at their own pace and choose the direction they take their game in.

Pros:

 - Robust single and multiplayer experience.  Co-op shines in this title.
 - Lots of different pal types
 - Large amount of base / building structures and decorations
 - Large over world map
 - World settings can be changed beyond just the difficulty level 
 - Developer is patching frequently

Cons:

 - Terrain clipping for pals and players
 - Pals in base may get stuck when trying to reach a destination.  This happens mostly when objects are built close to terrain features or right next to each other.  Pals in this condition may need to be placed back into the box and re-deployed to the base.  

Overall:

The game is in early access at the time of review and the cons (for me at least) are primarily just bugs at this point.  The basic game play offered is solid; it's clear there was a large focus on blending catch / train mechanics with base building, exploration, and crafting progression all while allowing the pals to remain the center of attention in several of these activities.  Types have unique background details and animations that add to their charm and it brings the general world to life. 

At this point it should be clear that this isn't a story driven game, so it's not going to play the same as other monster taming series.  Taken on its own, it's a fun, addicting game well worth the asking price.

Game of the year or I will eat my hat

âï¸ The Good
â¢ Palworld offers an amusingly irreverent experience that seamlessly combines PokÃ©mon-like creature collection with survival and open-world chaos.
â¢ The gameplay is intuitive, and the combat is both silly and satisfying, providing 100-plus hours of unrelenting fun.
â¢ Despite being an early access title, the game is surprisingly engaging, with intuitive survival mechanics and action-packed combat.
â¢ The cooperative efforts of Pals in automating tasks at bases add a unique and adorable dimension to gameplay.
â¢ Multiplayer mode, supporting up to 32 players, enhances the experience, making exploration and battles enjoyable with friends.
â¢ The game's humor and unexpected features, like capturing humans or giving weapons to Pals, contribute to its overall charm.



â The Bad
â¢ Some areas require excessive grinding, particularly for ore, affecting the overall flow of the game.
â¢ Capturing and battling with Pals may feel a bit weird initially, especially with the gun-wielding mechanics.
â¢ Despite the amusing designs, the Pals themselves can be perceived as "almost copyright infringement" and somewhat derivative.



â ï¸The Ugly
â¢ Technical issues and bugs, while mostly minor, are present, including rough framerates, crashes, Friendly/Enemy AI and multiplayer disconnects.
â¢ The need for manual resource grinding at bases, particularly for ore, can be a cumbersome and repetitive task, specially late in game.
â¢ While engaging, the story lacks depth, and more NPC interactions and evolutions for Pals are needed for higher-level relevance.
â¢ Enemy/Pal AI needs major work.




Overall Score:
8.5/10



Detail break down

ð® Gameplay
â¢ Intuitive gameplay with a surprising mix of creature collection, base-building, and open-world survival.
â¢ The combat is both silly and satisfying, providing over 100 hours of unrelenting fun.
â¢ Capturing and battling alongside Pals adds a unique and enjoyable dimension to the adventure.

ð Story
â¢ While lacking depth, the story involves surviving a harsh land and facing off against rival human factions.There is really nothing else to it.

ð¦¾ Mechanics
â¢ Intuitive survival mechanics with cooperative efforts of Pals automating tasks at bases. Areas like capturing, leveling up, and fighting alongside Pals contribute to the overall enjoyment. Some areas, like the constant need for ore, require excessive grinding and manual work.

ð Content/Price-point
â¢ The game offers a surprising amount of content, with an enormous map to explore and varied activities. Multiplayer mode enhances the experience, making exploration and battles enjoyable with friends.

âï¸ Balance
â¢ The game strikes a balance between creature collection, base-building, and open-world exploration. Some areas, particularly resource grinding, require retuning for a smoother gameplay experience.

Spec Breakdown

ð Graphics
â¢ I had no issues running this on my RTX 2080 Super, there were instances of glitches but that was due to the server side of things.



ð Sound
â¢ The sound design complements the game, adding to its overall appeal. The chimes IMO can get a little annoying when teleporting to and from places.
The music when fighting is the same throughout the entire game, it drove me crazy after a few hours.



ð¤ Enemy/Friendly AI
â¢ The cooperative efforts of Pals in automating tasks at bases can be a bit overbearing. They typically never stay to an assigned task for long and usually move onto other things. This became increasingly frustrating when trying to focus on specific tasks.
Also, there were instances when my pals would just sit at my base and starve to death even though there was food. This to me is the area that needs the biggest improvement.
Enemy AI typically do the same repetitive moves without any change, making interactions go stale quickly.


â±ï¸ Quality of life
â¢ There are some thign Palworld gets right, and a lot of things it got wrong. When moving items or pals within the palbox, choosing to click and drag or click and move was annoying to say the least.
With a plethora of fast travel locations, moving around the map was reletively easy.
SLAVERY WEPONS AND DETH

We made the main base until it can sustain itself then we go exploring, raid some villages, capture p*kemon, breed or butcher them, meeting new enemies and bosses, and build new bases all around to upgrade more equipments in order to survive. First off, I just want to say that I only had this game for around 2 hours, so this is just based on what I was able to experience in that time. I played this game with my friends on a private server, and honestly it's nothing special. The game is basically just a bunch of great games like Genshin Impact, ARK, and pokemon crumpled together and the product feels really unpolished. I personally don't like how the UI looks, especially that of the inventory. You can tell that the pals are just cheap knockoffs. There is no motivation in the game--at least not one I could see--that would make you want to keep playing for hours and hours. The map and especially caves are boring. The only thing it really has are pokemon imitations that you can ride and have as slaves. Overall, this game just feels pointless, boring, and unpolished. Unless you're really into anime-style games with goofy looking monsters, I don't recommend buying this game.

Palworld is good. It's funny as people joke about as a meme (which I can agree in some ways). But it's got some decent content. Picture it like a less immersive Skyrim, but Pokemon + Minecraft. It can be repetitive. But the current map is pretty large and it's fun to play with friends. I can't see it keeping longevity if they don't spice it up a little bit more. But it'll burn about a hundred hours if you're really just trying to get lost in it all. Once you figure it all out you can start to speed run it through new playthroughs. But you have plenty of content if you're playing the first time. The soundtrack is nice, and the ambient sounds is really immersive. Sometimes I forget it's winter out just from hearing the birds sing in the background.

This game will just smother you in cuteness. It REALLY gives me the same wonderful vibes I got when I first stepped into Grounded, albeit with Pokemon-ish mobs in a fantasy world, and more cuteness by far (and NO SPIDERS, for all you Grounded arachnaphobes out there...).

Game world has temperature and food-based survival, as well as trying to avoid aforementioned white fluffy Lamballs rolling over you and other obstacles which can make you die and have to run back from spawn to pick up the loot you dropped on death.

Here's the gameplay:
Make a cute little toon with serviceable customization, nothing to write home about. Wake up on the beach of this new world surrounded by Pals (cute little stuffed toy looking creatures similar to other Japanese cartoons like Pokemon and Digimon). Pick up some sticks and stones and make tools. Night time comes and you realize this brings with it new, more aggressive mobs, as well as cold temperatures which cause you to lose health over time if you don't take the precaution of making clothes, a torch or a campfire to stay warm. Realize you would be better off following instructions and building a base before attempting to venture further. Make or find your first Pal sphere thingy (the little balls you throw to catch the Pals in, I forget the name). Realize it's easier to capture the Pal if you beat the cute little bastard into submission first (but not quite to death...). Feel as guilty as I did the first time you beat one up, but quickly move past this sentiment in about 1.5 seconds of remorse before proceeding to run rampant with the sudden, overwhelming urge to collect more, ruthlessly menacing entire populations of animate stuffed toys with your stick, foaming at the mouth as you go. Plop them down at your base using your Pal Box, and have them perform all manners of menial and defensive tasks. Get up from the computer and wish you could somehow get the Pals into the real world with you to help you with dishes, laundry, vacuuming, cooking, etc. Realize this isn't going to happen, sit back down at the computer, forsake your laundry and dishes for days, watch the state of your real life home deteriorate rapidly around you at the expense of constructing a proper tidy little base full of your new best friends, a bunch of Pokemon-inspired animated stuffed toys in videogame that will never refuse a virtual hug. Die happy.

From the outset, you can reach high vantage points to look out over a breathtaking, sprawling, vivid fantasy world, but later on as you reach those places in the distance you start to wonder if they were afterthoughts neglected in favor of milking panoramic visuals for the starter zone, as higher level zones look lackluster in comparison to the point of apparent laziness, even to the point of being downright ugly in contrast. The starter zones are imaginative with winding paths, canyons and thoughtfully-arranged decorative natural scenes like waterfalls and flowerbeds, then, somehow, they utterly fail at delivering any comparable awe in the desert and snow zones, which are typically the strong suit of many other videogames.

Combat is pretty janky, with your Pals sometimes unresponsive or stuck behind something and unable to obtain a line of sight to a target, and, being a long-time PvP gamer, there's absolutely nothing about it that would lend to any sort of PvP element for the game, so hopefully Pocket Pair doesn't go wasting undue effort on attempting to make it so at any point - the focus here should be maximizing the utility of Pals, such as fixing their pathing AI and combat responsiveness, as, let's face it, the adorable Pals are what we came for.

Lastly, base-building is terribly simplistic and limiting, being some of the most basic and inflexible of the many survival sandboxes I've played. In order to place the roof you end up having to make walls to connect the eaves, which is terribly cumbersome, so base-building is certainly not the strong suit of this game.

But the Pals are adorable. Foxparks are my new spirit animal.

PS - you can play with ACTUAL real life pals (friends) in co-op.

Game is already better in early access than other AAA titles are on release, and, much like Grounded, at a quarter of the install size, though, unlike Grounded, this game isn't overly polished and leaves a lot to be desired (but the Pal animations look great).

8/10 - Say NO to real life. Say YES to Pals. Say goodbye to your friends and family, Pals are your new friends now. You "think" THEY are YOUR pets... BUT in REALITY...YOU are THEIRS!

This ended up being far more in-depth and unique of a game than I first anticipated. Survival mechanics aren't too complicated and play into the tech tree/basic game loop well. Pal gear and base building makes every pal come in handy somewhere. It's not just about the guns, there are area bosses, tower/arena bosses, dungeons, and plenty of resources/loot to be found exploring. Some pals can be ridden, especially the giant or airborne ones, or even thrown like a grenade. The base building and pal breeding combine with the tech tree to make the late game path to victory visible and crazy fun with plenty of viable options for party loadout and such. Definitely one of those always something next to do type games that is hard to turn off, even in failure. The entire experience definitely benefits from multiplayer with your real world pals too. Easy 9/10, took one off for the various bugs I'm willing to put up with but hope get fixed.

It's early access. I knew what I was getting into and I'm not going to berate this game for it but, I am going to list some faults that need to be addressed before I'll return to the game.

Bugs, specifically, one type of bug that has caused this game to stop being fun for me. One of the core pillars of the game is the base building and having your pals do jobs around the base. This is a fine idea but, whenever you move away from your base for any period of time and come back, you will find that some or even most of your pals are stuck. I have had pals stuck on top of rocks, buildings, farms, trees etc. and they stand there unable to do anything. Even (and this is the most annoying part) the flying pals WHO CAN FLY get stuck on top of things for no reason. If you are gone for long periods of time, they will eventually start to starve and get upset/sick. Micromanaging the jobs of the pals is fun. Micromanaging the bugs involved in the process is not.

Building is a travesty in this game. Compared to it's competition, this game is severely lacking in the building department. Sure, you get all the crazy interior and exterior decor you can dream of but the actual building pieces like walls, foundations and roofs are a joke. You have 3 options for style and a handful of pieces for each. No where near enough variation to make it enjoyable. Along with the lack of style, the actual process of building is infuriating. Trying to snap roofs onto buildings is a nightmare as they have exactly 1 snap point it seems and it's not the bottom of the roof but the peak of it. I found myself making the same basic home for each of my bases because it was frustrating trying to find out half way through a build that I couldn't do something due to weird building restrictions.

Boss fights and dungeons. My only complaint with the boss fights is the arenas. They're all the same. Each boss should have a unique, personalized arena to make the fight actually stand out. The little intros before each fight is a nice touch but when the arena is the exact same each time, it makes the experience less memorable. Dungeons on the other hand, are boring. I believe I read somewhere they're procedurally generated but that is not the case at all. Once you've done one, you've done them all. They're almost exactly the same each time. About the only difference is they may have a different skin on them depending on the region you're in.

As I mentioned before, I know this game is in early access and it's still being developed and I'll end up coming back to this game some time down the line and give it another shot once it has been developed a bit more. Until then though, I can not recommend it for anyone looking for a fully fleshed out experience.

The game gets very grindy toward the end, but it is fun. It is more fun in a private world with your friends online, but if you don't mind a lot of crafting in your games, you could enjoy this solo as well but be prepared to spend a lot of time crafting. 

The game's combat AI could use some improvements, a larger variety of Pals, and a fuller world. Player damage feels very low, and when you get to later levels with guns, you will spend a lot of time gathering and crafting ammunition to feel relevant in boss fights. The game world feels a bit too large if you aren't playing in a public online server with multiple clans and bases all over the map, and the creatures and discoverable items are somewhat procedurally generated, so there is a lot of empty traveling around the map while you unlock fast travel points. In your camp, you can direct your Pals to do tasks but they often forget or get stuck on terrain or fall off of cliffs, so that can be frustrating constantly managing that.

The story is also paper thin, and some nonsense.

The devs have been fixing bugs during EA, so I will believe that they will continue to listen to the fans and make improvements and bug fixes, including expanding the game and hopefully dialing back on the crafting because right now it feels empty and there is way too much work involved in enjoying this game. 

Don't buy this game if you have any responsibilities for the rest of the week. It's so fun, but you will spend more than 75% of your time grinding for materials and crafting things. If you don't like crafting games or games with EXCESSIVE grinding then you will probably dislike this game.

It's almost like this game is a crafting utopia...a "Craftopia", if you will.

Incredibly fun ARK/Monster Collecter clone. Took them too long to make an awesome game like this. I was never into sandbox games like this until now, I can't put the game down. I've only played for 10.7 hours but I've already enjoyed the game so much. I'm not usually big on survival type games but I am in love with this one. It gets very addicting and is so fun to play solo or with a friend/partner. You can change the difficulty and really customize the world settings to adjust it accordingly to your game play style. I was worried that it wouldn't run well or at all on my gaming laptop as I only have 8gb of ram, however it's been running smoothly on the very low graphics (which still look great btw) and I haven't had a single crash yet, even in the more chaotic areas. Of course I've ran into some minor bugs and glitches throughout the game but that is to be expected with a game in early access and they have been able to be fixed with a simple restart. I feel like there is lots to do and that you can put a lot of hours into this game and really get your moneys worth. As someone who usually buys games on sale and is very cautious with purchases I absolutely recommend getting this game even at full price (especially if you're into Pokemon). I honestly would have been satisfied paying $60 for this game and I can't wait to see it's future development out of early access.

Almost 50 hours in to the game and still only have 50% of the map filled in. I've been a diehard fan of Pokemon and Digimon since I was a kid starting with Red, and have played every game since. Mechanics and game loops similar to Rune Factory and Monster Hunter with base building, resources, and crafting keep me playing for hours longer than I meant to. Palworld developers managed to make a game inspired by many that came before it while being unique and filled with content. You can play the game how you choose, and taking proper care of the Pals that assist you is rewarding. For a game in beta with a price of $25 they've managed to produce a massive game that holds up on its own two legs and a minigun. Looking forward to what these developers produce in the future and potential content updates. The game they've made here is so appealing and fun that I'm sure I'll sink a few hundred hours into it. More than worth the modest price tag.

I purchased this game for my wife and I after just being curious about it since launch. Finally it seemed to be the right time after having to be forced to stay home for a solid week without being able to leave the house. The night we installed it I went to bed early because I wasn't feeling well but I encouraged my wife to try it out. She came to bed 6 hours later in the early hours of the morning. When I woke up she was telling me how great it is so I launched it and tried it.
  Let me say that this game has some of the best pacing, item collection/grinding, and genuine love of discovery that I haven't felt in any other title since Elden Ring and in many ways out performs it. This game is definitely less "Pokemon with Guns" and more "Elden Ring/Tears of the Kingdom/A.R.K that also has cool capturable monsters in it". Everything is just well done and it is a blast to play alone or with friends! I can not recommend this game enough and it has become my newest obsession!

Minecraft + PokÃ©mon is an unfair comparison to Palworld. After playing for an unbroken 10 hour first session, it doesn't feel like "Minecraft + PokÃ©mon" was [i]entirely[/i] what the developer had envisioned. To me, it felt like the vision behind Palworld was to make [i]The Everything Game.[/i] A game that has a little bit of as many different genres of gaming as could be feasibly crammed into one game, Minecraft and PokÃ©mon just so happen to fall within the scope of [i]everything.[/i]

The Game includes elements of:
[list]
[*] Survival Craft
[*] Base Building
[*] City Building/Citizen Management
[*] Factory Management
[*] Open-World
[*] RPG
[*] Even some, limited FPS elements
[/list]
All of them are easily within the game's scope, aspects of the game that you will encounter through regular gameplay. It even includes elements of other game genres, such as Soulslike in the importance of defensive actions during combat, though to a lesser degree than the aforementioned aspects listed above.

Palworld could easily be a fun game for groups of almost any make, though not necessarily any size. The four player limitation seems to be a temporary one, but at least at the time of writing, it seems like the only limitation that isn't just a reflection of where the game is at in development.
Water looks weird? Still Early Access.
Animations are a little janky? Still Early Access.
Limited number of players in one world? That one may not be a reflection of Early Access, but it also may not be around for long. The game's settings allow for the creation of up to 20 guilds within one world, and I can't imagine that being a thing if there were only ever going to be four players at most, I suspect that's a temporary problem.
While the number of players in any one world may be limited to four, I believe that any group of four friends could easily find something they enjoy doing within the game; there's enough different kinds of content that each player could even branch into doing their own thing, separately, but have it all tie in well enough that it can still feel like a cooperative effort.

tldr; don't get Palworld because it's "Minecraft + X" or "PokÃ©mon + X," get Palworld because it's [i]everything.[/i] The developers continued work on the game will determine just how [i]everything[/i] the game continues to be.

Game is pretty much barely beta at this point.  Has a lot of issues with pal pathing, random clipping from getting hit by mobs that forces you under rocks or trapped under the surface of water to where you can't get out... you die from lack of stamina.  Today the game glitched on reloading and I was stuck in a "box" of ground with a yellow sun in the middle of the screen.  Attempted to respawn - lost ALL my inventory as none of the inventory was able to be recovered.  I see the X on the map, but nothing is there to pickup because it is likely clipped under the surface or high up in the clouds.  I once saw a mob get shot up in the air and it kept going up and up and up - it never came back down.  Oh... and pathing for pals in caves - yeah - HUGE problem.  There are quite a number of times where you summon your pals in combat and they do nothing - they just sit there and take damage and don't move.  That happens a lot in caves.  When you start your game and you have ANY structures built next to the PAL console, larger pals get stuck there and will never move until you move them yourself.  Annoying!  Lots of clipping with pals in structures - happens all the time.  And there is literally no way to designate priority of pals to a job.  If they have 2 skills, it can sometimes be random which skills they choose to use.  You could have transport and watering for example and have 10000 items laying about your base... your pal will do nothing until a crop place needs watering, go water that, and then do nothing for another 5 minutes till it finally realizes there are items to pick up.  It will then pick up one item, then take a break, and by this time... your crop field needs to be watered so it will go water that and leave the 9999 items still on the ground.  No real way to organize chests at all - pals will dump items randomly in chests in multiple stacks in multiple chests - even chests right next to each other!  There is zero designation for items placement or organization.  makes it hard to unload your inventory from adventuring cause you have to click each chest to deposit all your items - annoying!  Many of these issues are simply ideas that have never really been thought out properly or tested.  I could go on and on about so many other things... but you get the idea.  Not worth the money at this time - at least till they do a major update and fix a lot of these issues.

I originally bought this game expecting a joke, I come away from this game fully recommending this excellent experience.

Palworld combines elements from many popular games in ways that honestly work very well. It is an open-world survival game filled with creatures you can capture and tame to battle alongside you, with base building mechanics involving automation by having the creatures work in your base. While you might be able to make comparisons to other popular games like Pokemon and Ark, the way Palworld uses these elements is undoubtedly... Palworld. Not Pokemon, not Ark.

You may hear a lot of people say Palworld is just "Pokemon with guns". The problem I have with this criticism is that the guns actually have a place in this game, and it's executed perfectly. Normally, you as the player in these creature collect/battle games are just an accessory to the action. You don't do anything, you're just the vessel under which your party clears the game. By giving the player weapons with which to properly get involved in every part of combat, this problem is solved. You're not the accessory, you're the sixth member of the team.

While I'll readily accept that the game is clearly in very early access, there is a level of polish that shows the game is cared for by the team that develops it, with the updates the game receives showing that it is heading in a good direction. Performance and AI of worker Pals in your base could do with a major overhaul, but the game you get right now is genuinely worth the price.

It is like Pokemon but with weapons. Their are problems. Like outside of the grind to improve your gear, there is no story. And no I don't count lore scrolls. It's the laziest way to tell a story. There is also alot of bugs. And the default experiance points you get is pathetic. Crank that up or it'll be a slog in between levels. Also why make better versions of pals if you could simplely just evolve them. I guess it would make it too close to pokemon but idk. Coromon, Nexomon, Temtem got away with it. You can even throw digimon in there. They also need to lower the amount of Pals it takes to raise a pals star level. It takes an obnoxious amount to even bring up it up a single star. Finally the bugs, The amount of times my pals decided to leave the base or get stuck in walls is insane. I tried everything to prevent them from getting stuck. You may think it's not a problem. But it is. If your not paying attention. They could starve because they're stuck in the wall. I almost had this happen several times. And the AI is terrible. Alot of times my pals will refuse to attack. And the enemies it's even worse. Specifically talking about raiders. If you have a mount base they will never be a threat to you until they send flying units. Yet despite all that, there is enough here to have a good time. What I recommend is playing on custom difficulty. Which you can edit at anytime. It needs some work. But, they've got something special here.

This game combines the PokÃ©mon genre (with guns) with base building and management mechanics. 

Instead of merely capturing and battling pals, youâll also construct and manage your own bases (which takes up a good chunk of time). This refreshing blend adds depth and variety. Exploring the game world feels organic and intuitive. The landscapes are beautifully crafted, and each region holds different pals. Capturing pals and fighting alongside them is memorable. For an early access title, there's an impressive amount of content. The devs have clearly poured their passion into creating a rich and engaging experience.

Looking forward to how the devs flesh this out in the future!

I am writing this from the perspective of someone who grew up never really catching on to the Pokemon craze. The art was cute but I always found myself going back to Zelda, Spyro, Star Wars games more. Despite that I do enjoy creature catching/hunting games. I really enjoyed Temtem in early access, Dauntless was fun for a while and now Palworld is a hybrid of so many games I enjoy. It combines the early building and survival of The Forest/Minecraft with the creature catching of Pokemon/Temtem and the hunting aspect of Dauntless/Monster Hunter. 

This is what makes the gameloop so addictive. There's always that "one more thing to do" pull. While that starts to wane in the 20s and 30s levels it does still stick around. For the $26 I spent for this game I enjoyed over 100 hours. It catapulted to a top 10 most played Steam games for me. It even made me drop The Finals that I was previously addicted to. Palworld has plenty of bugs and some performance issues but it is still highly enjoyable in its current form. 

I highly recommend it to people that enjoy Survival games with creature capturing/hunting aspects. The building is the weakest part of the game and is similar to The Forest early in development. There isn't half walls or half stair cases and limited clipping you can do. Don't let the "it's a Pokemon clone" comments make you ignore this game. It is good enough to stand on its own legs and even above Pokemon (from the limited Pokemon games I've played). Pick it up !

This game is always compared to Pokem*n, it's not. That's an rpg. This is Ark with a better pet system. It's a survival base builder where capturing Pals is not only your way to level up, but the best way to automate your base. They will collect basic supplies for you as you are away. The boss system is akin to Dark Souls, dodge and roll and use your pals as a diversion.

This is a great game.  Thoughtful combination of a bunch of different genres, monster collector, survival crafting, sci-fi action RPG.  Reasonably polished for Early Access with plenty of content.  Tons of fun Pals to collect, battle with, and have run automated tasks in your base.  It does a good job of not being too stressful or throwing too many mechanics at you, letting you learn at your desired pace and not making the survival aspects anything too realistic or brutal.  It's good escapism, it's got that addicting quality, and the Pals are very lovable.  Yes, the devs added petting functionality because they knew we would want it.

Great game but I can't recommend it yet until they fix some things..

At least for single player..

- I lost all 200 hrs of progress when my game crashed, logged on and my world is gone. I've tried multiple fixes but nothing has worked to bring it back. 

- Pals (especially the bigger ones) have incredibly bad pathing in a base. They get stuck on everything, so you can't really build a base they way you'd want because it ends up being a jail cell for your pals who will get stuck in the walls or on some feature you built. 

- Pals are constantly avoiding their assigned tasks lol. The breeding farm has been a nightmare keeping an eye on your pals so they don't wander off.

- Unfortunately its very unbalanced right now too. Legendary pals are the only ones worth using, even if you breed a beast they will never have that extra 10k HP...

- Falling through the world or getting stuck inside walls in very common. That includes your pals & wild ones too.

Palworld: Team Rocket RPG Takes the Crown!

I've been a Pokemon fan since forever, but Nintendo's games didn't quite hit the spot for me. Then I stumbled upon Palworld, thinking it was just a parody. Turns out, it's a game-changer.

Palworld felt like the game I've been waiting for. The market needed this, big time. From creating bases to catching pals in different places â it's a blast! And yes, Team Rocket RPG totally won me over.

This game's got the perfect balance. Bases are like crazy hubs of fun, and catching pals in various spots, raids and legendary pals keep things interesting. Palworld took the cool parts of Pokemon, mixed in some wild chaos, and bam â you've got a game that's pure entertainment. Enslaving pals (oops, I mean catching) has never been this much fun!

In a sea of same-old games, Palworld is a breath of fresh air. It's like Pokemon and chaos had a baby, creating a mix of cool and cute animal collecting that's been missing. Early Access started strong, and it's already a surprise hit. 

So, get ready for Team Rocket RPG to steal the show. Palworld is not just a game, it's a rollercoaster of excitement where every catch spins into an adventure and losing half your spheres trying to capture Jet Dragon, and yeah, you're going to die a lot during the process.

At the time of writing this review I currently have 178 hours invested into the game. With that said, I can say that the game has me hooked. I wanted to add my input on this game, as I am excited to see where it goes in the future. 
So, what do I like about Palworld? My simple answer is this game is unique to the point it has held my attention since I first picked it up weeks ago. Itâs apparent through its seismic initial release that there has been a desire for something fresh as opposed to what we have, up until now, had to settle on with recent Pokemon games. To be honest I played Shield for a long time, couldn't stomach Arceus, and put Scarlet down in a matter of hours. I can admit that those titles target a younger audience now, so it does make sense the appeal is just not there anymore. However, those of us who grew up on Pokemon are now in our 30's or 40âs and we want something a little more mature and engaging. This is where I see Palworld having the potential to really take things further with the genre.
Really, the game keeps you busy grinding away on managing your bases. From setting up production lines of key resources to just making components to crafted items, this game isnât for those who do not enjoy this type of grind. However, I prefer games that require a grind as it gives me something to do. Apart from that, venturing out to capture Pals and clear the tower bosses is a nice goal keep me pushing forward. This is where I can see the developers adding in more tower bosses and even raids (pretty sure they already are working on this). 
All in all, Iâm interested to see how big this world gets and what else gets added as features.

Extremely fun especially due to its creativity and the design of a cartoonish game with real world elements that wouldn't usually be put into a cartoon like game IE Tiny chipmunk with a submachine gun, dinosaurs that shoot FUCKING ROCKETS and all the shenanigans and dumb stuff you can do. The dumbest things can make games so much more fun like being able to punt a living ball of wool across the map or blowing up a village on a dinosaur strapped with Grenade launchers. Just the perfect variety of  exploration, discovery, funny names, diversity of tools and weapons as well as the diversity of creatures along with the weapons and guns they can be strapped with just make this game really fun. And an open world game that follows a story line whilst still allowing the player to have as much freedom to do whatever they want is really nice. you're not forced to go straight to the next "checkpoint" if you will. Also they somehow made farming and grinding resources and exp surprisingly fun. Love this game so much even tho its still in development. There is so much room for adding even more dumb and funny things. This game has huge potential. Id say just as much potential as minecraft when it was in its early stages, and that is something very very few games can accomplish. Anyway Im looking forward to the future of this game and I'll be playing it all the while. AND THANKYOU DEVELOPERS AND GAME/GRAPHICS DESIGNERS AND EVERYONE ELSE WORKING HARD TO MAKE THIS GAME, YOU'RE ALL DOING AN AMAZING JOB!

Been burned by early access before, but this game is just full of potential. It is very rough using mostly stock movement and ai, and has map bugs on par with rust or ark... yet It has a very fun gameplay loop, as everyone says its pokemon(actually closer to shin magami tensei since YOU actively take part in combat) but new and fresh.


Pros 

The capture system is pretty rich taking into account hp, positioning, aggro, status effects, and current hp. As such you are rewarded for putting in a more effort. It would be nice if we had some pal moves that had high status rates and low/no damage but I'm sure that will come.

The pal skills are mostly pretty good, with very few that seriously need tweaking. Ice missile can be deleted tho...

The animations while simple and not so evenly spread across all pals for now, are ooozing personality... ~depresso~ laying face down in the spa pool is priceless. Not all pals have unique animations as of now, but hopefully they will be filled out as they game progresses. 

The world has a good bit of flavor for now design wise. Also movement is ... pretty good for a early access title. The inputs are a bit weird in places like having to cancel your grapple with ctrl rather than another mouse click OR simply hitting space to cancel right into your glider. I'd like to see the gliders and grapple flow a bit more like Just Cause in the future, aka being able to grapple objects mid glide then cancel back into gliding in order to boost your momentum and regain height. 

Most pals DO have a function, and while some will be simply replaced in their respective roles, the breeding system allowing you to crossbreed to create different pals allows you to benefit from all tiers of pals by using low tier pals as quick breeding stock to compile skills and IV's to pass onto your desired final species.

Cons ~earlyaccess woes~

The ai is barely functional for now, resulting in mobs suddenly becoming lobotomized, staring off into the void while you shoot them, or running into walls. No easy out here, they used stock ai, and it shows. hopefully the billions they are making right now is enough to hire a competent ai dev to really bring the wildlife... to life.

Movement pal skills are VERY broken, the pathing is very broken so dash skills will just get stuck on tiny objects or map dips causing them to dash in place... and leaps are even worse as they suffer from collision with their target, causing larger body targets to shoved them out of the area they are attempting to land mid animation either resulting in them missing the long cooldown ability OR getting stuck mid dive forever. Partially removing collision during said skills should easily solve this easy enough however.

Difficulty is not really difficult, just punishing. The difference between hard and easy is how much pal damage the player takes. Basically on hard you WILL get one shot or 2 shot if you have a shield, and unfortunately the ai does not like to pokemon battle. Aka you throw out your pal, and the enemies just attacks you instead. As a result even low level spots are insanely threatening even if your pal is a absolute immortal death machine... and there is little you can do to resolve your characters durability besides hide in a corner(also causing the bosses to just run into walls trying to reach you while your pal fists them from behind).

 Furthermore riding mounts does NOT offer any immunity to attacks, so in ~hard mode~ doing so is a death sentence. Lost track of how many times I was insta killed off the back of my pal from a homing attack shot as I passed by. Tho depending on your active pals ~intimidation~ hidden stat wild pals will just ignore you or run from you.

You WILL clip through the ground and into walls, yet you can not actually swim at least there is not diving/underwater content as of yet, and very little in terms of sub terrain content. A huge missed opportunity that will hopefully be corrected going forward.

Hopefully a more advanced ai will have wild pals only retaliate against the player directly IF they are attacking them directly, otherwise having the ai focus on the players pal first, OR offer more in terms of player defensive progression so that the attacks from those lower level pals are as impotent against the high level player as their pals.

There is no Vaporeon, and lovander feels a bit too bill cosby for my taste.

Pro/con

Alot of the current pals are just pallet swaps or very slightly tweaked ~evolutions~ of eachother. This is nice if you like your early pals designs, but results in a the actual selection of pals being quite limited for now. Its a good idea to create progression lines for popular species, but I personally prefer a wider range of more unique creatures to encounter.

The game is just full of potential, but its just that ~unachieved potential~ IF the studio is serious this could easily be a minecraft situation... or they could grab the bag and run treating it as a simple indie pump and dump.

 I actually bought this game because I don't see how they could rationalize doing so with all the attention they have gotten. AAA studios spend BILLIONS trying to get this level of positive fan reception, so it would be pretty stupid to let it go to waste.
