Very addicting gameplay, I have "completed" the game (Being in Early Access and not completely finished I have all current Pals and completed all achievements) and still am having fun with the base building and farming drops. I also am thinking of starting over a new with a few friends on a server. This is a great game for those who like survival games and creature catching games. It has a very fun game play loop and if you like farming there's plenty of that as well though there are multiple ways to cut down on manual farming if your not a fan as well. Overall, very excited to see what is to come in the future with this game and hope for a long success and a long life span both to enjoy such a great game and to bring some competition to certain genres. 12/10 rating (Even though there were a few bugs that got worked out with updates I still give this game this rating especially with interviews of the developers and how they view their community and the gamin community as a whole for bonus points. Finally developers that seem to care what the fans/players want and think), this game is Highly Recommended it scratches the itch for multiple genres, and where most games fall flat when trying to cover a multitude of different game-play styles this game takes a little bit of everything and somehow makes it all good.

I'm not sure what is is about Palworld that made a certain corner of the internet furiously hate it for any reason they can think of, and refuse to give it any kind of respect.

Nintendo fans savagely trying to cope?  Maybe.  People with AI derangement syndrome going rabid when someone even implies something might have to do with AI?  Perhaps.

Whatever the claim, they keep moving the goalposts to continue hating it.  First it was wild claims of AI that proved to be false.  Then claims of copying which turned out to be made up.  Then calling it low effort, which is easily disproven if you play it for 4 hours.  Now they've gone on to call the player count dropping a sign that it's bad.  The truth is they put their 60-80 hours in and have finished the game, so are moving on like any normal person does all the time.  There will be some new reason they hate it next week.

That's all not to say it's a perfect game.  Or that the game isn't clearly heavily, heavily inspired.  Or that its using lots of popular game mechanics just to attract people.  But there's nothing wrong with any of that.  In fact, most AAA games do that too, they just maybe don't make it as obvious.

If you like survival crafters, and like pokemon, you'll have fun with this game.  If you hate those game genres, you won't.  And that's about all their is to it.

[h1] Builds on the Pokemon formula in a compelling manner (it is not just a rip-off). [/h1] 

The core gameplay loop of capturing more Pals, unlocking new tech, developing your base and gear, and then venturing out to battle or capture even harder Pals is quite compelling. Graphics are cartoony but suits the world quite well, performance is okay (but to be fair it is still in Early access). 

Does not have a story mode or any major quests at the moment - but this could be added in future updates. 

Overall it's a really enjoyable game to play and in pretty good shape for an Early Access Title. If you are fond of more narrative driven titles or need an intriguing objective/sign post to drive towards - then your mileage might vary. But if great gameplay, decent base building mechanics, and interacting with magnificent Pals is what you are after - then this is the game for you! Scratches the itch that Pokemon has never been able to.

Multiplayer is unstable a somehow riddled with hackers. The game itself needs a little polish but it overall a good time, particularly if you get friends on board.

So far its basically a weird love child between Arc: Survival Evolved and Pokemon with some Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild mixed in. I am mostly a crafter so I will not speak much on combat, but it seems alright. Nothing too special but nothing much wrong with it.

Crafting is split between what you can and cannot do. Most things can be done with the right Pal, but there are some things that you can also help with. Farming, Repairing, and Cooking food are some examples. Item Progression flows alright, and sometimes it helps to have the right Pal for the job. Unless you stack Work Speed, then you leave all your Pals in the dust and only need the ones for the work you can't do yourself. Crushers(Water Pal), Furnaces(Fire Pal), Etc.

Multiplayer it a bit of a hot mess. None of the hackers are being banned yet so the servers are riddled with them. The servers themselves are laggy and unstable, and chat cuts your sentences off. Your better just keeping the fun to you and your friends or going solo for the time being. But it can be good fun if you don't mind the problems.

This Frankenstein's Monster of a game is AMAZING. Fortnite + Ark + Pokemon. Who knew it would work as well as it does. Such a fun game. It can be a survival crafter. It can be an FPS. It can be a monster catching game. Love it.

The Pals work well with the survival crafting aspects and really help reduce a lot of the grind for resources that you'd be confronted with in other games in the genre. 

Special shout out to the customization sliders, you can change almost everything about the world. Want more items to drop? You got it. More XP? Sure. More Pals spawn in the world? Yup. You take more damage? Of course. Don't want to wait an hour or two for eggs to hatch? Just change the slider.

Really lets you make the game your own. If you're playing online they're set by the server. If you're single player you can change them as much as you want. Makes this game super approachable for casual players, can make super grindy (less resources, less xp) if you want that, you can make combat difficult if you want to be challenged that way. Really unique, more games should do this.

In the same vein, the memes about forced labor can be funny the first time or two because of how ridiculous it seems, but the game really doesn't lean in to it that much. It's really the player that can make life hell for the pals. You can give 'em luxury beds, hot tubs, feed them pizza and burgers and salad, pet them, let them take breaks and eat whenever they want, give them medicine when they're sick, etc. Or if you're a psycho.... you could force them to work grueling days, give them limited breaks, make them sleep in piles of hay, make them continue to work while injured, force them to eat raw meat, and then butcher them when they inevitably start lagging. The game is super open and really lets you play how you want.

Overall, this game is pretty much everything I ever wanted since I was a kid, it's so open. It lets you interact with your Pals and actually fight alongside them, it's great. Gonna date myself, but remember how Pikachu coming out of the ball and following you around was such a big deal in Pokemon Yellow? I feel like Pokemon never really evolved past that surface level of interaction with your Pokemeon. Even the most recent ones (maybe with the exception of Legends: Arceus) don't come close to touching the level of "creating a squad and your own community of cartoon monsters" that Palworld does.

This game takes that and blows through the stratosphere. I didn't know this mashup was even possible. Fight with your big green panda. Give your big green panda a grenade launcher. Shoot your penguin friend out of a cannon. Fight with a big beetle pal that protects you and adds to your defense. Throw a pink cat at  your enemies and watch it scratch and distract them while you focus on getting headshots. Almost any strategy is viable, and even some of the cute Pals from early in the game can stay relevant throughout. Oh, and there's base building and everything else to go along with that. I don't remember being this obsessed with a new game since Elden Ring.

It's still in early access and there's supposed to be a lot more content coming, but even in its current state it's worth it (IMO). I've easily gotten 50 hours out of it, and had a blast the entire time.

One thing to note: DON'T play on official servers. I play local single player but from videos and posts I've seen, there is rampant griefing and cheating that the devs are having a difficult time squashing. Some people are losing entire bases and lots of progress. I mean, the game's been out for like a month and they weren't expecting it to be this big. I don't blame the devs, just stay off of official servers for now. Either host your own (or buy a virtual server to use) or play single player until this is fixed.

One other minor thing: Type advantages are suuuuper simplified. I'm fine with it, it makes it more accessible, but it takes some adjusting if you're used to Pokemon. I can't count the amount of times I used ice moves against grass, or water moves against ground types, or electric attacks on a flier, etc. thinking they'd all be extra effective when they weren't. There was def an adjustment period. Part of me hopes they add a bit more complexity, but deep down I know that's probably a bad idea.

Very fun early access game. Can't wait for future updates. What could be wrong with an open world, pal collecting game. Dungeons, hard bosses, legendary gear, cool lucky pets, and many serotonins when leveling up. Progression is smooth and doesn't have too many instances of feeling like you aren't making progress. Late game can be tough to level up, but that's the challenge. There's a little bit of everything. Base building, ease for optimization (you can be SUPER efficient if you want to), exploration, AFK-ability, multiplayer on single player worlds (no separate saves for different game types - you can turn on multiplayer whenever for small servers). I've sank an ungodly amount of hours into this game and plan to continue!

5 hours in I can see why people really do enjoy this game.

It is relaxing. It isn't hard. But it is annoying in one particular way.

Coming from a background of survival craft games, Palworld has easily one of the worst base building mechanics I have ever interacted with. At least in the early game. If how the wooden constructs operate are indicative of how the rest of the constructs in the game operate, it'll be frustrating for anyone who has enjoyed base building in other survival craft games. The only one that I can think of off the top of my head that is worse than this is Stranded Deep, but that's a different expectation to base building. When you have an open world and open ended building, it needs to be crisp, not clunky and frustrating to use.

If you're someone who really loves base building like I do, you're definitely going to have an aneurysm like I did. It is still a great game nonetheless. Hopefully since it is in early access, this is an area I expect to be vastly improved.

I am writing just as someone who grew up with the Pokemon-craze as a kid and still enjoy it as an adult:

I will choose Palworld over Pokemon any day.

The franchise of Pokemon was dying, and it became more and more obvious that they were just following the same boring formula, becoming lazier in implementing an open world in this form.

I got so bored of pokemon sword and shield and other versions since it was always new pokemon and non of the old ones were featured. Yeah you could take them for picnics, but it was all the same wasn't it? A team rocket you had to defeat, defeat these big trainers to move on...and the pokemon couldn't follow you all the way unless you got to the end game or something silly.

Palworld, it has that, but so much more! Explore a huge map, climb mountains, find treasure chests, craft, cook, survive. Take your Pal everywhere you go and make a new home and family with them while protecting your base for threats of the world!

I have been playing for 70 hours, mostly because I was just trying to get a flying pal I loved and explore it with my Pal/friend.

The world is beautiful and fun to interact with, and finding random eggs in various hiding spots is my favourite hobby.

It is nice that you can just enjoy the world instead of always battling and fighting; this is what Pokemon has been missing, a way to just enjoy yourself with no pressure to follow their formula to get through the game; just play as you wish and explore.
I still like Pokemon more

Addicting, Needs late game balancing to remain fun.

Palworld is a nice relaxing game to play, especially with friends. The best aspect of the game is the variety of Pals to collect and the roles they perform in base building. Some key features that enhance game play are; multiple bases, base material varieties, Pal variety, and auto Pal working. This game is currently in early access and will continue to add new and improved features. Some future features that would enhance game play includes; Pal roles management system, reduction in Pal condensing system, a mini story line, and better base snapping system. Overall, Palworld is a fun game that allows for exploration, Pal collecting, and interesting battles.

**People say this game is a low-effort copy of Pokemon, it is not**
Palworld has no official proof of copyright infringement, IP theft, or even using AI technology to design their creatures. Please do not believe everything you read on Twitter.

The only similarity to Pokemon this game has is being able to capture creatures in balls. That's it. Beyond that, this game is actually much more similar to survival/ exploration games such as ARK. Typically, I don't play survival games like that, but I've enjoyed this very much! The Pals are very cute, and even while some share clear inspiration of some Pokemon, many of them are entirely unique and creative. 

The world is very large and fun to explore, especially alongside a Pal you can ride. The combat is fun shooter-style action with dodge rolls and sometimes hiding while your Pal dishes out attacks. Much like ARK, you can ride a Pal and use their abilities to fight, whether that's breathing fire or wielding a mini gun. Base building is a bit archaic and needs updating, but I like it. It's fun building a base that's efficient and aesthetic at the same time, and I like that each Pal has their own jobs they can perform to varying levels of skill. 

I've had tons of fun playing this and look forward to future updates as the game continues through early access.

Better than anything a certain monster collector game series has put out in it's entire runtime, and the first game I ever owned was Blue.

Yes there are bugs, glitches, and issues. It's missing depth and memorability. But the gameplay loop is a constant stream of satisfaction, the progression of your character and the scale of the world is a straight line up. It's ridiculously charming how much personality is in the animations for your pals, and how much the game is trying to pack all in to one experience. There are things that could be added from it's opposing games in the genre that would improve it in many ways and that's an easy arguement to make. But if you want to make it, realize that it should go both ways and Palworld blows its competition out of the water with a blindsided alpha release that has plenty of content to come.

If you want to argue that craftopia was a failure, it released in a very negative state and did nothing but improve for years in to a quite enjoyable game. If this is Palworld on release, I am nothing but excited for it's future. Not to mention the modding community is already hard at work creating the tools for people to create their own perfect experience.

It's satisfying, fun, a massive world full of things to enjoy/collect/craft whether you're solo or with a group. Just play the game. To say I've gotten my moneys worth would be a hilarious understatement.

Linux support is rough as it stands with Unreal games, but Palworld really pushed my machine in strange and interesting ways. I've been hard it, getting stuff like FSR, NVAPI, and various little community-made optimisations going.

At first it just ran bad. To be expected, it's unoptimised and you're basically getting a dev build for what you pay for. You would be fine if you played for a bit then saved, went back to the main menu, and then loaded again. Seems like after a while of playing the game is slacking off and doesn't manage memory properly. I still can't tell if it's GPU or CPU related, but there's more to be said about VRAM in a moment.

After more tuning I was starting to get more consistent performance. Capped my frame rate to 30 to save on frame processing time, and actually got a workaround to replace DLSS with FSR, which is something my 1060 lacked.

Now today as of writing, I ran into a fun new issue. The game was running better than ever. Sure! I'll take the boon. But, why was it running better? Up until now I couldn't see how much VRAM was actually being used until I finally crashed for the first time. 50 hours in, first crash. But the crash was caused by an out of memory error on the graphics pipeline. Oh hell. I have 6GB of VRAM. You mean to tell me it wanted even more? This does make me conclude that at current, Palworld's graphics are its biggest problem and if you wanna play it, seek out the various tricks to wrench down and optimise memory usage.

---

As for the game itself, it's addicting, sure. It does things no other monster raising RPG has done before, or had a stronger investment toward doing.
At times, Palworld does have moments of being itself. I think the core combat is where that comes from.
You can be tag-teaming a boss with your Pal, trading who's got agro. It could use some more flavour like a more in-depth command system instead of "attack", "attack but only who i'm attacking", and "don't attack ever, even when you're getting hurt".

I'd love to see an option where my Pal could just, lower the enemy's health to as low as it can get without killing it and backing off so I can try to capture. Hints that the Pal combat system is not fully cooked yet and I'll just have to wait for future updates. Fine.

There's also stuff like collecting ammo that's useless until several hours and levels in (such as AR and shotgun ammo), which makes me think we need more middle-tier weapons that can make use of them, even if they're garbage.

The NPC pathing is absolute dog. You need to build a whole parking lot on your base just to make sure the Grinder or Mill has enough space for a water Pal to power them. There's no clear indication whether NPCs of any size can even path to a certain place, and you kind of just need to guess and watch what they do.

Balance changes are needed. The handgun is pointless. Expensive to make ammo for. Makes zero sense to use when the Makeshift is more powerful for cheaper material cost. While we're on it the rifle ammo almost makes sense, but I'd like to produce 10 ammo instead of 5. Or the other way around and have handgun ammo produce 10 rounds.

Otherwise, making use of your Pal party is required to compensate for either a lack of firepower, or ammo. Their ammo is food. Kind of a strange balance, but I wouldn't say no to a change.

---

There's so much stacked up against this game. Whether it's controversy, the developers being harassed, or just the concept of the game in general. There are those who want to hate this game and see it fail so badly. Maybe even suggest that you play other similar games, made by even smaller devs, even if the gameplay is nothing like it.

---

Stuff I like.
It's not "X, but messed up", like some have suggested. It's got a medley of game mechanics and aesthetics going on where I'm not sure anymore if it's genuinely "derivative" of its contemporaries more than it is a cute jab to say hey, witness me. It may not even share the same look by its release for all we know.

The Pal designs themselves are fun too. They aren't garish and (not all of them) are designed to be these provocative parody level creatures. It's fresh. Some are really thought through. Yes, I do think there's a couple of Pals that get dangerously close to being a full-fledged parody. Not naming names, but the second or third Pal you see in the game is straight up just a stylised cartoon chicken. ;D

--

Verdict? All I can say is if you have been eyeing this game, don't feel bad for buying it. Some of you may find it more worth to wait a year when more dev-time has been put in, and I respect it.
For right now, Palworld is what I believe many would call it "feature complete". There's still a lot more PP could do, and much that really needs to get done. But if you're on the fence, this side does have some nice lush grass to sit in. Come on down.

I provided the best working conditions for my pals;
I gave them better food,
I gave them the best beds.
I gave them jobs,
I gave them families,
I made them stronger!

All I wanted in turn was to borrow their power,
The power to defend my shelter.
The power to explore the islands.
The power to make other pals submit.
and,
The power to decimate those who sat comfortably in their towers.

At the end, I never really knew what I really sought...

An awesome blend of mechanics, styling and features drawing inspiration from some of the finest gaming experiences ever made. Progressive AF. GG.

It plays like ARK with visuals evoking the charm of Zelda, promising players a survival and adventure experience like no other. The addition of Pals, alongside collecting and breeding, adds depth to both PvP and automated farming, enhancing the overall gameplay.

Dedicated servers and PvP mechanics opens doors to boundless possibilities, encouraging both co-op ventures and intense duels among comrades. While the concept of raiding and base defence holds promise, current challenges such as duping and cheating detract from its viability. Still, the potential for skirmishes with your chosen companions is undeniable.

As with many titles in their early access phase, Palworld grapples with the inevitable rough edges and technical hurdles that accompany such ambitious projects. Frequent hiccups and occasional glitches disrupt immersion, particularly when Pals encounter issues navigating environments.  The developers show a lot of promise in addressing issues and coming features, it is early and I can only hope they dont pander too much to all the silly noise and jealously that comes with the hype. While it's early days, maintaining focus on the core idea and optimising to perfection could lead to lasting success.

While its current state may deter some, those willing to weather the storm of early access may find themselves really enjoying the game as I have. Palworld has the foundation for greatness and definitely has the opportunity to evolve into a standout title within the gaming landscape. Don't listen to all the dweeb pretend nerds that cant let go of the past and autisming hard for nostalgia, they are the reason nobody even wants to dev for the- 'now now now, entitled ego rat generations' anymore. Majority of games now are just swindles and mental loop traps.

Highly recommend running a 10x dedi with your crew and duelling.

PalWorld is an amazing game that deserves a perfect score of 10/10 for the innovative way it approaches the monster-collection genre. Far from being a simple copy, it makes its own niche by brilliantly combining different types of gameplay to suit a wide range of gamers' tastes. Here are some reasons why PalWorld is a great adventure that deserves all the praise it gets.

Gameplay: PalWorld has great game play, with survival elements, strategic battles, and a large crafting system all working together to make a smooth and fun experience. There are so many things to do that players get lost. They can build complex bases with the help of their Pals or fight in high-stakes battles that test their strategic thinking. PalWorld is a unique game that pushes the limits of its genre thanks to its deep gameplay that makes every moment full of discovery and excitement.

Replay Value: PalWorld has a huge amount of replay value because the world is always changing and there are so many Pals to find, friend, and fight. The open world of the game makes it fun to explore and try new things. In battle, you can use different strategies and put together different teams. Also, the crafting and base-building features let you be as creative as you want, so no two players will have the same experience. PalWorld is a game that people will want to play again and again because it has so many different parts. Each time is like a new adventure.

Multiple Players: Playing PalWorld with friends makes it even more fun. As players work together to defeat tough enemies, fight, or just explore the huge world, the game encourages friendship and a sense of shared adventure. PalWorld is a great choice for people who want to share their gaming experience with others because it has a multiplayer mode that adds a lot of fun and teamwork that you can't find anywhere else.

Graphics and World Design: PalWorld's graphics are stunning, and every part of the game's huge world is rendered with great care. The settings are not only beautiful, but also full of life, making players want to explore every corner. They range from lush forests to dry deserts. The design of the Pals is just as impressive. They have a lot of different creatures that are creative and look good. This careful attention to detail in the graphics and world design makes PalWorld a very immersive experience.

Unique Features: PalWorld stands out from other games because it has unique features that make the game more fun in real ways. Survival elements give the adventure a more realistic and urgent feel, and the full crafting system lets you be as creative as you want when you build and customize your character. These features, along with the strategic depth of PalWorld's combat, make for a fun and challenging gaming experience.

For the most part, PalWorld is a great game that deserves all the praise it gets. It's a great example of what creativity and passion can do in the gaming industry because it has great gameplay, a lot of replay value, fun multiplayer options, beautiful graphics, and new features. No, PalWorld is not just a game. It's an unforgettable adventure that gets 10/10 from all of us.

Considering early access, it's all good though.

This game puts Game Freak to shame and shows that you don't have to be a multibillion-dollar company to make something incredible. A small indie company managed to create Palworld, a game that is arguably better than Pokemon S/V, despite the latter being produced by hundreds of industry professionals with years of experience in game development. Palworld has striking graphics (at least compared to Pokemon) and addicting game play. Each pal has various animations that add depth to their personalities. Additionally, I've seen a lot of criticism online about the inconsistent art style, but I personally like the juxtaposition between the cartoonish pals and the realistic world. Pals are reminiscent of Pokemon, which automatically gives them an innocent nature since that franchise is targeted towards children. Meanwhile, the realistic world emphasizes the very dark and real-life themes that are prevalent in Palworld. 

Palworld does have numerous bugs, but so did Pokemon S/V upon its initial release, which is unacceptable considering its $60 price tag and the unlimited resources available to its developers. Ever since Pokemon transitioned to the Switch, Game Freak has produced nothing but half-baked games, because they know any Pokemon game will sell due to brand recognition and nostalgia. Pocket Pair put passion into this game, which in evident in the quality. They also took significant risk and almost went bankrupt trying to get this project off the ground. Even after its release, they're regularly coming out with patches to improve and refine the game for players. Palworld is half the price of modern day Pokemon games, yet it's far more enjoyable IMO.

With all that being said, the only big issue I have with this game are the blatant rip-offs of certain Pokemon (Verdash, Fenglope, Dinossom to name a few). I know Pocket Pair was working on a tight budget, but I honestly would've preferred less pals in this game if it meant we didn't have some that felt totally uninspired and looked AI generated. All in all, a great game though. 8/10.

The game itself is very solid. It is still in early access, however the developers have been releasing regular patches to fix the small bugs that are present. Unlike other games of this style, there are very few, if any, game breaking bugs. While the game itself is based around capturing "pals" to help you with combat and around the base, the combat mechanics are fluid enough that you could successfully beat most of the alphas without using pals if you are familiar with games that have "dark souls-like" combat. Many of the "pals" have passive abilities that you can utilize without having them "active", allowing for more forgiveness when participating in these style fights.  If your looking for an interesting sandbox survival game, I highly recommend trying Palworld.

Overall been a great game for me. Like a combo of Pokemon, Ark, Rust, and Satisfactory wrapped together. Still buggy and got issues but that's why it's early access, play at your own risk with beta's. I've bought the game for a few friends as well and they're all enjoying it is much as I am. For an early access title this certainly offers far more playable game play than others I've played. I've paid far more for games that I only got 30-50 hours of game play out of then never touched again.. and this is only 50-60% complete leading up to full release, excluding and DLC or Expansions after.

Where it sit's right now I'd give it a 7.5/10, if or once they get all the bugs and multiplayer issues ironed out, and more content, an easy 10/10 GOTY Nominee/Contender.
Better game then anything Game Freak could cook up.
